This city is crawling with Imperial Legion, and you know what? I'm still nervous. All these damn Stormcloaks. They're making me nervous. Never in a million years did I imagine they'd gain control of Solitude.

Lazy and useless, the lot of them. They can't even keep the Stormcloaks in line. No way I trust them with the Emperor's life. I'm all for diplomacy, but the sooner the Emperor deals with this civil war mess, the sooner we can get back to Cyrodiil.
You worry too much. The Emperor's never been safer. You think assassination attempts are planned overnight? We discovered the plot. End of threat.
Aha! Here we are. Honored guests, I present to you - the Gourmet!
You, an assassin for the Dark Brotherhood, have just made an attempt on the Emperor's life. Would have succeeded, had it been the real man.
Quite. Yet that recent business with the young officer. Maro, was it? How dreadful. The son of your commander, plotting your assassination.
Surprised? So was I, when a member of your "Family" came to me with the plan. We worked out a deal, you see. An exchange.
Ah, the Potage le Magnifique. So delicious. My friends, as Emperor, I of course reserve the right of first taste.
Yes, an unfortunate turn of events, that. But an isolated incident. And I have been assured that the fault was with the man's son alone.
(Laughing.)
I get you, and the Dark Brotherhood gets to continue its existence.
Kill him. And make sure there's nothing left to bury. Kill her. And make sure there's nothing left to bury.
By the gods! The Gourmet has killed the Emperor! Attack! By the gods! The Gourmet and the chef have poisoned the Emperor! Get them!
You mean the wedding? My cousin's apparent murder? An unfortunate misunderstanding, no more. Cold mead, hot tempers... these things happen.
But you know what? I've changed my mind. How about this? I kill you, and butcher each and every one of your miserable little friends?
But aren't even you the least bit nervous? After everything that's happened?
Truth is, we are in no danger whatsoever. Killing an Emperor can be useful, but befriending one? Now that's beneficial - as I'm sure you'd all agree.
(Clapping.)
Here we are. Gods, I'm nervous. We'll go in in just a moment. Please, I'll serve. You just stand there and... be amazing.
That man was, by far, the most insufferable decoy the Emperor has ever employed. I'm glad he's dead. Ah, but I'm even happier that you killed him.
Your Sanctuary's being put to the sword right now. That's what I think of this "deal." You killed my son! All of you! And now you'll pay the price.
What? No! No, you don't understand! There's been some kind of mistake! I... Aggghhh!
Listener. I am your only salvation. Come. Embrace me.
I'm not exactly built for manual labor. Now come on, you've almost got it.
One more... pull...
Can you get it open?
Yeeaahh! There.
I think so. Just hold on a moment.
Hurry, Nazir! I'm telling you, he's in there! Hurry, Nazir! I'm telling you, she's in there!
You must speak with Astrid. Here, in the Dark Brotherhood Sanctuary.
I'm going... as fast... as I can, you stupid she-devil. I don't see you... helping...
Speak with Amaund Motierre at the Bannered Mare in Whiterun. He will know the true Emperor's location.
But first, inform Nazir of your plans. For you are the Listener, and must bind this Family together.
Astrid is dead. It is as it should be. May she find redemption in the Void.
But while you live, the Dark Brotherhood lives. We must fulfill our contract. Emperor Titus Mede II must be eliminated.
Which one was the rat?
Arcturus took some men deeper in, wanted to be sure. We should maybe... assist them.
Suppose not. But what's taking the others so long? The sooner we get out of here, the better. Smoke's getting bad. This place'll be raging soon.
Dunno. One of these corpses. Does it matter?
You assist all you like. And get roasted for your trouble. I'll guard the exit.
What's the bloody hold up in there? How long can it take to run through a few scraggly assassins?
If they were easy to kill, don't you think we would have done it years ago? If our men aren't out in a few minutes, they're dead, trust me.
Anyway, I can smell the smoke. They've already set the place alight.
And so ends the Dark Brotherhood, once and for all. About bloody time.
If I am to die today, so be it. But you'll not soon forget the Dark Brotherhood.
Sleep.
Damn it, there's got to be a way out of here!
It is done. Emperor Titus Mede II lies dead, and the Dark Brotherhood yet lives.
And, once more, I prove Commander Maro the fool. I told him you can't stop the Dark Brotherhood. Never could.
Hmph. Now there's an excellent question. An excellent question, indeed. Truth is, as soon as the Emperor sets sail,  I'm resigning my position.
The honor has been mine. You should be proud of what we've accomplished here. The Dark Brotherhood is no more. And the Emperor, finally, is safe.
And the outpost at Dragon Bridge?
Very good. And you'll be returning to... Well, if you don't mind me asking, where exactly will you be going now, sir?
Yes sir.
Oh... I see. Well then, let me be just say that it's been an honor serving under you Commander Maro.
It'll be shuttered by the end of the month.
Babette, my girl - pack your things. We're moving.
I was hoping you'd say that.
But our work is just beginning. Approach me, Listener, and hear my words.
Yeah. I'm glad we can finally stand down- getting tired of looking over my shoulder all the time.
Well, it's all over now. Lieutenant said you could see the smoke from Whiterun.
I think we'll all feel better once we're back out to sea. Won't be long now.
Dragons, murder, rebellion... and we sail right into the middle of it with the Emperor on board.
Gods, I'll be glad to see the last of Skyrim.
Nothing to do now but sit back, relax, and enjoy the trip home.
*Sigh*... and that's the last one. All right, enough of this.
C'mon, let's get something to eat.

Speak with the Nervous Patron at Candlehearth Hall, in Windhelm. Accept his gold, then kill the target. So begins a contract, bound in blood. Speak with the Wary Outlaw at the Bee and Barb, in Riften. Accept his gold, and then eliminate the target. So begins a contract, bound in blood. Speak with the Corrupt Agent at the Penitus Oculatus Outpost, in Dragon Bridge. Accept his gold, then kill the target. Hail Sithis!   Speak with the Scheming Servant at the Keep in Markarth. Accept his gold, then eliminate the target. So begins a contract, bound in blood. Speak with the Desperate Gambler at the Barracks, in Windhelm. Accept his gold, then eliminate the target. So begins a contract, bound in blood. Speak with the Blasphemous Priest at the Temple of Kynareth, in Whiterun. Accept his gold, then kill the target. Hail Sithis! Speak with the Dishonored Skald at the Bards College, in Solitude. Accept his gold, then eliminate the target. So begins a contract, bound in blood. Speak with the Indolent Farmer at the Vilemyr Inn, in Ivarstead. Accept his gold, then kill the target. So begins a contract, bound in blood. Speak with the Griefstricken Chef, at the Windpeak Inn, here in Dawnstar. Accept his gold, then eliminate the target. Hail the Listener! Hail Sithis! Speak with the Unemployed Laborer at the Frostfruit Inn, in Rorikstead. Accept his gold, then kill the target. So begins a contract, bound in blood.
Yet another child has prayed to their mother.
Come on. Let's see what you're made of.
You want a real fight, eh?
Twelve septims on the big one! Drive that snowback to the ground. Come on! Fight! Fight! You just going to stand there and take it? Fight back. Who taught you to fight? Keep those hands up!
Get him! Get her!
Don't let him get away with this! Come on, he's not so tough. Don't let her get away with this! Come on, she's not so tough.
Not so tough now, are you?
Arvak!
Arvak, please! You can stop running now!
Arvak?
Arvak!  Where are you, boy?
Why?
Gunmar, do you think I could borrow a troll?
Fine. You could've just said 'no'.
Are you mad, woman? After the trouble I've gone through?
Well I need to do some testing on this new weapon, and I was thinking a live target would be helpful.
They're trolls. They smell like trolls. I can't help that either.
I'd also like to not have to smell troll all the time.
I can't help that space is cramped in here, Florentius.
I'd like to be able to make a potion without tasting iron flakes, you know?
Yes, they smell like trolls. But do you have to? Consider washing up a bit more often.
That's why I always try to be ready for anything.
Nothing. Well, not on purpose. But you never know. The strangest accidents can happen at any time.
What are you doing that's so dangerous?
Fairly well, I'd say. I've managed to get this far without blowing myself up, I still have all my limbs...
How is the work coming along?
Have you talked to Isran?
Fair enough.
Why do you think I was asking?
No. I try to avoid it. Always seems to end in an argument. You?
I suppose we're all a little crazy to be here, right?
I didn't say that. I wondered if perhaps he did it for the attention, but every now and then he'll say something that makes me reconsider.
So, you think he's just crazy?
I'm... not sure. I've never heard of the Divines speaking directly to someone before.
Do you think Florentius really talks to Arkay?
Well, that's certainly a line of thinking I can relate to.
And then realizing a troll with armor is even more intimidating.
Oh. Well, I'm not sure. I guess it came from fighting them, thinking "what could be worse?"
I mean, why would that idea even cross your mind?
What?
Why in the world did you ever try putting armor on trolls?
I told you, I've prepared for this. It's going to work.
We're not going to have a problem with your little... project, are we?
We don't have many other options, do we?
If you're so worried about the trolls, why agree to let me go ahead with it?
There's enough for us to fight out there. I don't need us having to defend ourselves within our own fort.
You know I'm more than capable. Why are you bringing this up?
Can I cound on you to handle whatever smithing work we need done? Repairs, new armor, weapons...
I don't relax. Ever.
Right. Well, you can relax. I have it under control.
I can't afford to make any assumptions. That's how people wind up dead.
How are your friends?
Very funny.
I don't know how you do it, getting them into that pen and putting armor on them. A very special relationship, clearly.
What?
Why the trolls, of course! You seem to have quite a way with them.
Which friends would those be?
I didn't even think you knew what a book was, my brutish friend.
Orthjolf, I'm surprised!
Well, well. Where've you been, Vingalmo? Nose stuck in a book all day?
And you'd do well to be more careful of whom you engage in witty banter.
You'd do well to watch that tongue, elf.
Oh, I see. I just assumed he'd sent for both of us. How awkward for you.
What? What meeting? I wasn't informed of any such thing!
Surprised you weren't at the last meeting with our Lord, Vingalmo. Too busy plotting to overthrow him to show up?
No, sire. I have not.
And you haven't forgotten what you need to do, have you?
I am well, sire.
My dear Salonia, how are you?
Wonderful. Carry on, then.
Yes, of course.
No, I don't need anything right now. Please stop asking.
Can I assist you? You know I live to serve.
What?
Do you... do you need anything, Feran?
I don't want to hear about it. I want what I asked for.
Ah, yes. That. There were... well, complications.
Ronthil, where is the last batch of alchemy ingredients I asked you for?
Yes, Feran. Of course. I'll see to it.
Very good. I'll just... I'll be going now.
In the unlikely event that I ever require you for some reason, I shall find you. Until then I see no reason for us to be speaking.
No, I just... I thought perhaps...
I don't recall addressing you, worm.
Vingalmo, is there... can I do anything for you?
Well, maybe it really is time to resurrect the Dawnguard.
Well it was... Thank the Vigilants for ruining that.
Ugh. I thought this place was supposed to be secret?
Hold it! He's the one Tolan mentioned. Hold it! She's the one Tolan mentioned.
Here comes another one!
And so I'm going to give you a chance to get yourself cured.
Since you could've attacked me before now, I'm going to assume this was a little accident on your part.
And it seems we have a problem.
Sorine and Gunmar are settling in.
Glad to see you've taken care of your little problem, and kept it from becoming my problem.
I'll be waiting.
If you can manage that, the Dawnguard still may have use for you.
Welcome back.
Go to Morthal and find Falion. He's the only one I know of in Skyrim that can cure vampirism.
This is all well and good, but do we actually know anything about what they're doing? What do we do now?
All right Isran, you've got us all here. Now what do you want?
If anyone is going to stand in their way, it's going to be us.
And they have an Elder Scroll.
I'm sure you've heard a bit of what we're up against. Powerful vampires, unlike anything we've seen before.
Years of mocking, of dismissal... and now suddenly here you are, begging for help.
Yes, you've explained yourself. I'm supposed to just throw myself in front of you all and offer protection, am I?
Isran, these vampires are different. I know you've disagreed with the Order in the past...
Why not just scream at the top of your lungs "Here we are, monsters! We're oh so tasty! Come and get us!"
Look at these fools, so concerned with tending their precious "beacon."
Well what did you expect, Tolan? Didn't I tell you? Didn't I warn you this would happen?
In the meantime, we're going to get to the bottom of why a vampire showed up here looking for you.
We'll get to that. For now, get acquainted with the space.
Gunmar, there's an area large enough for you to pen up some trolls, get them armored up and ready for use.
Sorine, you'll find room to start your tinkering on that crossbow design you've been working on.
So, welcome to Fort Dawnguard.
Making sure you're not vampires. Can't be too careful.
What are you doing?
Hold it right there.
Let's go have a little chat with it, shall we?
They threw me out, Tolan!
I know, and I'm sorry that happened. But now...
That make you feel any better?
There you are. Give me a hand with this door, would you? There you are. Looks like this place has been cleaned out. At least the shard is still here...
Come on, I think it's over here.
We meet again. That was quite the trek.
Hey! Grab my journal. If you survive, you're going to need it.
Here's where I fell. Feels like ages ago.
Watch your step.
Not bad. Not bad at all.
Look, there's a chest in there. Door's sealed tight, though...
Falmer up ahead.
(Sigh)...
Watch yourself. Since the quake, this place has been pretty unstable.
Damn things are like flies. No matter how many you kill...
Take good care of it for me.
Hey, there's my bow! There, out on the log. Wondered what happened to it.
Have to say, I'm pretty impressed.
Quite a place, huh? Was even more impressive before it all fell to pieces.
...this is where I ended up. It was... quite the fall.
See if you can find a pattern in the sequence. Most of these locks have a pattern of some kind.
You might look around a bit. Maybe one of our predecessors still has a clue.
Now you decide to give up? Fine. I'll be here.
Turn back...
You could always go back and get my journal, you know.
So this is it...
Well, your loss...
Got it!
Hey! Journal?
If all else fails, just take a chance, see what happens. Wouldn't be surprised if half the traps had been sprung by now...
Grab my journal, would you? We're going to need it.
Really? You had to take the armor? Come on, leave me with a little dignity...
Please, turn back... before it's too late...
See that thing? Dwarves called them 'Kinetic Resonators'. Don't see them very often, least not among the clans in Skyrim.
Almost... Keep going... So close...
That's it... Good... All right...
Oh, gods... Look out! Damn it, not again! Not again!
Just hit them, and they'll... do whatever it is they're supposed to do.
And now... I think I can rest. Farewell, my friend, wherever your travels take you.
Oh, gods...
Got him!
To think... no one's been here in four thousand years...
It's... it's true. It's all true! Come on, let's check it out!
What the... get back! Hurry!
Woah...
Try... taking it out?
Hmm...
Gah... let's clear out this steam so we can take a look.
That took longer than usual. How deep are we?
Is that... the Forge?
Amazing...

It'll be good to get out of the sun for a while. Good, let's get inside there. The sun is starting to get to me. So this is the grand tour of Skyrim's caves that you're showing me? I always wondered what the dwarves actually looked like. I hear they're like elves, but with beards. Another cave. I've spent enough time underground, myself, but if you want to go in, I'm right behind you. Nordic ruins. Even older than I am. I wonder if the draugr are as gullible as they were when I was a girl. Is this a dwarven city? I can't believe they'd let it get so run down.
Oh wow. This is gorgeous.

I'm glad you're here with me. I'll remember this. It's like from the stories I used to hear... the two adventurers seeing the world. This is the kind of thing I've been wanting to see.  Never saw anything like this back on the island. It... almost doesn't even look real. You know? Are you seeing this? It's fantastic!
I never knew it would be this beautiful. Makes everything else worth it. By the blood...
Keep your eyes open, here. Stay on your guard. Did you hear something? I don't like the look of this... Something's not right here. Be careful. I think we may be in for some trouble.
To come in here alone... a fool like all the rest of them.
You wouldn't dare. Now shut up and keep on watch.
And I have half a mind to tell Lokil of your disloyalty.
I wish Lokil would hurry it up. I have half a mind to return to the castle and tell Harkon what a fool he's entrusted this mission to.
All this talk is making me thirsty. Perhaps another Vigilant will wander in soon.
Ha. Those two deserved what they got. Their arrogance had become insufferable.
He fought well though. Jeron and Bresoth were no match for him.
I believe you, Vigilant. And I don't think you even know what you've found here.
Yes, of course Lokil. Do not forget who brought you news of the Vigilants' discovery.
I'll never tell you anything, vampire. My oath to Stendarr is stronger than any suffering you can inflict on me.
And we will not return without it. Vingalmo and Orthjolf will make way for me after this.
He knew nothing. He served his purpose by leading us to this place. Now it is up to us to bring Harkon the prize.
We haven't gotten anywhere ourselves with...
Are you sure that was wise, Lokil? He still might have told us something.
I never forget who my friends are. Or my enemies.
So go and meet your beloved Stendarr.
These Vigilants never know when to give up. I thought we'd taught them enough of a lesson at their hall.
Yes, si... Isran.
That's good enough for me. Go see what the vampires were looking for in this Dimhollow Crypt. With any luck, they'll still be there.
Yes, well... I never wanted any of this to happen. I tried to warn all of you... I am sorry, you know.
Oh, hey there! You here to join the Dawnguard, too?
I'm, uh... my name is Agmaer, sir.
Yes, that's it. Dimhollow Crypt. Brother Adalvald was sure it held some long-lost vampire artifact of some kind.
We didn't listen to him any more than we did Isran. He was at the Hall when it was attacked...
Isran, Carcette is dead. The Hall of the Vigilants... everyone... they're all dead. You were right, we were wrong. Isn't that enough for you?
Feel free to poke around the fort and take what you need. There isn't much yet, but you're welcome to anything you can use.
Do I look like a "sir" to you, boy? I'm not a soldier, and you're not joining the army.
And now that you've stirred up the vampires against you, you come begging for my protection?
Yes, a crossbow. Best thing for killing vampires. Just take a few shots at those crates over there.
Tolan, tell him about, what was it, Dimhollow? Tolan, tell her about, what was it, Dimhollow?
I remember Keeper Carcette telling me repeatedly that Fort Dawnguard is a crumbling ruin, not worth the expense and manpower to repair.
New recruits? Hmm. Here to join the Dawnguard? Good.
Uh, crossbow? I've never...
I'm going to Dimhollow Crypt. Perhaps I can be of some small assistance to you.
And now you want to come running to safety with the Dawnguard, is that it?
Where is everybody? This place looks almost deserted.
You there, boy. Stop skulking in the shadows and step up here. What's your name?
Don't worry, I think we can make a Dawnguard out of you. Here, take this crossbow and let's see how you shoot.
I know what you think of us. You think we're soft, that we're cowards. You think our deaths proved our weakness.
Stendarr grant that you do not have to face the same test and be found wanting.
You know why I'm here. The Vigilants are under attack everywhere. The vampires are much more dangerous than we believed.
You've probably killed lots of vampires, huh? I'm sure Isran will sign you right up. Not sure he'll take me. I hope so.
"My pa's axe", Stendarr preserve us.
You Vigilants were never trained for...
That must be it. Fort Dawnguard... Wow. Bigger than I expected.
Uh, my weapon? I mostly just use my pa's axe, when wolves are attacking the goats or something.
Tolan, I don't think that's a good idea.
Why are you here, Tolan? The Vigilants and I were finished with each other a long time ago.
Hey, uh, don't tell Isran I was afraid to meet him by myself. Not the best first impression for a new vampire hunter, I guess.
Didn't I tell you to step forward? Hmm... Farm boy, eh? What's your weapon?
I'll meet you at Dimhollow. It's the least I can do to avenge my fallen comrades.
Isran will decide if you've got what it takes. Go on, he's right inside.
Truth is, I'm a little nervous. I've never done anything like this before. I hope you don't mind if I walk up with you.
I guess this is it. Wish me luck.
Here, you should take a crossbow. Good for taking out those fiends before they get close.
That's it. Watch the recoil. Takes some getting used to. You'll get the hang of it. Take a deep breath and let it out as you fire. You need to concentrate, boy. Try it again.
You are prey, like all mortals. I banish you!
The scroll!
After all these years, that's the first thing you ask me? Yes, I have the scroll.
She has the scroll!
My long-lost daughter returns at last. I trust you have my Elder Scroll?
I guess I'm expected.
I can't believe it.
This is my savior, the one who freed me.
Now tell me, who is this stranger you have brought into our hall?
A savior?
Of course I'm delighted to see you, my daughter. Must I really say the words aloud?
Ah, if only your traitor mother were here, I would let her watch this reunion before putting her head on a spike.
I don't like the feel of this place. I'll wait for you back by the entrance.
Well? I'm waiting. I'm not known for my patience. I need to speak to you, stranger. Now. You are testing my patience. It's only for Serana's sake that I have let you live.
All right, now pull your lever!
Hang on... could you pull that again?
It looks like there's another lever over on the other side.
Stay here. I'll go check it out if you open the door back up.
My lord! Everyone! Serana has returned!
Wait... Serana? Is that truly you? I cannot believe my eyes!
How dare you trespass here!
I don't want to either, but you're going to have to jump. I'll be... right behind you. Above you. Just go.
Is that... oh no. Are we going down there?
Is that what passes for security with your lot? I can't say that I'm feeling any more confident.
Ah, it's so good to breathe again!
Umm... this is the part where we usually get in the boat. You with me?
Is... everything all right here?
That's it, out there to the north. We used to keep a boat around here to get there and back.
This feels like the right way. I was starting to worry.
So this is where your Vigilants came from? No wonder you look so lost all the time.
So I'm thinking that wasn't the right way. All right, so obviously not this way, either.
Well, we're definitely not going to find our way out from here.
Do you... know what you're doing?
Even in this weather, it's better than the cave. This weather is incredible.
Yes… master…
Yes, I can feel your defenses crumbling. You want it to end. You want to give in to me.
Now, acknowledge me as your master!
Must... resist...
Your mind was strong, but you're exhausted from the struggle.
How much longer can you keep this up, Moth Priest?
I will resist you, monster. I must!
The more you fight me, the more you will suffer, mortal.
Thank you for breaking that foul vampire's hold over me.
That... that wasn't me you were fighting.
I could see through my eyes, but I could not control my actions.
Wait, stop! I yield!
Come on, old man. You should get some rest.
I must rest now. The reading has made me weary.
Do you know where he's staying now?
Some Imperial scholar arrived in Skyrim a few days ago. I was staking out the road when I saw him pass by. Maybe that's your Moth Priest.
Thank you for your kindness. I'll remember it the next time I'm feeling hungry.
In the meantime, don't make me regret my sudden outburst of tolerance and generosity, because if you do, your friend here is going to pay for it.
You hear me? Don't feel like a guest, because you're not. You're a resource. You're an asset.
You want to find him, try talking to anyone who'd meet a traveler. Innkeepers and carriage drivers in the big cities maybe. But you're on your own.
No, and I'm not going to waste men looking. We're fighting a war against your kind, and I intend to win it.
So let's hear it.
This vampire showed up while you were away.
I'm guessing it's the one you found in Dimhollow Crypt. Says it's got something really important to say to you.
"The Winking Skeever." Charming name.
Those vampires put up a hell of a fight.
I'm working on it, now give me some silence so I can think.
How do we do that?
I don't know, maybe. Won't know until we get him out of there.
You think they turned him?
I just hope we weren't too late.
I'm not sure what they did to this Moth Priest, but he doesn't look right.
Look to the cities. Speak to innkeepers, carriage drivers, anyone who would meet a traveler.
I have spread false rumors about the discovery of an Elder Scroll in Skyrim to lure a Moth Priest here.
Now that I have reclaimed one of my Elder Scrolls, we must find a Moth Priest to read it.
The prophesied time is at last upon us. Soon we will claim dominion over the sun itself, and forge a new realm of eternal darkness.
Now it is time to see if those efforts have borne fruit. Go forth, and search the land for rumors of a Moth Priest within our borders.
Go now, and carry out this task. This is my command!
Scions of the night! Hear my words!
Hm. Most interesting.
It will be done, my lord!
A Moth Priest?
I knew she was deep into necromancy. I mean, she taught me everything I know.
But I had no idea she had a setup like this.
Look at this place. This has to be it!
I'm not sure about this circle, but it's obviously... something.
And what's this thing?
Look at all this. She must have spent years collecting these components.
She actually did it... created a portal to the Soul Cairn. Incredible.
By the blood of my ancestors...
Everything's been torn down... the whole place looks... well, dead. It's like we're the first to set foot here in centuries.
We've made it to the courtyard.
Oh no...
Well, at least we're getting closer. Let's go.
I've never been in those tunnels before, but I'd bet they run right under the courtyard and into the tower ruins.
I used to walk through here after evening meals. It was beautiful, once.
Very clever, mother. Very clever.
Wait...
I didn't even know the crests could be removed. Maybe my mother's trying to tell us something?
Something's wrong with the moondial here. Some of the crests are missing and the dial is askew.
This was my mother's garden. It... do you know how beautiful something can be when it's tended by a master for hundreds of years?
She would have hated to see it like this.
This used to lead into the castle's great hall. It looks like my father had it sealed up.
What happened to this place?
Castle looks so big from down here. I mean, it is big, but, well, even bigger. I used to hide down here and look out at the sea. Usually when my father was in a bad mood.
Yeah, just around this bend.
This leads out to the courtyard. Just head for the door.
Take a left up here. This is one of those weird double-barred security measures that my father put in when he got more paranoid.
If we follow that path around, we can find the other switch.
I've never even seen this part of the castle before. Be careful. I don't know what might be around.
The old water cistern. On some days, this would smell just... be glad you weren't here then.
He doesn't know we're here. I don't have time to explain.
Serana? What are you doing here? Where's your father?
Mother!
Is it really you? I can't believe it!
How do we get inside? We have to talk.
You. Come forward. I would speak with you.
No, you don't...
Wait a moment... you've brought a stranger here? Have you lost your mind?
No, you've got it all wrong. We're here to stop him... to make everything right. No, you've got it all wrong. We're here to complete the prophecy our way, not his.
I must have failed. Harkon's found a way to decipher the prophecy, hasn't he.
How dare you! I gave up everything I cared about to protect you from that fanatic you call a father!

This "stranger" has done more for me in the brief time I've known him than you've done in centuries! This "stranger" has done more for me in the brief time I've known her than you've done in centuries!

This stranger aligns himself with those that would hunt you down and slay you like an animal, yet I should entrust you to him? This stranger may call himself vampire, but he knows nothing of our struggle. Why should I entrust you to him? This stranger aligns herself with those that would hunt you down and slay you like an animal, yet I should entrust you to her? This stranger may call herself vampire, but she knows nothing of our struggle. Why should I entrust you to her?
Oh, Serana. If you'd only open your eyes.
The moment your father discovers your role in the prophecy, that he needs your blood, you'd be in terrible danger.
Both of you were obsessed with your own paths. Your motivations might have been different, but in the end, I'm still just a pawn to you, too.
So to protect me you decided to shut me away from everything I cared about?
You never asked me if hiding me in that tomb was the best course of action, you just expected me to follow you blindly.
Yes, he's a fanatic... he's changed. But he's still my father. Why can't you understand how that makes me feel?
All I wanted is for us to be a family again... for things to return to the way they were before.
I had no idea you felt that way about me, Serana. It was never my intention to push you aside.
I've allowed my hatred of your father to estrange us for too long. Forgive me.
I'm sorry, Serana. I didn't know... I didn't see.
If you want the Elder Scroll, it's yours.
Maybe we don't deserve that kind of happiness. Maybe it isn't for us.
I want us to be a family again. But I don't know if we can ever have that.
But we have to stop him. Before he goes too far. And to do that, we need the Elder Scroll.
Wait... I hear something!
It's Durnehviir... he's here! Defend yourselves!
Maker... it can't be. Serana?!
Mother?
I wonder what these souls do all day. They look... bored.
Be careful with those crystals. They feel... hungry. Another one of those things. Let's keep our distance.
Ugh. The smell here... let's try to handle this quickly.
I wonder if the horse's remains are around here... someplace.
Woah!
I think that might have been what we were waiting for.
Let's head back up there and see if we can read the scrolls.
Look at this place. No one's been here in centuries.
I doubt there's any other place like it in Skyrim. It's beautiful.
Wow.
Well, we got the knife... now all we need to do is track down one of those Canticle Trees.
Hope the moths like that bark as much as Dexion said they would.
Look at them... they've definitely taken a liking to you.
And unless I'm seeing things, you're starting to... glimmer.
If this ends up being a wasted trip, your friend Dexion and I are going to have some words when we get back.
Hmph... not very impressive, is it?
So, let's get this straight.
We need to do all that nonsense to get into the temple, so we can kill your brother and claim Auriel's Bow?
This structure is known as a wayshrine. They were used for meditation and for transport when the Chantry was a place of enlightenment.
I know how it all sounds, but if there was another way I'd have done it long ago.
Well, once the Initiate's enlightenment was complete, he'd bring the ewer to the Chantry's Inner Sanctum.
Pouring the contents of the ewer into the sacred basin of the Sanctum would allow him to enter for an audience with the Arch-Curate himself.
Once the Initiate completed his mantras, he'd dip a ceremonial ewer in the basin at the wayshrine's center and proceed to the next wayshrine.
Prelates of these shrines were charged with teaching the mantras of Auri-El to our Initiates.
All I needed was the blood of a vampire and his own weapon, Auriel's Bow.
Auri-El himself may have been beyond my reach, but his influence on our world wasn't.
You want to take revenge... on a god?
Enough, Vyrthur. Give us the bow!
I swore I'd have my revenge, no matter what the cost.
The moment I was infected by one of my own Initiates, Auri-El turned his back on me.
You're... you're a vampire?
But Auriel should have protected you...
Gelebor and his kind are easily manipulated fools.
Look into my eyes, Serana. You tell me what I am.
You were waiting... all this time for someone with my blood to come along.
Well, too bad for you... I intend on keeping it. Let's see if your blood has any power to it!
Until the "Betrayed" corrupted you. Yes, yes. We've heard this sad story.
A prophecy that lacked a single, final ingredient... the blood of a pure vampire. The blood of a Daughter of Coldharbour.
How dare you. I was the Arch-Curate of Auri-El, girl. I had the ears of a god!
The blood of a vampire... Auriel's Bow...
It... it was you? You created that prophecy?
Come forward. You have nothing to fear here.
So, this is snow elf magic. Incredible.
It's symbolic. I don't expect you to understand.
All that just to end up dumping it out? Makes no sense to me.
So these Initiates had to lug around a heavy pitcher of water. Marvelous.
How long would they have to do that?
What's that basin in the center signify?
He's up there, on the balcony. Come on!
And I thought the Soul Cairn was creepy.
I wonder how long they've been like this.
These Falmer are... they're frozen in the ice.
Come on, the bow has to be in this valley somewhere.
Not the most solid construction here. About what I'd expect from... creatures like this.
The bow has to be in here.
This is a statue of Auriel, but it's using the older signs of his power. This temple must be ancient.
A strange race, these Falmer.
Looks like they're better at making traps than they are at making bridges.
That... has to be the place. I've never seen a building like that before.
It looks like some kind of temple.
Does this ice feel a little... thin to you?
Ugh. I told you!
Next time I say to please not go over the waterfall, maybe you'll listen to me.
Careful, here. If you fall down that thing I'm going to have to drag you out of... wherever it leads.
More spiders? I liked the ones back home better.

I think that's another wayshrine up there. Here we go. Is that another one of those wayshrines up there? I wonder where this one goes... These things are everywhere, aren't they? If we open that one, we'll be able to move around this valley a lot faster.
This is incredible. It's like a whole other world.
Poor thing. I know it would have tried to kill us, but still...
Hmmm. Pull chains and traps. Be careful here. Whatever's on the other side of this, the Falmer wanted to keep there.
Looks like these Falmer are here to stay.
They must be who that priest was calling "the Betrayed."
That... wasn't as unpleasant as I thought it would be.
Kind of soothing, actually. I feel a little warmer, now.
What's that? I can feel some kind of power from it...
I wonder what happened to them.
These people were... why would anyone want to set up camp here?
Burn them all!
Kill the abominations!
Give him a crossbow bolt between the eyes for me!
Praise Arkay!
Send them to Oblivion!
This is it!
Everyone! Gather 'round!
Victory to the Dawnguard!
Provided for me? Are you insane?
You've destroyed our family. You've killed other vampires. All over some prophecy that we barely understand.
And you...
No more. I'm done with you.
The prophecy is no more!
So, I see this dragon has fangs.
Your voice drips with the venom of your mother's influence. How alike you've become.
Send the troll after them!
No...
Because unlike her, I'm not afraid of you. Not anymore.
Come on then, we haven't got all day!
Serana, my darling. I see you still favor keeping a pet. So, you've returned.
Is your... pet keeping you entertained?
This is the time of the Dawnguard!
This is our fight and this is our fate!
The time has come to finally put an end to Harkon and his unholy prophecy!
We will march on their lair and destroy those wretched abominations so they can no longer corrupt our world!
We now have Auriel's Bow. The gods themselves have favored us and we must answer with action!
For too long we've allowed these vampires to poison the night and kill our people! Now, we finally have the means to strike back!
You know why we're here.
Of course I do.

You disappoint me, Serana. You've taken everything I provided for you and thrown it all away for this... pathetic being. You disappoint me, Serana. You've taken everything I provided for you and thrown it all away for this... pathetic half-breed vampire.
You will not touch him. You will not touch her.
He was out of control, Garan. It had to be done.
I'm not happy about this. He... he was still my father. But I suppose my father really died a long time ago.
This was just the end of something else.
My lady, you have my deepest sympathies. I am sure this was not easy for you.
Lord Harkon, defeated. I never imagined I'd see the day.
I think perhaps... I think you did more than that. You have my thanks.
I did what needed to be done. Nothing more.
I think my father really died a long time ago. This was just... the end of something else.
I... I suppose this is difficult for you.
It's over. He's dead, and the prophecy dies with him.
Of course, my dear. All will be well now.
Lady Serana's back! Open the gate!

You have kept your side of the bargain, now let me fulfill mine. I can feel my strength returning each time I am set free from that prison! Ah! The free air of Vus at long last! I rejoice in my freedom, if only for a moment. The skies of Keizaal are mine again! You give me freedom from the enslavement of the Ideal Masters. Thank you.

Feel the last word of Soul Tearing within yourself: "Zol" - the unlife that results when a soul is imprisoned in dead flesh. Hear now the second word of Soul Tearing: "Vaaz"- meaning to tear your enemy's soul from its living vessel. As promised, I now teach you the first word of Soul Tearing: "Rii" - the essence of your enemy's life force.
That's it. That's the last scroll.
Come on, let's take it to Dexion.

Once I get it done, first I'll publish a regular edition, then the folio. I'll be rich! "Saviour of Morrowind." Hm, that's good but it sounds too narrow of scope... I wonder how many copies I'll sell? Hundreds? Thousands? I'll hire the finest bookbinder I can find. Now what was it I said to that prisoner? "Stand up, there you go. You were dreaming..." Yes, that was it.

Was it "Between the forces of good and evil."? No, no... that's not it... Did I start with my ride on the prison ship, or was it before that? "And without any regard for my safety, I fearless charged the enemy!" No, much too dramatic... I can't believe I lost those pages.

Hm. Did I call it "The Great Hunt" or was it just "The Hunt?" Bah, I can't remember! When I rewrite those pages... they'll see what they missed. Was it "Having the adoration of thousands..." No, wait. I could make it "the adoration of tens of thousands." Damn it. How could I be so foolish?
What're you up to, Garan?
The Chalice? Why?
And here we are.
Excuse us. I need to fetch the Bloodstone Chalice.
Well, then...  Best of luck to you.
Lord Harkon has never cared to use the Chalice, relying on his more than adequate powers until now.
This is an intriguing change.
Indeed. He's off to Redwater Den. Indeed. She's off to Redwater Den.
Really?
Our friend here has been ordered to fill the Chalice.
Lord Harkon's orders, Orthjolf. Calm yourself.
Yeah, too bad. Lord Harkon's new favorite, dead so soon after joining the family.
Vingalmo and Orthjolf are Harkon's primary advisors. I'm sure they're quite surprised to learn that you're taking the Chalice.
It's really too bad, you know. The little accident you had here, completely unexpected...
Well that's just fine. Orthjolf told me to finish off anyone who got in the way.
Idiot. You didn't really think I'd let you walk out of here either, did you? Vingalmo wants you both dead.
Wait, what? That's not what we agreed. We take it back together.
We're just lucky I was here to return the Chalice to Vingalmo, so he could make sure Harkon gets it back.
There is much to learn, but if you master the powers of the Vampire Lord, few enemies will be able to stand against you.
That is all I have to teach you. If you wish to be reminded of these lessons, you need only ask.
Over time, your powers will grow in strength and you will find new ways to use your gifts.
There is one last thing you must know. Slaying mortal men with your life drain grants you new night powers and blood magic.
I keep a stable of thralls in the castle should you need to feed like the baser vampires to stave off the sun.
Good. You are weaker while on the ground, because you cannot access the blood magic.
However, the night powers are still yours to command, and your claws are still formidable weapons.
The true power of the ancient blood is found in the form of the Vampire Lord.
Assume the mantle of the Vampire Lord, and we will continue.
Should you run out of magicka, you can descend to the ground and fight as the beasts do.
Do so now and we will continue.
In this form, you can drain the life from your foes with your right hand.
With your left hand, you can wield the power of blood magic to raise the dead.
You can also call upon the powers of night to turn into a swarm of bats and reappear some distance away.
Use the power of the ancient blood to transform into a Vampire Lord. Transform into the Vampire Lord, and I will teach you more.
Land on the ground, and I will have more to teach you. Cease your flight and we will move on to the next lesson.
Oh no! What have I done?
Are you alright? Come on, we can do this. I know we can.
Wait, is he talking about me?
Finish them!
An impressive display, but a wasted effort. You delay nothing but your own deaths!
No... I won't let you ruin centuries of preparations...
This has gone on long enough.
Death first!
Surrender and give us the bow!
Child, my life ended long before you were born!
Your life ends here, Vyrthur!
Watch out! He's pulling down the ceiling!
Which, I'm sorry to say, means your usefulness is at an end!
You've done exactly as I predicted and brought your fetching companion to me.
Did you really come here expecting to claim Auriel's Bow?
That's close enough, fool. Now you die!
You there! Traveler! Over here!
Good thing the boss heard that old farmer running his mouth off in the tavern about finding this place.
The water from the spring makes the skooma so much more potent, we'll have all the thralls we'll ever need.
That's the last of them. Poor sods can't resist after they get a taste of your dosed Skooma.
The boss said it's some sort of profaned spring. It looks like blood, but it's not the real thing.
So why don't you just drink the blood from the spring? I mean, that seems easier than running a skooma den...
Drinking it gives you strength, but it also gets you pretty messed up... That's why we thought of putting it in the skooma.

If you tire of the search, read your book again to return to your mortal life. For a time. The lure of Apocrypha will call you back. It is your fate. Perhaps you are a fool or a coward. If so, you are in peril. Read your book again and escape before Apocrypha claims you forever.
Sate your thirst for knowledge in the endless stacks of my library. Perhaps you will prove clever enough to uncover the secrets hidden here. If so, welcome.

I know you, champion. The Oghma Infinium was only the beginning. So, another seeker after knowledge enters my realm. As I told you when I gave you the Oghma Infinium, your free will is an illusion. Why else would you be here?
This is Apocrypha, where all knowledge is hoarded. I am Hermaeus Mora, Prince of Fate and Lord of Secrets. This is Apocrypha, where all knowledge is hoarded.
What are you doing? That book! Look out! What in the...
I do not think that is wise. Be careful. You should leave those books alone. Remember what happened to Storn. Do not let Herma-Mora tempt you further.

Not again. Are you sure this is a good idea? I wish you would stop doing that. You won't catch me doing that. I'm never going to get used to that. Ugh, not again. I can't believe you do that on purpose. That isn't right. That can't be good for you.
This should be interesting. That doesn't bother you? Hmm. Say hello to Hermaeus Mora for me. Ah, yes, the lure of the Black Book.
I'd rather be stuck out here than floating in there.
And now we're stuck out here listening to it all day and night.
I saw the Fadrin brothers bobbing around in there this morning, so that makes three.
How many is that today?
You can't have them! Stay away!
Who are you? Have you come to take them away?
Why did he have to call me insane? Their mine. The spiders are mine to control! Maybe I can find more of them. More spiders! No one can take them away. No one! I am their master!
At your service.
Ah, my favorite customer.
Now I just have to figure how to get this thing started...
If you say so. That old crackpot made the trials sound a lot harder than that.
Nonsense. A few Dwemer Spiders will pop out, we kill them, and the Treasure of Kagrumez will be ours!
Maybe we should come back with more men. We don't know how many of those things will come out.
I don't want to have my spirit outstripped by some wanderer. So let's get up there and kill us some Rieklings!
You seek my blessing for the leadership of Thirsk Hall?
So I just need to take hold of it...

No. Nor is there any among you fit to serve. For a band in the wilderness, it is better to have no leader than a poor one.  Go forth and seek your fortunes. Inhabit the hall as you may. In time, a true leader worthy of the Thirsk name may arise. But I see that new leader's coming is yet far off the distant horizon.
There it is!
All I had to do was mention our little infestation, and he volunteered in a second! All I had to do was mention our little infestation, and she volunteered in a second!
Then... the leadership is not mine?
But look here. This outsider has more fire than any of you.
You allowed your fellow warriors to grow weak while the dangers around you mounted.
I know you're all starting to settle in here, and keep up the fat lives you got used to up in the hall.
No! I...
Hey, you lazy milk-drinkers, get over here!
And well it is that this has happened. But I have always watched, and know that it was your softness that lead to your own exile.
I do. It is I, Bujold. You blessed me in the past, and now I've rid the hall of Rieklings and returned it to its rightful owners.
Well, you'd better say something. And soon.
Your stomach isn't my problem. We'll act when I say we do and not before.
Then train them. What are we doing here? We should either get used to staying here, or be preparing to retake the hall.
You're having us do neither, and I can't stomach it.
I'm not going to lead them to their deaths if they aren't ready.
I never said it would be. But either way, we have to try. Whether we succeed or not, it'll stir up some of the old blood in this crowd.
It won't be that easy to get rid of the Rieklings, Kuvar.
Kuvar, I'm your wife. You can't...
Just... I can't even look at you right now.
Get out of here. Run to the wilds.
Kuvar, I...
Your words carry some wisdom. But if you truly believed in the spirit of Thirsk, you would have spoken them honestly.
Instead you hid your shame.
Kuvar, listen to me. You said yourself that this place had lost sight of its past. We need a new tradition, to move us forward.
Instead of listening to a ghost in a tomb, we should steer our own destinies.
So... you don't deny this?
My second would do well to keep his mouth shut. My second would do well to keep her mouth shut.
Bujold. Your second claims that Hrothmund did not yield a blessing to you. Is that true?
And so I feel your shame all the more deeply.
When it's time, we will seek you out. Until then, go and attempt to earn your honor in the old ways.
Hawah!
Felgir paw tuwani barj.
Goora! Goora! Goora!
Goora!
Karoo taray pelfrik?
Froo ha cawasy jo la.
Roo cha!
Just trust me, you don't want to drink it.
What did they... do to it?
Were you able to salvage any of the mead?
Most of the old brew is still good, but I had to get rid of some of the newer batches.
I can handle it. Just wish there was more mead, is all.
Not everyone was built for this kind of life. There's no shame in that.
It's rough out here. But I'm getting by.
How are you holding up?
Calm yourself, Hilund. There's plenty of time for that. Solstheim isn't going anywhere.
Are we off on the hunt again, soon?
Don't worry about Kuvar. Just be patient, and enjoy the between times, like this one.
But Kuvar's been saying...
Unless you're ready to go fight those things, just leave me.
You don't have to live like this now, though.
Don't you see, though? None of that matters. I'm going to go down as "the Unworthy" because of that rabble.
It's not your fault. There were too many of them. Nobody could have known...
Your worry helps nobody.
I just wanted to make sure you were all right.
What now?
Just... leave her be. She'll find her way.
Why so touchy on this?
And I don't think she needs any help from you to do that.
I'm not harassing her. She just needs to decide what kind of person she wants to be.
I don't want you harassing Hilund anymore.
That's between me and the spirits, Kuvar. You know that.
What exactly happened at the barrow?
I'm feeling motivated. That's enough for now.
Are you feeling any stronger?
That's what I'm trying to do...
I don't want your apologies. I want Thirsk to live up to its name.
I'm trying to apologize. Do you want to listen?
Do you know how tired I get of watching the softer ones here grow softer?
I'm sorry about before. You're not wrong, it's just...
Forget it. I'll make things better in my own way.
I don't want to get comfortable here. We need to be back up there.
Thirsk was respectable. And we let this happen. No, we'll get respect the way it should come.
This is a decent spot. We're right on the water. This could grow into something respectable.
I wish you could just relax a little...
Once the rest of you are done licking your wounds, of course.
That's not fair. We can still take it back.
Look around you, Kuvar. If any of us were strong, we wouldn't be on this beach.
I wish you'd stop acting like I've grown weak.
You don't have to apologize to me. Just pull yourself out of this and let's find a home. Either here or up there, it doesn't matter to me.
I'm sorry if I was hard on you before.
No, you won't. But I'll love you anyway.
We'll figure something out. And I'll get better, I promise.
Don't push, son.
You like it?
I'm sorry. The mead... it is good.
I know... I just... I wanted...
There are more important things than mead, Elmus.
Have you tried any of the mead I brought out of storage? It still tastes all right to me, but...
This is home, now, boy. Start living it.
I... I hadn't really thought of it. I'm still hoping we can go home.
We're not going to be lounging around in a hall anymore, so you'll have to be a little more useful. Can't make mead down here.
What do you mean?
So... what do you plan on doing?
No. But you need to come on the hunt more than we need you on the hunt.
I... uh, I hadn't planned on it. Do you need my help?
Are you going to join us on the next hunt?
Thanks to you. You've taught me a lot.
I'm proud of you, Hilund. You've held up well.
We are if I have anything to say about it.
Are we hunting soon?
There's more, yet. Don't get too comfortable.
Why are you so hard on Elmus?
Not everything is as happy as you do.
Not everything is as dire as you make it out to be.
Because he's not hard on himself.
This book... It seems wrong, somehow. Here, yet... not. It may be what we seek.
There are dark magics at work here. Ready yourself.
Send him back where he came from. Send her back where she came from.
And it is only a matter of time before Solstheim is also mine. I already control the minds of its people.
Who are you to dare set foot here?
Are you ready to help me now? We should not delay.
I cannot leave this unfinished. I must remain.
Where are you going? You would leave, now, when we have yet to find what is at the heart of this?
But I'm afraid this is not over. I shall return and take what is mine.
Well fought, Dragonborn.
We should check these rooms for supplies before going any further.
I grieve that you must meet your end this way, but necessity demands it.
This realm is beyond you. You have no power here.
What?
Ahh... You are Dragonborn. I can feel it. And yet...
You have no idea of the true power a Dragonborn can wield!
He can await my arrival with the rest of Tamriel. She can await my arrival with the rest of Tamriel.

You have done little beyond killing a few dragons. You have defeated dragons, yes, but still... You have slain a great many dragons, I see. And yet... So you have slain Alduin... Well done. I could have slain him myself, back when I walked the earth, but I chose a different path.
Soon they will finish building my temple, and I can return home.
The time comes soon when...
You must leave this place! It is not safe here! We must go back to the village!
Ysra, can you hear me? Ysra, I'm here to help you!
You must listen to me! We must leave this place!
Oslaf, please! You must fight against what is controlling you!
I feared that it would be so.
He has confirmed that Miraak is indeed behind the suffering of our people. She has confirmed that Miraak is the one behind the suffering of our people.
No, but I have brought someone who has seen things...
Frea! What news do you bring? Is there a way to free our people? Frea! I had worried I would not see you again.
Father! I have returned! There is yet hope!
Please, tell Storn what has happened.
It is good to see you again.
And there is the one who has freed us.
A strange thing, to lose control of oneself. We are lucky to be free.
I fear there is too much we do not yet know.
But how is that possible? After all this time...
The book is housed inside that dome. I'll need to unlock the door for us. Let's get on with it.
The Dwemer certainly knew how to build for the ages. These towers have outlasted their creators by millenia.
Or that the Dwemer's servitors continued to try to preserve the city after their creators' disappearance.
I sealed the door when I left to keep out ignorant meddlers. Let me unlock it.
Interesting. That would suggest that the city must have originally sunk during the first cataclysm of Red Mountain.
The Dwemer of Nchardak appear to have been fond of these control pedestals. Luckily I found a cube to operate it inside on my last visit.
It looks like most of the cubes were moved to the lower levels, perhaps to try to control the flooding before the city was abandoned.
Yes... here we are. This device shows the location of four more cubes in this section of the city.
But the pumps only operate when a cube is in the pedestal. And unfortunately, I only have one cube.
As you can see, most of the lower levels of the city are flooded. But it isn't hopeless - the old Dwemer pumps still seem to work. Watch.
So, if we can find four more cubes, we can turn these boilers back on and restore steam power to the room upstairs.
Then I should be able to open the book's protective case.
They're shut down, but they still respond to the control cubes.
These four boilers provide steam to the room upstairs.
The book is just inside.
Besides, it could be very dangerous. These books are known to drive many people insane.
At last. I hope it was worth it. Please... be my guest. You deserve the first look.
Yes, it worked! The steam is flowing. Now it should be as simple as...

What's the worst that could happen? Well, you could have your mind sucked dry by Hermaeus Mora... but that's supposed to be very rare. Please, go right ahead. I have plenty to occupy me for the moment. Aren't you going to read it? I thought that was the whole reason you dragged me out here. You should read it. I'd really like to see what happens. Don't worry, I'll take careful notes of what happens to you.
I'm going to head back upstairs and see if the reading room has steam. If so, it should be a simple matter to release the book.
That seems to have done it. Good. It took longer than I'd hoped, but at least it's finally done.
Oh good. Be sure to say hello to Hermaeus Mora for me, if you see him.
I have my doubts. But the city was a marvel of Dwemer engineering. Now... reduced to this.
In the old stories, when the Nords came to conquer it, it's said the Dwemer submerged the entire city beneath the sea until the invaders gave up.
Nchardak. The 'City of a Hundred Towers'. In its day, it was the largest of the great Dwemer Archives, and perhaps the most advanced.
Three of the cubes are through here. This seems like a sensible place to start.
In the city's days of glory, it was reputed to be able to assemble a complete automaton in a single day.
Much of the Dwemer army at the Battle of Red Mountain must have come from here.
These must be the "Great Workshops of Nchardak". Impressive even in ruins.
Wouldn't it be easier just to turn off the trap? Like so?
I hope the rest of the cubes are this easy to find. Although knowing the Dwemer, I rather doubt it.
You'll need a cube to unlock this door. I hope you remembered to pick up the cube I placed in the pedestal. You should be able to unseal this door with the control cube I gave you.
Let's see where this leads.
Ah, good! Another cube. We're finally making some progress.
Maybe through here.
With the water level this high, we can swim across the collapsed part of the passage and reach the other side.
Hmm, nothing down here.
Ah, good. Now we can see if we can find a way to get that next cube.

There's a passage up there. We could reach it if the water level was higher. You must have left a cube in one of the pump control pedestals. If you remove it, the pumps will stop and we'll be able to swim up there.
Unfortunately, each cube we retrieve shuts down the corresponding pumps, raising the water level. We'll have to be careful.
It looks like we'll need to lower the water level to make any more progress. I believe these pillars will activate the pumps for this room, assuming they still work.

Very good. By my count, we've found a total of four cubes. I have one that you forgot to pick up. I hope you didn't leave any others lying around. Very good. By my count, we've found a total of four cubes. Assuming you haven't dropped any anywhere.
I have an idea. I'll wait here and retrieve this cube once you find the last one we need. Good luck!
What a mess. I'm getting tired of wading around in this muck.
But how to reach it?
I'd guess that must be the pump activator up there.
You'll need to lower the water level before we can proceed any further. The last cube is somewhere through the northern door. We won't be able to open it until the water level is lower.
Watch out, the water's rising even higher with both pumps shut down.
Do you have the cube? Good, good! Then I'll take this cube and we can be on our way.
That was easier than I expected. I'm glad you were here to do all the hard work.
That's it! Don't touch anything else. Quickly now.
Well, that's progress of a sort. But we'll need all three down at once to get to the pump control. We'll need to get all three of these bridges down in order to reach the pump control.
Now we can finally see about getting those boilers started.

I have some cubes I'm sure you're going to need. You'll need the cube I picked up to start all the boilers. I'm quite sure the boilers will not work while they're under water. I thought you understood how this worked by now. The water level needs to be lower for the boilers to work at all. It should now be as simple as using the cubes to turn on the four boilers. As much as I enjoy this place, I'm ready to see if we can actually open the book's protective case. You do still remember why we're here? You need to start the four boilers. Then we should be able to open the book's protective case upstairs. Is there some problem?

With the cubes I retrieved, we should now have a total of five. I hope you haven't left more scattered about. With the cube I retrieved from the pumping pedestal, we should now have five cubes - exactly what we need.

Hmm. Still no steam. You didn't remove any of the cubes downstairs, did you? If you removed any cubes downstairs, you'd better go put them back. The boilers won't work if they're flooded, you know. All four boilers need to be working to open the casing. Are you sure you didn't remove a cube from one of the boilers?
The last time I was here, I only explored a small part of the ruins.
The last cube is somewhere in here. I hope it won't require more swimming around in this filth.
That should do it.
I was here alone then, and I find an assistant is absolutely essential for this kind of dirty, dangerous work.
Look out! Another Steam Centurion!
Follow me.
As you'll see, that's easier said than done. This way to the boilers.
No, we'll have to do this the hard way. If we can restore the steam supply to this room, I'm certain I can open it.
So tantalizingly close... But trust me, no magic will open that. I'd have had the book already if it could.
You can see the book right here.
Be careful.
Beware! Another of those creatures!
It is rather impressive.
Now we will see if he knows what he is talking about.
It would be madness to go through there.
Thanks for the warning.
Amazing to think that they built this so long ago, and it still survives.
Finally. We will not have to listen to his complaining.
The dwarves must have feared this book to lock it away like this.
I think you did it.
The Skaal have always avoided ruins such as these. Nothing of the All-Maker is to be found within.
You should leave slogging around in the muck to us youngsters.
That's correct. I'm glad to see someone else has been paying attention.
So, we only need one more of these... cubes?
Bring that cube. We'll need it.
Well that gives me a lot to think about. I need to get back to Tel Mithryn. I have some ideas about how to locate more of these Black Books...
Do not fear for me, my daughter. This is the destiny that the All-Maker has laid out for me.
Father! No, stop!
You will be either a worthy opponent or his successor, as the tides of fate decree.
In return, I keep my promise, as befits a Prince of Oblivion: I give you the Word of Power that you need to challenge Miraak.
Dragonborn, you have delivered me the gift I requested.
At last, the Skaal yield up their secrets to me.
Father! What have you done!
Here then is the knowledge you need, although you did not know you needed it.
Send the Skaal shaman to me. He holds the secrets that will be mine.
I know what you want: to use your power as Dragonborn to bend the world to your will.
But this is not enough. Miraak knows the final Word of Power. Without that, you cannot hope to surpass him.
The second Word of Power. Use it to bend the wills of mortals to your purpose.
I stand beside you, father, as always.
Do something!
I am ready for whatever the foul master of this book has in store for me.
Father, you must not do this. That book is... wrong. Evil. Against everything that you have taught me my whole life.
Go, then. Kill Miraak. Do not fail.
Go. My father sacrificed himself so that you could destroy Miraak and lift his master's shadow from the land.
I must, Frea. It is the only way to free Solstheim forever from Miraak's shadow.
You... liar... gah! ... I won't... not... for you...
There comes a time when everything must change. Nothing that lives remains the same forever.
Hail, thuri. Your thu'um has the mastery. Climb aboard and I will carry you to Miraak.
You will die. And with the power of your soul, I will return to Solstheim and be master of my own fate once again.
But now I will be free of him. My time in Apocrypha is over. You are here in your full power, and thus subject to my full power.
And so the First Dragonborn meets the Last Dragonborn at the summit of Apocrypha.
No doubt just as Hermaeus Mora intended. He is a fickle master, you know.
Did you think to escape me, Miraak? You can hide nothing from me here.
Beware. Miraak is strong. He knew you would come here.
No. Not yet. We should greet our guest first.
Sahrotaar, are you so easily swayed?
Miraak harbored fantasies of rebellion against me. Learn from his example. Serve me faithfully, and you will continue to be richly rewarded.
May she be rewarded for her service as I am! May he be rewarded for his service as I am!
No matter. I have found a new Dragonborn to serve me.
Sahrotaar, ziil los dii du! Kruziikrel, ziil los dii du! Relonikiv, ziil los dii du!
You cannot flee me, Dragonborn. I can call you back to my tower as often as I like. Your death will not be that painless.
Did you truly think to be rid of me so easily? Your Thu'um is weak, Dragonborn. You cannot hope to defeat me here.
One more thing, Dragonborn, if you will. One more thing, Skaal-friend, if you will.

Here in my temple. Here in my shrine. That you have forgotten. Here do you toil. That you might remember. Here you reclaim. What faithless minds have stolen. Far from yourself. I grow ever nearer to you. Your eyes once were blinded. Now through me do you see. Your hands once were idle. Now through them do I speak. And when the world shall listen. And when the world shall see. And when the world remembers. That world will cease to be.
Wake up. Wake up! Miraak has you, just like the others! Why did you touch the Stone? Come back! Wake up! You must fight him!
No! Do not touch the Stone while Miraak controls it!
Unless of course you'd like to contribute to my investigation. It could be very enlightening to observe you.
That seems inadvisable... oh well.
I would not advise touching the stone again. The effects of repeated contact could be...
Ah, so you appear able to resist the effect by exerting your will. Fascinating!

Fascinating. By touching the stone, you appear to have fallen under whatever influence is affecting the others. I wonder how long this effect will last. Perhaps it is permanent as with the others. That would be a shame. You were an interesting exception to the otherwise universal phenomenon. Can you hear me? Do you have any free will left, or are you completely under this outside influence like the others? Hmm. It appears that you were not as unusual after all.
Men, an invader has entered the fort! Prepare yourselves for an ambush!
Our defenses have been breached! I need reinforcements!
Fort Frostmoth will never fall! Long live the Empire!
Adril... I haven't seen a smile on your face like that in a long time.
Excuse me, Councilor Morvayn? I have some wonderful news.
And you... step forward.
Don't say that. It's not your fault, old friend.
They did it to gain our confidence, councilor. They had us all fooled.
I should have been more vigilant. I'm sorry.
Vendil? But he's done so much for Raven Rock... how could this be possible?
Vendil, Tilisu and Mirri Severin weren't who they appeared to be. I'm afraid they were here to avenge Vilur Ulen's death.
This visitor has single-handedly dealt with a threat that could have ended your life.
Your precious "contacts" have yet to conjure up a scrap of food or work for us, father.
Don't make me choose, father... I beg you!
He's twice your age and only wants to marry into our family to use my contacts at the East Empire Company. No, I won't allow it.
Father, Captain Veleth and I are in love. He means everything to me. Am I to simply ignore my own heart?
Dreyla! I told you I didn't want you seeing him anymore. Must I lock you into the house at night?
Had we only left a day earlier... she'd still be with us. It's my fault she's dead.
You don't need to say anything, father. I miss her too.
I never got a chance to thank you for everything you've done. Ever since your mother died...
It was her time, father. None of us have any control over that. You mustn't blame yourself.
Anything to report, Captain Veleth?
Apologies, Adril. In my experience it's usually the quietest before the storm.
Something troubling you? I'd think you'd welcome a little peace and quiet.
It's quiet for the moment.
Perhaps that's reassuring enough for you, but it's something that still keeps me awake at night.
I'm going to be fine, my love. Captain Veleth would never allow anything to happen to us.
It's nothing.
Is something amiss, Cindiri? I can sense your concern.
Adril, a word please.
You and I both know we can't spare anyone right now. I don't care if you still have friends at the East Empire Company or not.
They abandoned us long ago, so your contacts are meaningless here. That's it.
Why hasn't a Redoran Guard been posted at my shop like I've requested?
Fethis, I'm quite busy at the moment...
You must be using quite a bit of your raw materials repairing their weapons and armor. I'm sorry we can't compensate you.
Captain Veleth's mentioned how valuable you've become to the Redoran Guard. The Councilor and I appreciate your assistance.
I'm glad to lend a hand.
Not to worry, Adril. I'll recover my losses in due time.
Good news, Adril. The next shipment from Windhelm should include the building supplies you requested.
We'll finally be able to begin repairs on The Bulwark. Thank you.
I hesitate to ask for anything else. Your family's done so much for us already.
If there's anything else I can do, just let me know.
Fethis, all of us mourn your wife's passing. Just don't let it affect how you treat your daughter.
She has no idea what she's getting herself into. You may not always be there to take care of her.
What Dreyla chooses to do is her concern, not yours.
I want you to stay away from my daughter!
Is it because of your father? Or is it me?
I don't know if I can do this anymore, Modyn.
At some point, you're going to have to choose. No matter the outcome, I'll always respect your decision.
He's never been the same since my mother died. I don't think he ever wants me to feel the pain he suffers.
I promise you, I have nothing but good intentions towards everyone in this town.
I'm not talking about that. I have a knack for smelling trouble, and for some reason you reek of it.
Understandable considering the differences between us.
I don't know what your playing at, Glover... but something about you just doesn't add up.
If I had the resources at my disposal, I'd build you a wall myself.
Excuse me, captain. Do you have any plans for the west end of town? We feel awfully exposed over there.
Tell you what. I'll make sure we have a permanent foot patrol over there. It's the least I can do for you.
I understand. I know you're doing everything you can.
Next time you feel like having a conversation, talk to someone else.
Nothing... I... I was just making conversation.
What in the name of the Black Hands is that supposed to mean?!
Fethis! How's that pretty young daughter of yours doing?
Sure, but then where would you go?
I don't know. There are many who would've already expected us to leave this place.
So what do you think, Vendil? You think this town will survive?
A fair question, my friend... a fair question.
Nah. He... finds things people are looking for. Makes a good bit of coin doing it, too.
That's quite a distance from here. What's his trade? He a blacksmith as well?
Just a brother. Lives in Riften.
Have any kinfolk?
Skyrim. Born and raised.
So where do you hail from, Glover?
Don't worry, my love. I'll find a way.
I don't want you hunting them again. You almost got killed last time.
Damn. I'm still low on netch jelly. He might have to wait until next month until I can gather some more.
Gjalund said our customer in Windhelm wants more of that balm.
Haven't sold much.
It's going to be a long time before things ever get back to the way they were... if ever.
How's business today, Fethis?
Thanks, Milore. I appreciate that.
Have faith. Things will change for the better.
Well, if we keep having harvests like this, you'll never have to eat one again.
Well, we had to do something. I'd rather starve than eat another one of those horrid turnips.
They're incredible. I don't know how we ever got them to take in this soil, but I'm glad they did.
Are the ash yams growing like you expected this season?
Sorry, I... Never mind.
Fethis, they doesn't care about us. If they did, we wouldn't be standing ankle-deep in ash trying to sell a few meager trinkets to survive.
They just send you those promises to keep you off their backs... you must know this.
What's that supposed to mean?
Gods. Not this again.
Milore, I've finally gotten that letter back from the East Empire Company.
Faith's just going to have to wait, Elder. I'm sorry.
Our faith is being judged every day, captain. We can't ignore it.
Elder, we barely have enough men to keep the town safe as it is. I can't pull them off watch.
Captain Veleth, I haven't seen you or your men visiting the Temple.
I'll see what I can do...
That isn't my problem. I was clear when I loaned Garyn the money that I wanted it back by the first harvest.
You can't get blood from a stone, Mogrul. As it is, we can barely make ends meet.
Milore, you need to talk some sense into your husband.
Oh... Mogrul. Care for anything from my stand today?
If you want that beautiful wife of yours to stay that way, you'd better.
Look, I know why you're here. I'll get the coin, I promise.
Ash yams? Disgusting. I'd rather eat cheese that's been sitting in the sun for a week.
I said to put it on my account and that's the end of it. Understand?
About your account... it's been a few months...
Why don't you say that louder so the entire town can hear you, idiot.
Just give them to me and put it on my account.
Mogrul... I got those special poisons you asked for.
Hold a moment, Mogrul.
I've gotten a report that you've been harassing some of the townsfolk. Is this true?
Yes, sir, Captain Veleth, sir.
See that they stay that way, or else I'll send you back to Skyrim in a crate. You understand me?
Oh, come on. You know me, Captain Veleth. My hands are clean.
Well, here we are. This is Raven Rock. Can't say I'm all that glad to see it again. Well, here we are. Welcome to Raven Rock.
Good luck. Maybe you can figure out what's going on around here. Just... be careful here. Things aren't what they used to be.
Gjalund. I was starting to wonder what happened to you. Hail, Gjalund.
All right, Adril. Don't worry about rushing it. Just pay me when you can.
We, uh... we were delayed by bad weather. Well met, Adril.
After all these years, they're gouging us for every last drake we have.
Let me talk to Lleril. I'll see what we can do.
Look, the East Empire Company didn't give me a choice. They've raised their prices again, and there's nothing I can do about it.
Damn it, Gjalund. You know we don't have that much coin.
This load cost me double what we had agreed on. Nothing I can do about it.
But what?
Before you even ask... yes, I have the supplies you requested.
But...

Of course, here you are. You poor thing. Here you are. Oh fine, fine. Here you go. Here, have some food instead. Don't let me catch you spending it at the Netch. Ugh, get away from me. I'm sorry, I don't carry coin. Perhaps next time. Bralsa, I can barely feed myself... Ask my husband. I'm busy. Oh here, just take it.

Help me out, milord. I haven't eaten in days. Help me out, milady. I haven't eaten in days. Food, coin, anything you can spare? Please, I'm starving. Any help will do... I know things are tough, but at least you have a roof over your head. Please, help me. Is a single coin too much to ask for?
People laugh at things they don't believe. It helps them accept the unknown.
They've laughed at me, Aphia. They thought I was a crazy old fool. But I proved them wrong.
Well, I put up with you, don't I?
You're too kind to people, always giving them the benefit of the doubt. Don't know how you put up with it.
Then I'll simply have to fall in love with some other senile, grousing old fool.
And what will you do when I'm gone?
It doesn't matter, my husband. Let's simply cherish the time we have for now.
I'll have food ready soon. You need to eat.
You're too good to me, Aphia. I only wish I could remain with you longer.
We'll pull through, I promise. Councilor Morvayn would never let us down.
Things seem just as bleak here.
We tried to start a new life on the mainland, remember? It was too dangerous. Vvardenfell isn't ready.
Garyn, did we make the right decision coming here?
I don't know what we'd do without him. Send him my thanks.
Fortunately, none. Captain Veleth was able to drive them off almost single-handedly.
As if we didn't have enough to contend with already.
How many did we lose this time?
Councilor, I'm afraid there's been another ash spawn attack at The Bulwark.
Very well, cover the difference from my personal treasury.
No, Councilor. I'm afraid we're going to fall short once again.
Did you look over next month's expenses? Will we have enough?
It doesn't matter, Adril. I'm responsible for those people and I'll make whatever sacrifices are necessary to keep them alive.
Your coffers are running low, Councilor. At this rate, your treasury will be empty by next winter.
My primary concern is your safety, Councilor. I give you my word that no harm will befall you while I stand by your side.
I understand, Adril. I know you're both doing your best.
No, Councilor. He's spoken to everyone in town... twice. If House Hlaalu has a spy in Raven Rock, he's hidden beyond our means to find him.
Has Captain Veleth discovered anything yet?
Well of course, now that they're under House Redoran's protection, why would they want to go back to Mournhold?
I'm hearing that the Council will be staying in Blacklight permanently.
Any news from Vvardenfell, Councilor?
My thoughts exactly, my friend.
I'll speak with Garyn and see if we can't increase the crop production this season.
Sorry, Cindiri, I fear we'll be feasting on ash yams a bit more often this year.
I was concerned about our food stores. Gjalund can only carry so much on each journey, and I'm afraid we might run out.
Of course, Cindiri. What troubles you?
May I have a word with you, Councilor?
I'm sorry, my love. It's this island... it's never felt the same since we left Vvardenfell. It's as though a part of me is missing.
