The Redoran Council tasked me with keeping Lleril alive, which I've done without question for over a hundred years.
He's the closest thing I've had to a brother, and we all owe him our lives. Am I to suddenly turn my back?
How much longer do you intend to serve as his shield, Adril?
Every Dunmer left a piece of themselves behind when they departed our homeland. All we can do is make the most of what we have.
You're doing your job, Adril. No one can fault you for that.
I'm sorry. I shouldn't bark at you like that.
Geldis, I need to know if you've heard anything about House Hlaalu setting foot on the island.
I'm not holding back. If I knew something I wouldn't wait until you strolled in, I'd come find you.
How about I just settle for some mazte and we'll forget I mentioned it.
There's no reason to bourdon you with my troubles.
I'm afraid we're completely out of them at the moment.
Sounds like you've had a rough day.
How about a hundred Dunmer armed to the teeth?
Captain Veleth! Good to see you again. What can I get you?
Dreyla, I have a message for you.
I do! Thank you.
He said he'll meet you where you met for the first time. He said you'd know what it means.
Oh my goodness, I'm so sorry, Geldis! Please, tell me... what did he say?
It's not from your father. It's from Captain Veleth.
Tell my father if he wants to speak to me, he should do it in person.
She's not a little girl anymore, Fethis. When are you going to let her go?
Geldis, I want you to let me know if you see Dreyla with Captain Veleth. I don't trust him.
How about you keep serving the drinks, and I'll decide what's right for her!
Raven Rock doesn't offer much in the way of companionship. You should be happy for her.
He's twice her age and they barely know each other. You expect me to ignore them?
These hands were made for bending steel... not mending bonemold. But, it's certainly better than not working at all.
Aren't you pleased to keeping busy?
The usual. Piles of armor to repair for the Redoran Guard.
How's business, Glover?
I should have another batch of vegetables ready for you soon, Geldis.
It's a deal.
Tell you what. If you use them to make your kwama egg stew, you can have them for free.
How much do I owe you this time?
You're right, my friend. I just grow weary of the struggle.
My men have laid down their lives to keep Raven Rock safe. We've fought too hard to leave. We can't just let it all go.
I'm afraid not. If we don't do something soon, we may have to think about moving on.
It's not looking good, is it?
Sorry, boss.
Damn it. I wish you would have told me sooner.
We ran out of jazbay berries almost two weeks ago.
Drovas, I thought I told you I needed the jazbay crushed for my Emberbrand Wine. Where is it?
Yes, boss.
Well, then you'll just have to clean them twice a day. Whatever it takes.
Sorry, boss. The ash comes in faster than I can clean it up.
Drovas! I need you to clean the rooms again. I went through there, and there's ash everywhere.
Mogrul, I thought I told you I didn't want you hanging around here.
And I'm supposed to run my operation outside in a pile of ash? I don't think so.
I'm not asking you if I can stay, I'm telling you. Now that's the end of it.
Look, we've been over this. I paid you off, I don't owe you a thing.
Yeah, I heard you before. I just don't care. You won't kick me out of here, and we both know it.
I don't know what you're talking about. I'm here to do a job, and that's it.
What's wrong with you? Do you want to ruin everything?
Look, "dearest", what I do on my own time is my business. You stick to your business and we'll both be fine.
I've seen the way you look at her. Do you take me for a fool?
I don't know, look for someone else to hop into bed with perhaps!
What am I supposed to do until then?
If everything goes well, we won't have to stay here much longer. For now, we wait.
This town bores me. How much longer must we stay in this wretched place?
Have you taken leave of your senses? We could be exposed... ruined. Ten years of planning all for nothing!
She's jealous. Can't say that I blame her.
I'm worried. I think she knows.
It's your choice, "father". Anytime you want to end it, you just give the word.
Remember your lessons, Attendant.
"The road to true belief is strewn with the incredulity of those that failed the journey."
And the Reclamations, they did nothing? Why did they allow the Tribunal to gain our people's favor at all?
The Tribunal's destruction was wrought by their own hands. Their actions, or lack of action caused their downfall.
Elder, why have the Reclamations destroyed the Tribunal?
Of course I'm certain.
I wished to bless the tombs with the monthly invocation, but I couldn't get the door to open.
Locked? Are you certain, Elder?
Attendant, why has the door to the lower level been locked?
I'm certain it's only stuck, Elder. I'll speak to Glover Mallory and see if he can take a look at it.
Of course, Elder. Please forgive me.
We no longer use that name for them. They have reclaimed their identity and no longer represent the patronage of the false Tribunal.
You'd do well to remember that next time, Attendant.
Don't you mean the Anticipations?
I was. I wandered the wastes of Vvardenfell, carrying the message of the Reclamations from tribe to tribe.
You were one of the Ashlanders, Elder?
With all due respect, those "things" aren't the only problem we have right now.
Be patient, keep the door locked, and we'll get there when we can.
I appreciate your problems, Adril, but I can't be expected to run a temple with those... things running around in there.
I'm sorry, Elder. I'm doing the best I can.
I did indeed. When are you going to do something about our central Ancestral Tomb? I can't even go down there any longer. It's getting intolerable!
You wanted to speak to me, Elder?
Hmph. Very well. I'll just have to find someone else to assist us then.
Galdrus, it's time for your lesson.
Very well. I'm ready, Elder.
Very good, Galdrus. Your lessons are going well. You may carry on.
The destruction of our homeland, the exile of our people and the rebuilding of our civilization.
Who were the perpetrators of those falsehoods?
We rejoice as the New Temple rises. We rejoice because we embrace the Reclamations as our saviors.
There appears to be a switch of some kind here.
There you go! Now let's see what mysteries await us in the next room.
I wonder if this fire pit has anything to do with the riddle.
Here's another riddle. "Stay your course. To idle is to die." Well, at least it's straightforward.
Careful there!
Ah, that's the trick!
Mind your step. There seem to be some corpses strewn about on the floor here.
Alright, lets see what we have next.
And two, I'm not going anywhere near them.
Perhaps a different form of attack will yield better results.
"A sacrifice will bring you closer to that which you seek." I wonder what it means.
Ah, splendid! I had no doubt you'd make it across. Let's see what awaits us ahead.
One, the riddle is most likely referring to these flat square stones.
Well, see what you can figure out. I'm going to inspect these pillars further to see if I've missed something.
Now, I'm not sure if you can read the dragon language, but this seems to be a riddle of some sort.
Keep moving, and don't look down! Well...other than to see where you're going, of course.
Now, lets see if we can find the other half of that claw. Alright, now just unlock the other one.
Well, I'm pretty sure about two things.
They also have glowing stones of some kind at the top. They look vaguely similar to drawings I've seen of objects called Impact Stones.
I've had a look around and the only interesting thing I've found is this inscription here, and a switch below it.
If you can keep up with the platforms, you should be able to get across the chasm.
Ah! So, that's where that goes!
"Continue along the path, don't tread where you've been.." Interesting...
Three pillars surrounding a central one. Perhaps they are connected somehow?
By the nine! I've never seen anything like this. They appear to be platforms made entirely of magical force. Absolutely remarkable!
Splendid! The gates have opened!
I expect there's another riddle in here, along with a puzzle.
The inscription must be a reference to these pillars.
I'm sure everything will be fine.
And...
Well done! It looks like we can head in either direction. Since you seem to know what you're doing, why don't you lead the way?
"All men must die, often by their own means." Sounds rather grim, if you ask me.
I'll just stand over here while you flip that switch.
Only five more to go! Now let's just hope something good happens when you hit the last one.
You go ahead and see what you can figure out.  I'll look around and see if I can find anything of use.
Hm... three pillars. Other than that plaque, there doesn't seem to be anything else worthy of note. Let's see what the inscription says.
More of the dragon-tongue. The runes have faded a bit, but I believe I can translate the inscription. Let's find out what's written here.
It says that he was loyal, and his reward was an honorable death. Quite fascinating.
Hmm, here's another mention of the guardian. I can only assume that this is the guardian's tomb we are standing in now.
In fact, if I'm reading this correctly, it says that Miraak was a traitor. Most interesting.
The writing describes a guardian who defeated someone named Miraak.
Let's have a closer look at these runes. Look! Here's another wall with dragon language inscriptions on it!
These runes have faded a bit, but I believe I can translate the inscription.
Aha! Here's another of those dragon language inscriptions! I wonder what it says.
This writing refers to a guardian who inspired both men and dragons.
I wonder if the guardian was himself a man or a dragon?
Just let me study these runes for a moment...
Is it just me, or are these platforms moving a little faster?
Ah, yes, here's something. The first one has to do with a breeze, or maybe it's wind.
That looks like quite a drop! Is there something moving down there?
Perhaps there's enough undamaged text in these etchings to tell us the combination.
It seems these rings can be moved.
Hmm...looks like it needs some sort of key. Maybe those half claws you found would fit in here if you put them together?
There you go. I didn't doubt you for a second. Let's see what's up ahead.
There must be hundreds of years of history etched in these walls. Too bad they seem to be too damaged to read.
That's all I can make out from this etching. I'll check the rest and see if there's anything else. You keep trying out the combinations.
Ah, the Hall of Stories. These are found in many ancient Nord tombs.
And the third has something to do with fire. It also seems to mention scales.
I didn't think you were going to survive that fall, let alone those things that were down there.
The second one mentions the the night sky, and the moon.
I'm guessing this one will be even faster. Just remember to stay focused, and most importantly, run!
I'm glad these platforms appear once you finish them. I don't want to find out what's down in that water.
These platforms are definitely moving more quickly. Can you keep up with them?
There's probably an exit through one of these sarcophagi. Let's get moving.
It looks like a secret entrance opened up along the wall. You lead the way.
Remarkable, isn't it? This tomb has been hidden for... well, who knows how long. Many centuries, I would think.
There are some sealed doors up ahead. Perhaps you can figure out how to get them open.
It makes my heart heavy that you don't believe me, Fanari. Baldor could be in danger, and you will do nothing.
If you won't help me, then I'll ask the All-Maker to send someone else who can.
Something isn't right, Fanari. I feel it in my bones and I smell it in the air. Baldor wouldn't leave without telling someone.
Don't worry yourself over nothing, Deor. Do you want a head full of gray hairs before you've seen forty winters?
Deor, you must be calm. I'm sure there's a good reason Baldor left us.
Oh? And what is her name, this secret wife of yours?
Because I already have a wife, and I wouldn't want to make her jealous.
Why have you never taken a wife, Baldor?
Her name is forge. Now be silent before she hears you and becomes angry.
You speak the truth, Baldor. It makes my heart glad to see her keeping busy after Heifnir's death.
Very well, I'll ask Edla to trade for some coal.
True, but I think that Edla would be hurt if you didn't give her the chance to trade for it first.
You know how happy it makes her to play the village peddler
I could travel to Raven Rock and purchase some more.
We're nearly out of coal again.
Nikulas is restless. He's like an eagle, always seeking to fly somewhere new.
I do not think he has the patience to work the forge.
All-Maker willing, young Nikulas will take an interest. I would be happy to teach him.
It's tradition that the son of the smith take his father's place, but you have no son. Who will become smith of the Skaal after you?
Well, Deor and Yrsa are still young. In time, I'm sure that they will have many children.
Perhaps one of them will want to learn the ways of iron-shaping.
If they grow hungry enough, they will turn upon us.
The beasts are driven north in search of food.
The ashfall in the south kills the plants upon which the small creatures feed.
As the small creatures move north, the large ones that prey upon them must follow.
I have seen more wolves and bears among the trees since the last dark moon. Something is driving them north into our lands.
That is the way of things. We must be prepared.
At least the hunting will be easier with the beasts so close.
I'm in your debt, Wulf. That bow you gave me is twice as strong as the last one I had.
Then I will keep practicing my aim every day.
It's not just the bow, Deor. Your arm has grown strong and your eye sharp. You've spent many days practicing your aim.
The All-Maker favors those who work hard to hone their skills, as you have done.
It makes my heart heavy, to think of killing a beast when we have no need of its hide or its meat. That is not our way.
The bear might find food elsewhere. We will leave it alone.
We had better do something about it, then.
Yes, I know the one you saw. It watches us each night, always moving closer.
As the ashfall worsens, the land and water are poisoned. The animals have less to eat and become desperate.
There was a great brown bear on the slopes the other day. I could swear by the All-Maker that it was watching the village.
Very well, I'll take a look at it later.
One of our chairs is about to break. It will need to be mended with a new leg.
What for?
Make sure that you save some wood from the pile.
If I'd known that I was married to a fox who digs under beds to look for treats, then perhaps I would have.
That is sweet of you, Deor, but you should find a better hiding place next time.
What?! That was supposed to be a gift! I was hoping to surprise you.
Husband, do you know why there's a pouch of spiced tea leaves under the bed?
I wonder sometimes if you are truly happy here, Nikulas.
Very well, mother. I will stay for now.
My heart is still wounded from the loss of your father. I cannot lose my only son so soon after.
When time has worn away my grief, then you can go with my blessing.
I don't fear hardship and danger. I am Skaal. The only thing that I fear is not to follow my heart, and to die an old man filled with regret.
I know that Tharstan has filled your head with stories, but those stories don't tell of the dangers and hardships of the world.
I know why you're asking, mother. I am happy here, but I want to know more of the world outside our lands.
I don't need so many, but thank you, Tharstan. You are as sweet as honey from the comb.
My dear chieftain, I will bring you back a whole bouquet if you wish.
When you visit the ruins again, will you bring back some blue mountain flowers?
Hm? What do you need?
I have a favor to ask of you, Tharstan.
I'm not setting foot out that door unless it's absolutely necessary. If I do that, I'll be even colder than I am now!
Then take an axe and find a dead tree to cut. We keep only what we need in the village, you know that.
Just a few.
And you want to put more logs on the fire?
Is it just me, or is it colder than usual today? By the Nine, I feel as if my bones have turned to ice.
How much longer will you stay in the village, Tharstan?
I thank you, Morwen. It means very much to me to hear you say so.
I understand. Know that you are welcome here for as long as you wish to be.
It's hard to explain, but as much as I have come to think of Skaal Village as a second home, I do still miss Skyrim.
Then you should stay. What does the world beyond our lands have to offer that we do not?
To tell the truth, Morwen, I thought it would only be a year or two. However, I have come to be very fond of the village and of all of you.
Yes, papa.
I have given my answer, little cub. I know you are brave and have the heart of a great she-wolf, but all things have a time and place.
I just want to see. I promise not to get in the way of the hunters, and I'm not afraid of the beasts in the forest.
I've told you before, little cub, you're not old enough yet.
Papa, when can I go on my first hunt?
I'm sure the All-Maker has more important concerns than your potatoes, Oslaf.
Hm, perhaps I'll make an offering to the All-Maker. He can make our potatoes ripen as surely as he makes the snow fall from the sky.
Be patient, my husband. The crop doesn't grow faster because it hears your growling stomach.
Are the potatoes ready for eating? I want to roast them with some onions for the night's meal.
There's no time for that now, I have work to do.
Complaining to me won't make your pain go away, Oslaf. Go and see Edla, perhaps she has a remedy.
There's a terrible ache in my back today.
Then get back to it, you lazy horker! The day is wasting.
Not if I can help it!
Yes, I remember that you ate one of them all by yourself. Maybe this time, you will leave some for the rest of us!
Just make sure that when the berries ripen, you make more pies than you did last time.
The snowberries are not yet sweet enough. I tasted one just this morning.
When will you make another snowberry pie, Yrsa? It's been a long time.

It takes a strong will to command a dragon's soul. Perhaps you aren't as powerful as you think. Not this time, Dragonborn. This one's mine. This dragon's soul belongs to me. Do you ever wonder if it hurts? To have one's soul ripped out like that?
Thank you for your help. We will meet again soon. One step closer to my return. I grow ever stronger, Dragonborn.
So, Ildari does live after all.
She thought she could hide from me, but she can't!
I call upon the powers of the sun, moons and stars. Ildari Sarothril, reveal yourself!
She lives. Seek her in Highpoint Tower.
It's on your head if something goes wrong.
Just let me get back inside first.
The, uh... the lab is too small. Also, I need the ashy soil.
Master Neloth knows what I'm doing. Master Neloth told me to practice this spell while he's away.
No need to bother him about it though. He's quite busy at the moment. No need to tell him about it when he gets back. He knows all about this.
Master Neloth has tasked Elynea with repairing the tower.
Why aren't you doing this in the lab, where it would be safer for all of us?
If you must know, I'm trying to get this Ash Guardian spell to work.
Now let me concentrate.
Besides, shouldn't you be worrying about the damage to the tower?
Why are you out here? Aren't you supposed to be in the tower assisting Master Neloth? Why are you out here? Master Neloth is away. Aren't you supposed to stay in the tower?
No Ash Guardian. Maybe the book has something.
Nothing.
Why won't this summoning work?
Off you go. If you discover any side effects, come back and tell me straight away.
You won't feel a thing. But if you do, try not to scream too loudly. My ears are sensitive.
Master Neloth! What have you done to him? Master Neloth! What have you done to her?
What are those things growing out of his eyes? What are those things growing out of her eyes?
Well that's unexpected.
I presume you are blind, given the state of your eyes.
It's nothing that can't be fixed.
The spell that is. I think I can fix the spell. It should only take a couple more years.
But first, I need some data. Try wiggling them.
No, don't shake your fist. Wiggle the tentacle things where your eyes used to be.
Hmm. From the way they are waving about, I'm assuming they aren't under your control.
And I see now that your tongue is also...well, it's probably best if I don't say. Don't bother trying to scream though.
I...I think I'm going to pretend that never happened.
Is it over yet? Does he have eyes again? Is it over yet? Does she have eyes again?
It looks like it's beginning to wear off.
I think I'm going to be sick.

Climb on and we will smite our enemies. Bo nu. Quickly. How can I serve you, thuri? Hail, thuri. Shall we fly together? Zu'u fent aam. I am at your command. Your thu'um is stronger than Miraak's. Vobalaan in. I serve you now. Miraak has forced me to serve him for too long. Nahkriin saraan lingrah. Let us destroy him together.
I must leave you now. Ahmik oblaan. My service to you is over. I have served you for long enough. Tiidi do ahmik oblaan. Zu'u ni zaamiil. You cannot command me forever.
It's not your fault, Drovas. You do other things well.
Varona was never able to do the repair work that you do.
I can't help it if I have a black thumb. It's like the mushrooms hate me.
I miss Varona. She used to help me with the gardening.
Thank you. I didn't mean to be so defensive.
I know Varona was your friend. It's okay to miss her.
I suppose you're right. At least here I'm safe from Mogrul.
You complain too much.
Tel Mithryn is the safest place in Solstheim. Only a fool would challenge Master Neloth.
Do you ever get lonely out here in the middle of nowhere?
Ah! The wood is for the staffs. Put them away when you get a chance. But don't get in my way.
Mostly books. There were a couple of soul gems, some ingredients for Elynea, and some strange wood.
What did they bring? Books? Soul gems?
Master Neloth, the silt strider traders just dropped off some supplies.
Yes, yes. Canis root tea. And don't let Ulves water it down.
I'll go fetch some, Master Neloth. Canis root, right?
Drovas, where's my tea?
Master Neloth is the most powerful wizard of House Telvanni. Maybe the most powerful in all of Morrowind.
Someday I will inherit all of this. It's worth a little pain.
I don't understand why you let him do these things to you.
They're back to regular size. It didn't hurt nearly as much this time.
How are your ears, Talvas?
Unearthly screams?
What have I gotten myself into.
Master Neloth is preparing to... well, it's better if you don't know.
However, if you hear unearthly screams, I would advise you to not come up.
I know, I know.
So, unearthly screams, don't come up. Got it.
You better get used to this, Drovas. This isn't that unusual for Tel Mithryn.
Idiot! Those are hard to find. Next time don't fill it at all if you can't do it properly.
Yes, master. Although the grand soul gem only has a common soul in it.
Did you fill those soul gems like I asked you?
Yes, master. Thank you, master. I'll fix it right away.
That was before you ruined that staff. Fix the staff and I'll teach you the spell.
Master, you promised to teach me a new conjuration spell.
Yes, master.
Don't think your false flattery will work on me, Talvas. You're still going to give me that skin sample.
Thank you, master. It's all because of your brilliant teaching.
Your enchanting has improved despite your best efforts.
Good, good. As soon as I'm done here, I'll try it out.
I've prepared the staff maker like you asked.
We'll see. If the power levels aren't too high you may have it.
May I keep this one, master?
Bah! Patience is for the young. An old dunmer like me can't afford it.
Soon. Be patient. Ulves is still making his list. And of course Master Neloth keeps adding to his.
What with all the ash spawn on the road these days, I'm not leaving until the trip is worth it.
Are you going to Raven Rock soon? I need some thing.
I'm sick of all this ash. I know dunmer aren't supposed to mind the ash, but I hate it.
Maybe two hundred years ago they were.
Now they say those green lands are ash covered too.
So you've said a hundred times. But didn't you also tell me the Telvanni lands were green and lush?
It's a good thing you've always lived here on Solstheim.
Vvardenfell is covered in ash. Red Mountain makes sure of that.
That's what you said yesterday!
I really can't put this trip off for much longer.
Maybe some daedra heart. Elynea never seems to stock it.
Let me get you the rest of the list tomorrow. I'm just too busy to think about this right now.
I know that. What else?
Hmm? Oh. Raven Rock. Right.
I need soul gems...
Master Neloth, I'm preparing for a trip to Raven Rock to pick up supplies.
I have your list of soul gems, but nothing else.
You have some tea, but I'll get you a fresh cup.
Elynea is waiting for fresh taproot before she can regrow that chamber.
Varona, get me some canis root tea.
Oh, and remind Elynea that she needs to fix my tower.
That chamber has been withered for too long.
I already did, but it won't do any good. They haven't had any for months.
Taproot? That's all? Add it to the Raven Rock list.
And suffered twice as much.
Neloth is a master wizard of the House Telvanni.
I've already learned more than I would have in twice the time at the College of Winterhold.
I hope it's worth it.
The pain has subsided. Thank you for asking.
Hopefully the frost lessons are over.
How are your lessons coming, Talvas?
Master Neloth is going to be casting some rather loud spells in the next day or two.
You should warn the others.
Oh, and if the tower door suddenly gets icy cold, don't come in.
I don't want to see any of you get hurt.
Oh, could you get me an extra blanket. I think I might need it.
That man is going to kill himself one day, and take the rest of us with him.
Thanks for the warning.
Well you'll just have to wait. Last time I brought his meal up late he asked if I wanted to be a part of one of his experiments.
Well I can't wait forever. Master Neloth keeps asking if I have his soul gems yet.
I would have had it ready, but Master Neloth wanted his meal early.
Where is your list of things you need from Raven Rock?
I don't know how he drinks that stuff.
If you're here about the canis root tea, it's almost ready.
At least you don't have to taste every time to see if it's brewed right.
What?! Ooooohhhhhh Nooooooooooo!!!!!
It's working, I'm flying! I'm really flying! Hahahaha!

They said it couldn't be done. They said it. They said it. But they were wrong! There's nothing to worry about, nothing to worry about at all... The book in my dream showed me... To touch the sky like a dragon...
The secrets. They're in my head. I can't get them out. I can't get them out! They're stuck in there. In deep.
I can't believe it... Must go back and get it. Everyone dead! Everyone but me... All that treasure! Lost...
Is that so? Well, you'll never get that treasure now!
Boss said to bring you back or bring back your corpse.
I'm not chasing that map. It's a fool's errand. I'm done.  Leave me alone.
We've got work to do.
I told him "no" once already.
Boss says you're to come back with me. Come on. Let's go. Time to go.
We must be careful in these ruins. Traps can be anywhere, and there will likely be many.
Miraak was trying to take power here, and protect himself in the process.
We should check these rooms for supplies before heading further into the temple.
I shall look around. We can proceed when you are ready.
Impressive! Was it worth the effort?
The stairs are knocked out. I have no doubt you can find a way up. You never know, you may find something of value up there.
Look up there. I think I see something.
Take your time. I shall follow when you are ready.
I do not wish to imagine the kinds of things that happened in this chamber. Who were the poor souls trapped in these cages?
What tortures did they suffer at Miraak's hands? Was it in service to the dragons, or for his own purposes?
Impossible. There must be something more! Look around.
I will let you know if I find anything in the dining area.
Dead end?
I have no doubt that lever turns these blades off. I shall wait here for now.
It cannot be much farther now. I feel it in my bones.
How much deeper can this be? I had been told that Miraak's power was great, but to have built so large a temple...
You have a much better chance than I to make it through these traps.
I suspected there would be something down here. Do you know those spells already?
I am not going down there. It would be foolish to attempt it.
Interesting. This may be worth exploring.
I wonder if we will find some answers to what happened so long ago.
I do not know what it is Miraak learned that gave him reason to turn on his masters.
But his path seems to have been a cruel one.
Let us hope that is the last of these traps.
Thank you. Miraak took great pains to make it difficult to reach him, it seems.
I knew it! A secret passage in the dining area just opened up.
This must be it. Let us move quickly.
Something feels wrong. Brace yourself!
It is no wonder the dragons razed his temple to the ground. Seeing the remains hung up like trophies must have enraged them to no end.
I had heard Miraak had turned against the Dragon Cult, but to display the remains in such a manner as this...
It is eerily quiet. I do not suspect that will be the case the further we go. Be on your guard.
It looks like there is only one way to proceed.
I leave the honor of pulling that handle to you. I do not want to put my hand anywhere near the mouth of that statue.
I do not like this place. It almost looks as if these statues will come to life at any moment.
I do not recognize this statuary. We passed by a few of them earlier, but they are becoming more frequent as we get further in.
Nothing but ruined books.
I wonder if there is something here that tells the story of Miraak...
Don't tell me you believe that rot! Well, as soon as Jorn gets back, you'll see. You'll see.
We don't even know what's inside. And besides, there's... the curse.
See? I told you. Just where the map said it would be.
Well, at least if the other Nord returns, they'll take care of him.
Ha! Wait...
Did you hear that? Sounds like those Ash Spawn are back.
Who cares? Nords all look the same to me.
Do you think he's the one we left in the tunnel?
Ha ha ha! No more! What a fool.
Listen to this one! "My nights have been impossible to bear without you."
"I beg of you: Please depart that blasted isle and return to Solitude at once!"
Ahzidal! Awaken! Master, arise! It is time!
Ahzidal, arise!
You've gone far enough. Neloth is a fool to think he could send some low life to finish me off.
I'll admit, even I'm having a hard time disagreeing with you...
Hush, Veezara. You were very brave. Astrid may well be dead if not for you.
Achh... Thank you, dear. You are most kind. The jester's cut feels as bad as it looks, I'm afraid.
Bested by a fool. Who's the fool now, hmm?
She's right. I'll be forever in your debt, dearest brother. Now be quiet. Just... just rest.
Damn it, this never should have happened! We knew better. We knew better, and still we let our guards down. Agh!
Just try to relax, Veezara. Let the elixir do its work. You'll feel better, shortly.
But the Night Mother is mother to all! It is her voice we follow! Her will! Would you dare risk disobedience? And surely... punishment?
But make no mistake. I am the leader of this Sanctuary. My word is law. Are we clear on that point?
Understood... husband?
Oh, be quiet you great lumbering lapdog. The man has had a long journey. You can at least be civil.
Oh yes, mistress. You're the "boss." For now.
Oh, what a kind and wise wizard you are. Sure to earn our Lady's favor.
You and the Night Mother are of course welcome here, Cicero. And you will be afforded the respect deserving of your position as Keeper.
Oh yes, mistress. Perfectly! You're the boss.
Oh, yes yes yes! Thank you, thank you, thank you!
Mister Cicero, I for one am delighted you and the Night Mother have arrived. Your presence here signals a welcome return to tradition.
Keep talking, little man, and we'll see who gets "punished."
Hmph.
Don't forget the ranting and raving. About the Night Mother, how she was the true leader of the Dark Brotherhood, and Astrid was just a "pretender."
It's true, I'm afraid. Cicero was a little whirlwind, slashing this way and that. It would have been funny, if he weren't trying to murder us all.
Ha ha ha ha ha ha ha ha ha!
What about you, Festus? How did that last contract turn out?
I am not adorable, it was not funny, and he wasn't a merchant. He was a Khajiit monk, a master of the Whispering Fang style.
Ha ha ha ha! Again! Again! Do the part where he tries to buy you some candy.
Tried a new spell. Little something I've been working on in my spare time. Came "this" close to turning that priest inside out. Damned messy.
But now he's dead... and I have a new loincloth.
Oh ya, very good. Very good. My it is dark down here. Oh, but you are so beautiful. Such a lovely smile. Your teeth... your teeth! No! Aggghh!!
Oh yes, please, kind sir. My mama and papa left me all alone, and I'm so very hungry. I know a shortcut to the candy shop. Through this alley.
Oh, yes, please, old man. Regale us with your tales of wizardry...
Oh, a big doggy chasing a little kitty! How adorable!
And what of your latest, Arnbjorn. Something about a Khajiit? Merchant was it?
Okay, okay. Wait. Here we go. "Ooh, you are such a pretty little girl. Would the sweetie like a sweetie? Oh yes, how about some chocolate?"
Oh Babette, but you are so wicked.
Ah, the young and stupid. Always mocking the experienced and brilliant. My contract went very well, I'll have you know.
Ha ha ha ha ha ha ha!

Tell me, husband. Is it true what I've heard? So, is it true? Come now. What everyone else is saying. It can't possibly be true... Astrid, I've been hearing some, er... interesting things, from the others... about what you did when you left the Sanctuary last week... I heard about what happened... Tell me, brother. Are the stories true? Tell me, sister. Are the stories true? Your latest exploit certainly has the Sanctuary talking...

But really. A horker, some twine, three wood elves, and a hatchet? Points for creativity, if nothing else. It's the part with the severed head I find most impressive. My compliments. I'm just trying to imagine you hiding inside the body of a mammoth. Bloody brilliant idea. But to be outnumbered twenty to one... You infiltrated the position, eliminated the target, and made it look like an accident. Impressive. I'd say you earned your bonus on that one! To kill triplets, secretly, and then have the whole thing blamed on the mother. Remarkable. It was a suicide mission! Astrid said as much. Yet here you stand, hale and hearty.  By Sithis, you slew everyone! Well, except for that one you kept alive, to serve as witness. Does your wickedness, or your skill, know no bounds?

Ah, you must mean my little adventure on the ship... Oh, you mean in that manor house? During the thunderstorm? Heh. What can I say? It happened, just like you heard. You're referring to that blacksmith contract? You must be talking about the caravan job... Word certainly travels fast, doesn't it? The temple contract? Well, I certainly won't deny my involvement. He he he he he. The Redoran contract? Yes, you heard correctly. In and out of Vvardenfell in less than forty eight hours.

It's all thanks to a special technique I developed. I call it the "Razor-Winged Butterfly." I'd teach it to you... but then I'd have to kill you. Romantic, isn't? Like that time we first met. Remember that? Never seen so much blood. Ah, to be young again... Unscrupulous daring. It's why you fell in love with me, my dear. Bah! A child could have accomplished it. Such is the power of the arcane. If you only knew of the spells I didn't use. He he he he he. What? You think me too old, too feeble? There is more knowledge in me than in two of you pups put together. And knowledge... knowledge is my weapon. Once again, you have underestimated me. You see the man, brutish and hulking. But I am wolf as well. Deliberate. Cunning. When I am become wolf, I am treachery incarnate. And then, then... there is no one who can stand between the hunter and his prey. When I first received the blessing of the wolf, my creator gave me a valuable piece of advice. "Arnbjorn," he said. "Never lose!" And I never do.  He he. Don't forget that I am Shadowscale. I was, quite literally, born to kill. It was a simple matter, really, when one has mastered the art of camouflage. Scale becomes stone, becomes shadow. Then... death. My greatest challenge was deciding which weapon to use, for I am prone to indecision. Bow, dagger... axe? In the end, I opted for my claws. In truth? It was so easy, I feel a bit guilty. Once again, the sweet, innocent child earned more trust than was wise. You give me too much credit. For how could I fail? I am, after all, just a little girl. What threat could I possibly pose? He he he he he. I am the perfect weapon. My innocent, childish form grants me nearly unrestricted access. Poison or a good bite usually takes care of the rest. I am but a humble instrument of Sithis. Our Dread Father guides me. Therefore, failure is an impossibility. In the end, I relied on a woman's natural weapons - beauty and seduction. The rest was a formality. Though, a rather wet, messy formality... When one can divine the future, success may not be assured... but it can at least be anticipated. It helps that I've already foretold my own death. Yeah, well, don't expect many more stories like that in my future. I'm getting old. Being that amazing takes too much damn effort. Hmph. Been awhile since I've actually cleaved someone in two. Forgot how hard it was to get the scimitar back out. Let that be a lesson to you young pups. There is no challenge that magic cannot overcome. Come now, dear husband. You above all people should know what I'm capable of. Sometimes I just need to remind everyone why I'm the one in charge. I guess I got tired of handing out contracts to everyone else, while I stayed home playing den mother. It was good to get out, and have some fun. I'd be lying if I said I didn't enjoy myself. But more importantly, I made this Sanctuary some much needed gold. In the end, that's all that matters. Well, I just did what had to be done. Nothing more. Nothing less. I'm just glad I lived to tell the tale. Ah, contracts like that are few and far between, it seems. Makes me long for the old days...
The man doing your job?
Oh, I've heard this one before. Watch out Divines, poor Kodrir curses you all for giving him life!
Watch your mouth with me you pup! Who do you think you are?
I swear that woman Aeri doesn't appreciate all the work I do for her damn mill.
Whatever happened to Ennodius? He just up and left.
You're all heart, Kodrir. I bet Lady Mara is weeping a special tear for you right now.
Don't know why you're asking me. But I'm glad that damn Imperial is gone. Something wrong about him.
Come on, we just need a little elbow grease.
I don't think we're going to get those potatoes to come in.
Well of course, not with an attitude like that!
The ground is practically frozen. We can't dig down far enough.
Oh dear, I hadn't thought of that.
Now, I've been reading about the best ways to grow corn in permafrost...
I keep telling you, without a warming enchantment, it will never grow past your ankles.
Right, but if you plow the soil with fire salts...
Then you've salted it and nothing will grow at all. Genius.
There are places in the world that aren't wrapped in ice, you know.
I'll bet this is better than trying to grow something in Morrowind, though, isn't it?
Firstly, I've never even seen Morrowind. Secondly, in volcanic soil the plants practically grow themselves.
Oh, my, I hadn't thought of that.
The Blackblood girl? Now there was a fighter. If I didn't know better, I'd say she was a Forsworn woman.
Hey, remember that girl, Eisa? The one who sliced open that pickpocket they threw in here?
Think the guards will be coming down, soon?
Ah, it's not been more than a few days since they came down the last time.
Some day, brother. Some day.
Nearly broke my back out in the mines today. Damn Nords should bleed for putting us through this!
They keep the doors locked when they come down. You kill them, you're trapping us here with no food.
Think maybe we should jump the guards when they come down next?
You make one move towards my skooma, and I shiv you.
Have any skooma? I need to get something from Grisvar.
But strength doesn't hurt.
How do you manage to hold your ground like that?
You have to remember, it's not about strength. It's about leverage.
Well, no. I'm just saying there's more to defense than muscle.
I've heard some rumors... about you and Skjor.
Is it not allowed?
And if you want to keep having ears, you'll pretend you didn't.
It's not exactly forbidden, but even so... it's not true. So that's that.
It's called a shortsword, oaf. It's quicker. Sharper. Like a razorfish against a whale.
But whales eat razorfish.
You only use the little swords.
And they always come to regret it.
Tiny blades don't hurt enough. A sword needs weight.
But ten little cuts...
All I need is one to cut you in half.
Well, when you put it that way...
You might do well to learn a smaller weapon. Vary your style a bit.
Enough with the training. I want to go fight something.
No fighting just yet. Not till Skjor says so. We train now.
Easy for you to say. You get to fight.
But before I fought, I had to train.
You'll do all right some day. Today you need to keep training, though.
Relax, new blood.
I've been hunting on my own for years.
Some of them, anyway.
Fighting people is different. Smarter.
That's why it's best to not mistake foolhardiness for bravery.
I worry that you've been spending too many nights out.
Where I go is my business. If you have a concern about my honor, bring it before the Circle.
You forget yourself, young one.
I'm sorry. I didn't mean to snap. Just... these hunters. We're all on edge.
You wanted to see me?
How goes the hunt?
Skjor's heard rumors of a bear the size of a mammoth in Hammerfell. We're going to seek it out.
What glorious prey. Come back alive, and with stories to tell!
Always.
I hope so.
How are the young ones coming along?
Just have them focus on the calm in the battle. Control the rage, don't let it control you.
Some are too happy to fight. Blood runs hot.
I remember when you were the same way. The more they train, the more they'll cool down.
Brave hearts beat lesser ones. That's the decider.
What weapon do you like, Harbinger?
When I was young, I favored huge swords, much like you. Hard to lift these days, but I still enjoy the heft of a good hammer.
Big swords should always beat little swords.
Well which is it? Look farther or closer?
Come on now, boy, you know what I meant...
Tradition is very important to me, son.
You speak in riddles sometimes.
To me as well. I think we don't see the same tradition at play here.
If you want to lead this pack when I'm gone, you have to see farther. Look closer.
Don't worry about me.
It's not confusing... just frustrating.
You're a strong warrior, Skjor. Your heart is fiery and that serves you well in battle.
Thank you, Harbinger.
I don't mean to confuse you.
But even the bravest of men consider their actions. I want you to survive long enough to take the mantle.
Skjor has been a warrior for a long time. You would be wise to listen to him.
Any warrior that gets to be old is either fearsome or a coward. I'll let you find out which Skjor is.
My title is Harbinger, child. I am no man's master.
Forgive me. You're just the one in charge, and it's what I'm used to.
No one is in charge here. Each Shield-Brother is his own man, each Shield-Sister her own woman.
Master, I...
Well why do I have to listen to Skjor, then?
But aren't the Circle in charge? And don't you lead them?
Do you think I could be a member of the Circle? Some day? If I work hard?
I guide the Companions. The Circle advises me. But we are all free warriors. Only our honor binds us together.
Don't worry about such things. Just focus on your own honor. Bring glory to the Companions, and that glory will return upon you.
I just want to make sure I'm moving up.
This isn't the military, son. There are no ranks.
Well you can either get better with a bow or try to learn from me.
Why can't I train with Aela?
Because you wanted to learn the longer blades. Aela's never used anything bigger than a dagger.
It's just... I think our fighting styles are similar.
Exactly. When you have a big heavy weight swinging around your upper body, your lower body has to compensate or you'll fall right over.
Should I be holding the blade further away than I would a smaller one?
If you keep it in close, you'll have more control, but it can be harder to balance a strike.
I guess that comes down to footwork, then.
It just feels so slow.
I've never held a knitting needle.
It will feel that way for a while. But eventually you'll get used to it, and then you'll get faster with it.
After that, the shortsword will feel like a knitting needle when you pick it up again.
Of course not. My mistake.
Are you prepared for tonight's hunt?
I've been thinking we need to be more... discreet.
There's nothing wrong with what we're doing.
You know the old man doesn't like it.
Let's just not be too obvious.
That they might get themselves killed.
Worried one of them is going to take your place?
By you?
Some of them might try. But that's not what I'm worried about.
They should be so lucky.
What then?
All these younglings scampering around.
Just those same ruffians I was bringing in for the Shatter-Shields.
So much wasted breath in that crew.
I'm imagining you just standing your ground and letting them tire themselves out.
I'm telling you, it works. Let them ring their own ears on my shield, then scoop them up off the ground.
We all have different means to glory, Stonearm. Well done.
Heard you had a bit of trouble near Solitude last week.
I'm a warrior, not a blacksmith.
Can't you just tell me if the grip is bad?
If Eorlund made it, it's more likely you're gripping it wrong. Find me tomorrow and we can go over it.
I've got a bad grip on my shield, could you take a look at it?
They're lording it over us all the time, though.
Young warriors are smart to listen to older ones. They've lived.
One day when you and I are on the Circle, we can change how things are run around here.
I don't think that's how the Circle works.
Aren't they slow? I can get in and out before you have one swing.
Let's test that out some time.
What kind of weapon do you prefer? I like the smaller, quicker blades.
Yes, you're very fond of saying that. You know I like hammers and axes.
And I found a new deposit of amber. Would have been nice to have some help pulling it out.
You used to love finding new places.
I still do. I just like to have food waiting for me when I come home.
Verner, you should have come out with me yesterday. I found the most amazing tree growing right out of a cave.
Sweetheart, did you move my pickaxe?
It's at the south end near that loose rockpile.
So you can be helpful sometimes.
No need to get snippy.
Ever think about spending more time around town?
I guess I should join you more often.
You should. I miss you.
Not when there's so much to see!
Oh? What about it?
I'll have to take your word on that one, my dear.
Sondas, I've heard about Morrowind.
That it was black and gross and nobody wanted to live there anymore.
To see the fires!
I've been in Skyrim my whole life. Why would I want to leave?
I think I like the lake here just a little more.
Do you ever want to go to Morrowind, Sondas?
And Meieran thinks that we should go there.
I don't want to hear another word about what you're learning from the elf! It's high time you learned to be a Nord, too!
But mama...
He's a half-decent farmer. Ask him to teach you to farm!
Thanks for looking after Hrefna.
Oh, it's no trouble. She's a smart little girl. Might talk your ear off, but she's fun.
Well, I know she thinks the world of you.
Well, I'll try to be a good influence, then.
I'm just worried about what he's teaching her.
Sondas, does Hrefna ever mention Meieran to you?
I wouldn't worry about that. He's a good elf. I trust him.
She hardly mentions anything else.
You're probably right.
What about your family? There must have been someone waiting for you back at the farm. Wondering if you were ever coming home?
You never talk much about yourself, do you Horik? I swear, these past 30 years you've been at my side, and I think I barely know you.
You weren't. There's just not much to it.
I see. You're a good soldier, Horik. I'm sorry for intruding.
What's to say? I was born on a farm, joined the Legion when I came of age, and I've served you ever since.
No. Can't say there was. My parents died when I was young. You and the Legion have been my only family since.
With you by my side, is that right Horik?
So much for old soldiers settling down to a life of luxury, eh?
No. If we must fight, we will, and you will lead us to victory. As you always have.
Of course. I would have it no other way.
I'm fine, Horik. I just... are you worried about this war?
Are you all right? You seem tired.
Did you ever have to fight off bandits, Frida? Like in your stories?
Why, I once fought alongside your father when we were both younger. Saved him from getting his fool head sliced off.
Who were you fighting against?
Oh, dearie, it was so long ago. But I do remember the celebration we had afterwards. Mead never tasted so good.
Dawnstar has always held its own against the bandits and wild animals of the Pale.
Oh, he was young, and handsome. I had half a mind to go after him, myself, before I met my husband.
Did I ever tell you about the day when Skald the Elder was Skald the Younger?
I can't imagine Skald ever being young.
Frida, you aren't saying....
I was a beauty in my day, dearie. Don't act so surprised.
You mean Hildolf the Skull-Splitter? Remember when we rounded up the townspeople and dragged him out of that cave?
Those were the days. I'd never seen my husband fight so bravely before.
Aye, to your husband. Divines bless his memory.
Now, who was it that kidnapped the Jarl's son 20 years ago?
Thoring, do you remember the time when that wolf pack come clamoring into town?
How could I forget? That old alpha male almost took off my leg.
Never did find out why they came sprawling into town like that.
Animals in the Pale don't need a reason to attack Dawnstar. It's just their nature.
Leigelf is a good man, and I'm not running out on him now.
Oh, got a bit of an interest in your boss do you?
No, not that it's any of your business.
You should quit working in the Eastern Mine. Leigelf's no good to work for.
Tough day at the mines. I swear the ore is getting harder to dig.
You're just getting older.
That's why I come here to talk to you. You're all heart.
Why would they be looking at me? Are they upset about the service?
It'll do you good! Maybe you could visit Irgnir or Fruki on your way out? I've seen them looking at you when they come in for drinks....
Why would I do that? There's work to be done here.
Oh, never mind.
I was wondering, father. Maybe you should take a day off and head into town. I could watch the inn while you're away.
I'm sorry. I just don't feel up to entertaining anyone just now.
No, Karita. I don't think I could.
Father, do you want to talk? About mother?
I'm sure she would want you to be happy, father. Entertaining the guests and drinking and making your lewd jokes like before.
Divines sake, Skald. Who do think we're threatening with our old war wounds? We're not soldiers, anymore.
He's proud of his service, Skald. The Legion taught us loyalty. And we're loyal to Dawnstar.
Your man Horik is wearing his old Legion armor. What should I make of that?
This isn't over. I catch you sending one letter to General Tullius, I'll have you both executed.
You'll shut your mouth and get back to work, or you won't be a miner or a soldier by the day's end. Hear me?
Work hard, now! The pride of Iron-Breaker Mine is on the line.
Pride of the what? This isn't the Legion, boss. We're miners, not soldiers.
Uh, yes ma'am.
We're at war with Leigelf? Isn't he your husband?
Drafted into a war, how could my life get worse?
No he isn't! He's the enemy, and we are going to crush him.
Keep at it. We need to work twice as hard now that fat-headed Leigelf has declared war!
If you don't mind me saying, Leigelf. You're working too hard. Go home.
What is this feud you have with your wife? What started this?
You don't want to talk about it, or you don't know?
Never. Not until we turn this mine around, drive Beitild out of business, and force her to apologize to me for everything she's done!
I don't want to talk about it.
It's good to hear you say that. I wish my wife was as simple as you.
Where else would I go? Dawnstar is my home and working here is my job.
I'll, uh, just take that as a compliment.
Thank you for sticking by me.
The forge is hot today.
Not hot enough. Does your Skyrim ever get warm, husband?
(sigh)
No. Not really.
I'm just worried about raising a child in the middle of this war of yours.
Your people's war, I mean. The Nords. What kind of life would we be giving our little one if we stayed here?
Hammerfell? I'm not against the idea, but why?
War of mine? It's not my war, Seren!
Rustleif, I've been wondering. Maybe after the baby is born, we should move to Hammerfell.
I... well, let me think about it.
Considering how the Great War ended, I think we need to be cautious about what we rely on.
Maybe you're right. I guess the battles I won yesterday won't win today's wars.
I don't think that's needed, Horik. It's the same strategy we used for every major defense during the Great War. It'll serve just as well now.
I'm sorry, Legate. I didn't want to imply anything about your ability to lead. You're a hero to the Empire, and I....
Yes, Legate.
We should go over our strategy again in case the Stormcloaks attack.
Oh, don't be such an old stick, Horik. I was joking. I can do that, you know. Redo the battle plans. I'll look over them later.
Brings back memories. Do you have any orders for me, Legate?
Just like old times, huh Horik? You and me fighting in a war over some forsaken scrap of land.
Yes, Legate. No one is getting through us.
Shor's bones, I hope you're right.
Keep the guard alert. I want to make sure no townspeople get hurt if there's trouble.
Thank you, Madena. I appreciate your assistance.
I, well, no of course not. I would be glad to help.
Madena, I was wondering if you could help me with something. Your magic would be invaluable.
Actually, I was just wondering if you could make sure people are tended to if they get hurt. I'm sure you wouldn't object to that.
If this is about battle magic, forget it. I've told every Jarl I've served under that I won't....
I'm fine, Madena.
I know old men sometimes have pains in their legs when they rise from bed. I know a few spells that could help.
I've seen you walking with a bit of pain sometimes, Horik.
Still suspicious of me. Well, don't say I never offered.
I said I'm fine, Madena. I won't have some court mage fixing me up like some magical experiment.
So you say. We'll see if that's true when the Stormcloaks make their move.
I'll tell you the same thing I told Skald. I'm here to help the people of Dawnstar, not play politics. Point your suspicions of treachery elsewhere.
I want you to know I don't trust you, Madena. And I'll be watching you.
Well, at the first sign of battle I'll be comfortably sitting in my room, waiting for it to end, so don't you worry.
Uh, yes sir. That's me. The oafish servant.
Skald, if you don't mind sir, I have a request.
You, have a request of me, Bulfrek? This should be interesting.
Well, I was thinking sir, with the war going on and all. Maybe, I could enlist? Fight the Imperials?
A servant? Enlisting in the Stormcloaks? Ah, Bulfrek, that's why I like having you about. You're always good for a laugh.
Exactly, Bulfrek. You always know your place.
Bulfrek, I have an order of swords and armor from the local blacksmith coming here. I need every piece polished to a fine shine.
Yes, my Jarl. We could hardly waste anyone else's precious time on such a tedious task.
With respect, Jarl. You can't ask everyone to throw themselves against trained Legionnaires. Let's leave the fighting to the Stormcloaks.
If we win. This war is going to drag on for years. I can feel it. We need to prepare for a long struggle ahead.
You're right. Why dilute the glory with too many souls fighting over it? We'll drive out the Empire and be celebrated as heroes when we win.
We are poised for glory, Jod. The Empire will never take Dawnstar while every last man, woman, and child here draws breathe!
Enough of your dire predictions! We will talk about this another time.
Glory is meaningless if they have no home to return to. I urge you to lower our commitments to the front until I'm sure we're safe.
You keep pledging more and more of our guard to the frontlines. The way this is going, we won't be able to defend our own borders.
I won't have you rob our soldiers of their chance to drive out the Empire. I'm done discussing this, Jod.
Safety? Don't I have you to handle the town's safety? What is this about, Jod?
Nonsense. The best place for our men is driving the Imperials back. I will ensure that men from Dawnstar get every opportunity for glory.
My Jarl, I have concerns about the safety of Dawnstar.
Skald, I've been meaning to ask you for a leave of absence. I wish to return to High Rock until this war is over.
You wish to leave now? In Skyrim's moment of triumph, just before we cast off the yoke of Imperial rule?
Yes, that's exactly what I'm asking. I'm not a Nord, I'm a Breton, and I have no wish to fight this war.
I don't think so, Madena. There will be no deserters in this hold, and that's final.
I told you before, Skald, I have no interest in taking sides in this war. I've no desire to be killed.
Madena, can we count on your spells to assist us in this war? The Empire is bound to bring their battlemages against us.
What good is a court mage if she refuses to fight? Where's your sense of duty?
When I came here, my only duties were to cure crop diseases and occasionally light a bonfire on holidays. I didn't sign up to kill.
Fine, but this isn't over Madena. We'll talk again.
Father, how come Olda's so mean to everyone? She's only ever happy when she's with Lodvar, and she's not even married to him!
Fine.
That's no business of yours, son. Mind you keep your nose out of it.
As do I. That man saved my life. I hope that someone helps him, as he once helped me.
And how is that old warrior doing these days?
Oh dear. I wish there was something we could do to help him.
Yes, just this morning. It was from Logrolf. He wrote to thank us for the food we sent.
Not well. He's convinced that his house is haunted, so he's sleeping on the street.
Did you read that letter from Markarth yet?
Faida came by today. She says you left the tavern last night without paying for your drinks.
I must have forgotten. I'll take care of it tomorrow.
See that you do. You're an embarrassment, Horgeir. I don't know why I married you.
I'm thinking of going for a walk up the mountain later. Would you like to come?
Oh, that sounds nice. Yes, I think I'll join you.
I'll bring a blanket and some wine.
Yes, I think I'd enjoy a woman like your wife.
One of these days, we'll have to find you a good woman like my Olda.
Yes, it's a great shame. Gods willing, I'll find someone just like her one day.
Well then, it's too bad my wife is already taken.
Your father's too easy on you, boy. I'd have you cutting wood at dawn if you were my son.
Papa says I'm not old enough yet, so I help out by patrolling the town with Lucky here.
Haven't you got some chores to do?
I won't forget. I'll do it after I get the dishes cleaned.
Mind you don't forget to sweep up, Julienne. The floor's looking a bit dusty.
If the Nine are willing!
You've been working hard lately. You'll make a fine innkeeper someday.
Of course, Julienne. What's on your mind?
Miss Faida, may I ask you a question?
Since my customers are mostly local, I just knock on their front doors the next day.
What do you do when a customer can't afford to pay for a meal or a drink?
Ah, is there any weapon finer than an Orc blade?
No, mother. It's no wonder our enemies fear the sight of an Orc warrior.
Sorry, mother. I'll focus on my work.
The metal has been stubborn today. It refuses to bend.
Save your anger for the forge. The steel cannot hear your whining.
Imagine the heads of your enemies as you forge. Let your hatred work the steel.
Yes, mother.
The air has the smell of beasts. The hunt is good today.
Yes, mother. I'm eager to prove my skills today.
Patience, my son. The hunter days not welcome the blood of his prey, he waits for it.
Ah, the air is good today. I welcome the smell of blood from all the kills I will make.
He is pleased. Ours is the strongest tribe in all the Reach.
Tell me, mother, does Malacath favor our stronghold?
Do they, my chief? Am I now favored enough to replace Shel by your side at the feast? Back your words with action!
I saw you working the forge today, wife. Your muscles have grown strong from the metal shaping!
No more talk of Shel. As chief, I will do what I please, so point your fiery gaze to our enemies.
My chief, Gharol threatens to have me work in the mines. You won't allow my pretty hands to dirty, will you?
Oh, thank you my chief!
No, my wife. You have been given other gifts to please your chief than mine work. I will talk to Gharol and all will be well.
This metal will serve the forge well, my brother.
It is a fine day to work the mines.
You could challenge Burguk, my brother. Yours is the stronger swordarm.
Serving in the Legion taught me to respect leadership. The stronghold needs Burguk.
Most of my friends are buried here.
You visit us often, Thadgeir.
There are a lot of good men buried here, Kust.
Men aren't good or bad. They're just men.
I suppose so. Seems like it was just turning summer yesterday.
And now winter is coming.
The fields will need cutting soon.
The impertinence! You never would have talked to me like that when I was Jarl.
Narri! This mead tastes like water and the meat has gone off.
The mead is same as it ever was and the meat is fresh, maybe your sense of taste has "gone off."
We had this same argument every week, even when you were Jarl.
As he should I suppose.
Tekla! It's good to see you, girl. How's Dengeir treating you?
Hmmm, well don't take what you don't have to.
I don't know about you, tekla, but all my prayers are silent and who I pray to is still my own to decide.
Narri, do you think the war will ever end?
I think the war is just an excuse. If it does end there will be a new reason and a new place.
But what about the banning of Talos worship? Isn't that worth fighting about?
Leave me alone, Lod.
Ah Tekla, you're a pretty little mouse.
Alright, but if you ever want to leave that old curmudgeon I've got plenty for you to do at Gentle Repose.
I wish I could afford to pay you both, Narri.  I really do.
At some point we should hire Tekla on here. If she could just spend less time serving Dengeir...
Will do.
Keep them coming and keep them strong, Valga.
The way this war is going you'll soon have plenty of veterans like me to buy drinks.
The way this war is going there might not be anyone left to drink soon.
Bolund, you're going to die of thirst if you keep calling me that.
Hey gossip, bring me a drink.
Hey, Lod, how is the worst farmer in the hold doing?
Sure it is, Lod. Sure it is.
The Gentle Repose is barren, it was barren the day my father claimed the land and it's barren now.
Do you ever get tired of long nights at the mill, Zaria?
Do you ever get tired of the long days on the farm, Mathias?
Yes, yes I do.
That's kind of you, Lod. You know how farming is here, long days and little to show for it.
Mathies. I wanted to say I'm sorry about what happened to your girl. How's the Corpselight treating you Mathies?
Hmmf. Maybe you're the one talking to him then...
Do you think Tekla has been talking to Siddgeir again?
We've been over this, Den. Tekla does not share your secrets with Siddgeir.
Tekla. The Hall is filthy. See to your cleaning.
Yes sir.
Don't let my brother get to you, Tekla. You're doing a fine job around here.
Thank you sir.
Falkreath is a fine place to be, Bolund.
Falkreath is our home, a place where we have good jobs under a good Jarl. Until the war comes to us we stay put.
Another day in this graveyard.
Falkreath is where people go to die. We could be fighting, taking back Nord land!
Ah, Indara. Arkay's blessing upon you and your husband. Spend as much time here as you need.
Thank you, Runil. Your support means much to us.
It is a hard time for all of us. I hope that you too can find some sanctuary here, Mathies.
The temple is the one place my wife finds peace these days, Runil.
The graveyard has been lonely. Few pay homage to the dead.
Few want to be reminded of mortality in a time of war, Kust.
Preparing the defenses is almost impossible lately, every time we get a new war report our needs change.
The trade routes are affected as well. Procuring supplies is a guessing game. Weapons sell well though.
Mmmm, careful with that, Nenya, our merchants could be selling weapons to an invading force.
Why have taxes not come in from Granite Hill, Nenya? We should send some guards down there.
They are only a little late, Jarl. The trade routes are affected by the war, we should give them another day.
Very well, but when their emissary arrives I want words with him.
Sir, I will shape them up but with the war on it is unwise to reduce their wages any further.
We can't afford to lose any men if we wish to keep Falkreath protected.
I would think a man of your military training would be able to do with less but so be it.
Helvard! The guards are looking sloppy today. I want you to reduce their wages for the month.
<Laughter>
Harpies, every one of them.
Oh, hi, I'm glad I ran into you. I was wondering if...
Hello.
I don't know. If you see any big strong men around, let us know, will you?
Oh, come now. Don't go away mad.
Hello, ladies! Is there anything a big strong man can do for you this fine day?
Good dog. Stupid dog.
Good morning.
Oh. Well. Good day.
Bah. What's so good about it, hmm?
I wish you didn't hate him so much... I wish the whole family could be together again. It's okay, mother. I understand.
That's because there's nothing to tell. He left us to fend for ourselves and that's all you need to know. He was a wonderful man, and he loved us very much. I'm sorry I yelled at you.
Gralnach! I told you not to go through your father's things!
I'm sorry mother, I just want to know more about him. You never tell me anything! I'm sorry mother, now that he's dead, I just want to know everything I can about him.
There is a copse of elms to the east. We could really use that wood.
Just be careful, Gralnach. That copse doesn't look safe. If you see any trouble, you run right home.
Mother, I finished cutting at the northern stand. Where do I move on to now?
I was hoping to head into Riften for supplies, but I can do that after I'm done with the elms.
Yes, wouldn't want to miss the lush summer we have ahead.
I was wondering if you had ordered the shipment of that frostwheat, sir.
Yes, but that fool Endario can't get it in. I'll thrash him when I get back to the city, don't you worry.
I wasn't wanting to get anyone in trouble, sir. Just wanting to get the new planting started, is all.
You just need to remember that there's a war on, and firewood isn't cheap these days.
Make sure the back fence is repaired. I swear I saw some skeevers in nibbling the leaves yesterday.
Oh, no skeevers out here, sir. They can't stand the cold.
Maybe, but the way you burn through all that wood to keep the cabin toasty, they might mistake this place for Elsweyr.
Sorry, sir. These old bones do like a bit of warmth in the evening. There's no need to make fun.
So have you ever actually spoken to Captain Lonely-Gale?
By the gods, he's just a retired ship's captain.
Maybe to you, but he's just so... his story is...
He's just a guard captain. And not a very good one, at that.
How have things been with you?
I got another harangue from Torsten yesterday.
Don't worry about him. I know you work hard, and I'm the one who gets you your money.
Thank you, miss, I appreciate that.
And what about the dogs? How are those precious little angels?
Healthy and strong. Ysgramor's coat's gotten so thick, he looks fat!
Oh, that's just adorable.
I'll do my best, sir.
Oh?
It's filthy in there! Dirt everywhere, and it looks like the dogs have the run of the place.
Well, sir, it's a farmhouse. It's not going to be as clean as your house in the city.
I just know that our sailors are able to keep their ship quarters clean, and I expect the same of you.
Tulvur! I've just completed inspection of the farmhouse.
I'll provide you wood and timber to make whatever riggings you'll need.
I'm not building a ship, sir. I'm trying to make things grow.
Sir, I'm going to need some better equipment if you want me plowing the frost.
Like what?
Well, some tools that aren't rusted through would be a start.
What is it now?
Fastred, I wanted to talk with you.
Wilhelm said he saw you speaking to one of the pilgrims on the 7,000 Steps. I told you that I didn't want you to go up there.
I know what you said, but I only wanted to speak to him for a moment.
Well it stops now, and that's final!
You're hardly throwing her to the wolves. She just wants to see the world... just like I did when I was her age.
And if she decides to leave Ivarstead, what then? No, no... I can't bear the thought.
You have to let Fastred follow her heart. You can't tell her what to do.
She's our only child, Boti. Am I to throw her to the wolves?
I need you to pitch in a little more around here, dear.
I help, I do the chores. What else would you have me do?
I know your sights are set beyond this town, but for now, while you're under our roof, I need you to pitch in a little more.
Yes, mother.
What's the point? I'm not very good, and it's only for the same few people every night.
I think you play beautifully. It would be a shame if you stopped.
All right, Wilhlem. I suppose it's the least I can do for you.
I think you should continue with your performances.
I'm sorry. I was curious... I didn't believe the stories. I won't go over there ever again.
See that you don't. I promised to keep you safe and I'm not going to break my word.
I think I saw it again. That... ghost. It was over by the barrows.
That thing's evil, Lynly! I told you to keep away from there!
Have you spoken to Fastred yet?
Klimmek is doing just fine. You should follow your heart.
No. I'll tell you, Wilhelm, if I could sweep her away from here tomorrow I'd do it, but Klimmek still has so much to learn.
Perhaps one day, but not today.
I know, but I don't want to let them down. I guess I better start thinking about it soon.
You heading up to High Hrothgar soon, Klimmek?
I wish I didn't have to. It's quite a difficult climb.
Take your time then. It isn't as though the Greybeards are going to complain.
You're sweet. I'm just not ready for that sort of thing right now. I'm sorry.
I thought you played wonderfully last night.
Thank you Klimmek. That's too kind.
Perhaps when you're finished here this evening, we could...
I heard Temba yelling at you yesterday. Why do you let her treat you like that?
If you'll pardon the expression, she's far more bark than bite.
Perhaps, but abuse is abuse. I don't think I could stand it.
There's much more to worry about in life then a bit of a temper, my friend.
Blood from a stone, Klimmek. I've been out there every morning. They just aren't biting.
Come on, everyone in town knows that you spend more time with Fastred than fishing in the river.
That's none of your business and I appreciate if you wouldn't mention it again.
We're behind again. I need you to catch another two bushels by week's end if I'm to make another delivery.
If you have a moment, I've come up with a few ideas I wanted to share.
I'm becoming sick to death of your ideas. Not one of them has paid off since you moved in.
Look, I'm merely suggesting a few things that could expand our business.
"Our" business?
As I remember things, it was you that showed up at my doorstep looking for a job and a place to live. Try and remember that.
Not today. I'm just not ready to make the climb to High Hrothgar. The path isn't safe.
On your way up the 7,000 Steps again, Klimmek?
Honestly, I'm not certain. I've yet to be allowed into the monastery. Perhaps one day.
Aren't the Greybeards expecting some supplies?
When I want your opinion, I'll ask for it. Otherwise, mind your business.
Another batch of logs completely ruined. I swear, these bears have it out for me.
I hardly think the bears are clever enough to hold a grudge against you, Miss Temba.
Gwilin! I told you to cut those boards at twice arm length! My arm's length. Not yours.
I'm so sorry Miss Temba. Perhaps if you would have been more specific...
Sigh. Everyone isn't as short as you are... what good are these boards to someone of the proper height!?
Sorry, Miss Temba.
When are those Silver-Blood men going to leave?
Never. They've shut us down forever, Enmon. The Divines have abandoned us.
We're doomed. The mine is going to stay closed, and we'll up be carted of to Cidhna Mine as slaves.
Only criminals get sent to Cidhna Mine. They're not going to send us there.
Oh, they'll find some way to send us there. It'll be just my luck.
What I meant to say was... I love having an Orc here in the barracks. They're so... pleasant.
I don't like bunking with Orcs. It's not... clean.
If you want me to leave, you could challenge me to a fight. I promise to stop once you've lost an arm.
Why do your people claim the Reach is theirs? The Orcs have been in these lands just as long.
You wouldn't understand, Lash. Your people aren't smart enough for politics.
Is that so? I'll remember that next time we're in the mine tunnels... alone.
Did... did I say you weren't smart? I meant to say that I'm not smart, Lash. I'm just not smart enough to answer your questions.
Nothing, Ragnar. Please... don't hurt me.
I... I'm sorry, Belchimac. I didn't mean that.
Damn Nords. Always getting in the way of us honest folk.
What did you say? You lazy coward, I'll cut your throat.
You're always talking about the Forsworn. You aren't thinking of joining them, are you?
Maybe I will. What do you think about that?
I'm warning you. Those people are killers. You'd never last a day with them.
I've been thinking, would you like to join me in hunting?
You want me to hunt with you? I thought you preferred being alone.
Your arms and legs are fit for catching strong, agile prey. I could use your help.
I'd be honored, but I have work to do in the mines.
When will Sanuarach Mine be open?
I don't know. Whenever those Silver-Blood men decide to leave.
I can afford to buy meat now. I prefer working in the mines, anyway.
I haven't seen you hunting in a while.
Tell me, Ragnar, what do you think of the Orcs?
Cunning warriors and skilled workers. It's good to have you here, Lash.
I asked what you thought of the Orcs, not about me.
Oh. I'm sorry. Well, it's good to have you here, anyway.
You have strong arms. You'd make a good Orc.
Um... thank you, Lash. You'd... make a fine Nord?
Don't say words you don't mean.
But why did they take her? What could they want with our little girl?
I don't know. The guards are out looking for her, now. They'll be back soon.
You keep saying that. What if she's gone forever? What if they've done something to her?
Are you all right, dear?
The house is so... empty, Enmon... and quiet.
Are you all right, dear? I thought I saw a tear in your eye a moment ago.
Oh, I'm fine, Enmon. I just... I still miss her.
I miss her, too, but I'm glad she's safe.
So am I. I hope she's happy at the temple.
Enmon, dear, do you have any regrets? About letting her go?
No... no, we did the right thing. The temple will take good care of her, and one day she'll be helping all of Skyrim.
You're right. She'll be a great Sybil, won't she?
Of course she will. She's our daughter, after all.
Do you remember the Legion? Fighting the Thalmor in the Great War?
There were many good battles, friend. I miss those days.
You miss them? I don't know how many times I feared for my life.
You didn't die. A battle you live through is a great honor.
If you had to kill your own brother to be allowed back home, you'd think twice as well.
Did you ever want to return to your stronghold? Go back to your family?
I would need to challenge the chief, and take his head, to return home. I'd rather stay here.
Don't tell me you, of all people, are afraid of a battle.
I feel like we're mining even more ore than before.
It's the rush of good fortune, my friend. It makes you work harder.
I doubt the Forsworn would risk holding this mine a second time. They lost many of their warriors.
Are you worried the Forsworn might return?
Oh, like the sleepy rebel supporters in this town are going to tell anyone.
Did I tell you I got a letter from General Tullius? They've conscripted some more archers and will need...
Let's just not take the chance. We can talk about this later.
Sssssh! That's not something we want everyone to be hearing.
I want to make money just as much as you do, but we don't want to make the Nords angry.
Who could tell the difference?
That last brigade of soldiers said there's a tall forest on the eastern edge of the White River.
Yes, but that's too close to Mixwater Mill. We don't want to get Gilfre angry at us by stealing her trees.
Well we have to harvest somewhere! This is getting absurd.
No! Roggi and Kjeld need some more support timbers for the mine.
I suppose Kjeld asked for the usual discount?
We've got a new order in.
Well, he is the mayor.
Is that a joke?
No, it's fine. I don't mind being poor.
Oh.
What about Ulfric? Did you ever hear back from him?
No, but his housecarl sent us a letter.
You see? That's why I didn't tell you!
Why didn't you tell me? What did he say?
He... thanked us for contacting him, but said they didn't need any more lumber at the moment.
Well, we have to cut down something!
Well that's just it. Some of them might not be sacred.
Maybe we should just admit that this is a horrible place for a mill.
I'll let you explain that one to the Nords.
They have to be reasonable about it at some point.
There is some good news though. I think the borders of the shrine may be smaller than we think.
Gemma. This town is called "Kynesgrove." That stand of trees is Kyne's Grove. You don't honestly think you can just cut some down.
Wait, so you think we'll be able to harvest some of the sacred trees up there?
But we choose our own path now.
And a whole lot of good that's gotten us.
I'll never understand why you're so bitter about everything.
I'm bitter because we had lives in Cyrodiil. And we came out here to be paupers.
Again? But there shouldn't be any earthstreams over there.
Well I nearly lost my eyebrows to it.
All right, I'll take a look at it.
Roggi tell you about the scorcher we found under the scaffolding?
What did I tell you about snooping around my wards?
Woman, there's a vein of malachite as thick as my leg back there.
And if you don't let me secure the steam channel, your leg could get blown off.
So go dig at the other corner for a bit.
Well... just get it done.
