No, I've been busy trying to keep the whole mine from collapsing, if that's all right with you.
You're busy. I'll come back later.
Is the new shaft cleared yet?
Mama, when can we go play in the river again?
No way. I'm quick!
Not with all those soldiers all over the hold. Their horses can't see you, you know.
Well why don't you be quick about finding my book that you lost?
I know, but...
And you'll be trampled to death!
She said you threw her into a goat pen yesterday.
Because she was being stupid!
You need to take better care of your sister.
Don't make me bring your father into this.
But she's so stupid!
But papa was going to take me hunting tomorrow!
Oh, I don't think you're old enough for that yet. You can help me salt the cheese curd.
Why can't Froa do it?
I'm going to need your help in the kitchen tomorrow.
Because I'm telling you to.
There you go, son. Be your own man!
Papa, mama's making me do kitchen work again.
And what did you say to that?
She can't tell me what to do!
It's good to toughen her up. Not an easy world out here. Keep at it.
And then I told her about the vampires and how much they would pay me for her.
That is rich. What did she do?
She's a girl. She cried.
Oh, really?
When do I get to go hunting?
So can I come?
When you're able to draw a bow all the way to your shoulder.
We'll see.
I can do that! I did it yesterday!
Kjeld bothering you again?
Nothing I can't handle.
Well, you send that blowhard to me if he steps over the line.
How's the mine today?
Not too bad. Careful around the more obvious scorchers.
As usual. I've always got an eye on the rocks.
Did something happen to it?
All the apiaries... it will take years to get those bees happy again.
Do the bees need to be happy?
Have you heard about Goldenglow Meadery?
Of course! You can't make good mead without happy honey!
If you like mead so much, why not go live in Riften?
Oh, I wouldn't be able to help them. Their skills were given by the Divines.
Maybe you could be a taster or something.
Ah, but I can do that right here. Right now!
How are the little ones?
Oh, you know. Little Kjeld is a handful, and Froa is just so quiet.
He takes after his father, and she takes after you.
Well, that's the good and the bad of it.
I'm not sure that's a good joke to tell with women present...
But don't you get it? She thought he was a troll!
I get it. It's funny. It just might upset your wife.
Eh, let her get upset. She'll be angry no matter what I say, might as well enjoy myself.
That's just it... if she's not happy, there are plenty of other women who will be.
So, Roggi, when are you going to get yourself a woman?
Oh, you old charmer.
Oh, I'm not sure I could ever settle down like you have, friend.
Who says I've settled down?
I think this is yet another conversation that wouldn't make your wife happy.
Better honey?
There has to be more to it than that, though. I wish I knew where the bees got it from.
How much do you know about the brewing of mead?
I know all there is to know about the drinking of it, and that suits me just fine.
I've been trying to figure out what makes Riften mead better than the stuff from Whiterun.
Always.
Does Dravynea know?
Found another one of those vents in back near the scaffold.
She hasn't had a chance to look at it yet. Just be careful over there.
I'd like the fresh air better, but this isn't so bad.
Sweltering in here.
I don't know. Maybe because it makes the mead taste that much better at night.
How do you stay cheery down in these blazes?
Again with the mead!
Not sure. Feeling like taking another trip.
What's your wife think of your trips?
They're none of her business, and none of yours either.
You going to be at the inn tonight?
But mom, it's so boring with just me and Torom. I was just asking Skaggi some questions.
Yes, ma'am.
Skaggi tells me that you were bothering him today. Can't you and Torom just play by yourselves?
You leave him alone. I don't want to hear Skaggi telling me you've been bothering him again!
Of course, sweetie. What'd you like to know?
I don't know. What'd he look like?
He had your soft face, and that silly grin you get when you've done something wrong. That's his, too.
Mama, can we talk. You know, about papa?
I'm grateful, Skaggi. I'm sorry my daughter gives you so much trouble.
You work hard, Daighre. Glad you have stayed with us.
Do you think the Forsworn will come here? I mean, if they attacked Kolskeggr....
Let's just hope that doesn't happen.
The Forsworn have taken Kolskeggr Mine. We're the only ones left.
Troll's blood, what happened to you Pavo?
Gods.... You two head inside and get some rest. I'll send word to the Jarl.
Are you all right, Gat?
Still shaken from all the fighting, my friend. It's been too long since I had to kill someone.
Well I'm glad you were there. I don't know how I would have gotten past the Forsworn without you.
Those Forsworn were fierce fighters. Fiercer than I could have imagined.
Thank the Divines we survived that.
I told you I don't like you going there. I've seen scavengers picking at the mammoths. They could be dangerous.
I had a look at that boneyard the other day, Vantus. The one to the Northwest.
Oh, half the field should do.
I just think pollinating would be easier if I could do a lot of plants at once.
That should be all right. How much space were you planning?
You know, I was thinking of expanding the herb garden. Make room for some new plants I'm planning.
Half the field? What could need half the field?
Uh... why don't we talk about this later?
Nothing, you pig-headed oaf!
What was that you said, venomous wife of mine?
What do I pay you for, to stand around all day? You're supposed to be bringing goods to the store.
There are no goods to bring to the store. That's what I'm saying.
No shipments have come in.
Lazy oaf.
Only a few things came today. Cedran said he'd drop it off later.
Cedran said he'd... what am I paying you for? Next time, you bring the shipment in yourself.
Where are my goods? Did the shipment come in?
Worse. The loss of shipments from Forsworn attacks are really hitting us hard.
Not too bad, I hope?
Imedhnain, I was just comparing the ledgers from last season.
Where's Cosnach, is that lazy idiot out drinking at the Silver-Blood Inn again? On my coin?
There are no shipments scheduled today. Stop covering for him!
Fine, I won't fire him, but I'm doing this for your sake. Not his.
He's just waiting for the shipments, Lisbet. He'll be back as soon as they come in.
He's my cousin. Just give him another chance. Please.
You strike your metal like a new mother giving her babe a light slap. Hit it harder.
If you can't pound the dusk out of your iron, it'll break when it's finished. Hit. It. Harder.
I'm sorry, Ghorza. I just... flinch, and uh....
When will I learn how to forge weapons and armor? Isn't that my job?
Your job is to do what I say. And I say you have many nails and fittings to make before you even touch a blade. Now get to work.
The Forsworn ambush our roads and dragons cloud the skies. Is there any good news?
Umm.... No, my Jarl. I'm afraid there isn't.
More settlements have sent riders to say dragons are being spotted throughout Skyrim.
Our men know how to kill Forsworn and Legionnaires, not dragons.
I want soldiers sent to deal with these dragons. Every able-bodied man and woman who can carry a bow.
We can't do that. Every soldier we send to hunt dragons is one more man that can't defend the Reach.
Killing dragons isn't defending the Reach?
I just don't know if I can keep you safe.
I wonder if we should finally leave Markarth. These dragon attacks, I think Skyrim is cursed.
We will keep each other safe. No matter what.
What kind of talk is this? The man I married would never speak of leaving his home.
First war, and now dragons. Everywhere they go, the Nords bring nothing but ruin.
Ain't nothing for it. They're still in charge.
Now you're being ridiculous. This is our city. Not theirs.
A Forsworn agent. Running loose in the city. The Jarl is going to hear about this.
The Jarl has things under control. Don't you worry.
This was their city once. They won't stop until we're all dead.
Someone was attacked in the market. Do you know who it was?
I think it was Margret. Poor woman, she was just visiting the city from Cyrodiil.
Yeah, but she was a Nord. And a noble. Perfect Forsworn target.
You're being paranoid. We're in control of Markarth. Not the Forsworn.
The Jarl is refusing to dispatch men to the front lines. Do you think it's because of the Forsworn threat?
Please. Those savages are no match for us. The Jarl is just biding his time.
Biding his time until what? Until another person is lying dead in the streets? Don't be naive.
No, no girl. It's the pickled spider tongue and then the decayed taproot. Do it the other way, and your cure turns into a poison.
There's just so much to memorize. How am I supposed to remember what goes where for every single herb?
You will. Until then, you'll taste every potion you make before you sell it.
You want to know a secret of mine, young girl? The most effective poison to kill a man? A potion to make others fall in love, perhaps?
I have one. A nephew. He's in prison for being a member of the Forsworn.
I was actually just wondering if you had any family....
I'm sorry, I didn't realize.
Oh. Oh, I see....
Don't be. We all make mistakes.
Bothela, I have a question....
I'm sorry. You don't have to tell me if you don't....
Real men prove their love. Words are as empty as the air they run through.
He said he loved me....
You should be more careful with the men you pick, dear.
Stop moping about, girl. Tears won't change what you've done.
We all get used, dear. It's living with it that makes you a woman.
I was such a fool. How could I let him use me like that?
I'm a cripple. I have a reason to be drinking.
And I'm a porter with no shipments coming in. You're not getting any coin from me, Degaine.
Give us a coin, Cosnach. You'll just spend it on cheap ale, anyway.
Like you won't do different?
You're lying. You're not quick enough to be a pickpocket. What's the real reason?
Fell off the top of the cliff after a drunken party with the priestesses of Dibella.
How did you manage to cripple yourself, Degaine?
I don't buy that story, either.
Mining accident, back when I was in prison for being a pickpocket.
Too bad. That one's my favorite.
Maybe we could spend a little bit more and buy some meat, Endon.
Maybe. Let me think about it.
Something simple, a stew perhaps.
What should we have tonight?
Stew again, papa? I want steak.
Markarth has changed, but the inn is as lively as ever.
The city hasn't changed that much, dear. Same old dwarven stones gathering the same old moss.
The stones aren't what bother me, love. The Forsworn are tearing the Reach apart.
Let's not talk about this over dinner.
Mama, when is Cade coming home?
Can I join the Legion when I grow up?
He's off fighting, Adara, with the Stormcloaks. He'll return when the war is over.
If there's still a Legion left, Adara. I'm sure you'd make a great soldier. Just like your brother.
Our son joining the Stormcloaks. If this war had never happened, Cade would have joined the Imperial Legion, like grandfather.
Endon, we talked about this... Are you still disappointed in Cade's choice?
No. I think if I was a young man, I would have done the same.
You're right, dear. I'm sorry to worry you.
Adara bends the silver so naturally. Grandmother would have cried if she saw how deft our daughter has become.
Well, I'm proud of both of you. I haven't been so busy since those nobles from Solitude come into the city three years ago.
I miss those days, before the Forsworn took up arms again, when you could walk the roads in peace.
We sold all those lovely little necklaces you brought me today. Did you make them yourself?
Endon, dear, please don't.... Save your frustrations for work.
That's right! Papa helped me with the clasps, but I did all the links on my own.
Aren't you wonderful! Why can't your father be more like you and your sister?
Are you going to walk over to father and start hitting him again?
No, not right now. Maybe later, if I'm still upset.
How are your chores coming, son?
I've been cleaning up spills and there is fresh linen for the rooms.
That's just terrible. I'm so sorry to hear that.
Another drink, Cosnach? A porter with Arnleif and Sons deserves nothing but the finest here.
No you aren't.
All your drinks are watered down, Kleppr. You aren't fooling me, and you know Lisbet can't afford to pay me enough for the finest drinks anyhow.
I wasn't aware that Lisbet was having trouble, Cosnach. Is Arnleif and Sons not doing a good turn of business these days?
What are you, blind? That store is empty. Forsworn get almost every shipment that comes in.
Don't worry, my love. Just show the bugs your adoring face, and they'll scurry away in complete fear in no time.
You're an idiot, Kleppr. Why did I ever marry you?
Not a day goes by I don't ask that question myself, my dear.
I don't know, my darling wife. I assume you're going to tell me?
It's rotten because the wood is cheap and its soaked with ale! Now we'll have to replace all the furniture before bugs set in.
All the wood furniture in this inn is rotting to the core. Do you know why that is, Kleppr?
Clean the rooms yourself Kleppr. It's not like you do anything important around here.
No, just check in the guests and manage the coin and keep a roof over your head. No, nothing important.
Frabbi, my dear loving wife, could you please clean out our guest rooms?
What? What did I do this time? I was just standing here!
You were just standing there when you were supposed to be serving drinks to our customers!
Shouldn't you be helping me then, wife of mine? Sharing my problems? Being my better half?
Kleppr, you idiot! Can't you do anything right?
I am your better half. And your better half is telling you to stop being an idiot and serve the customers their drinks!
How are your chores coming, my son?
Never mind your mother, Hreinn. You listen to me, and you'll be a great man one day.
Ah, my son, you'll be a fine innkeeper someday, like your father.
Today I've cleaned the linens, washed the floors, and checked in on all our guests.
But mother says you're a terrible innkeeper!
That's right! Worst innkeeper in all of Skyrim!
Will I need to talk so loudly with my wife when I get married?
Dibella's Heart, son, I hope not.
Father, why do you and mother fight so much?
We don't fight, son. We, um, talk. Loudly.
Uh, right. Maybe just one of the popular songs, like "The Slaying of the Falmer Princes"?
That's a sensible lad. Now fetch me drink.
Playing tonight, Ogmund? Everyone here is anxious to hear the old ballads performed by the True Skald of the Reach.
Son, I know thousands of the old ballads. If I played all of them, everyone in this inn would be as grey as I am before I finished.
Mmmhmm.
"Mmmhmm"? I've been working with you for over 10 years, and all you have to say is "mmmhmm"?
Sometimes I think we deserve these miserable lives of ours.
Another foul day at the smelter.
Always such a model for decency in these troubled times, Yngvar.
Ah, Yngvar, here to sing? You know an employee of the Silver-Blood family is always a guest of honor here.
Shut it, Kleppr. Thongvor isn't here, so save your kissing up for a Nord who cares.
Did you hear all that noise outside?
You there. If you're here to trade, step up to the counter.
It's just the market rabble. We should get back to work.
Uh, a nail?
Is that what you call it? In the Legion we would have called it "useless." Look how brittle the metal is!
I... I'm sorry. I just, well, the forge gets so hot and I thought....
Tacitus? What is this?
You thought what? You would skip a step? Not heat the metal all the way through? Useless! Now do it again.
I just wanted to know if you needed anything.
Um, no. Nothing. Nothing at all.
Uncle Calcelmo....
Are you sure?
What is it nephew? Can't you see I'm trying to think here?
Stop bothering me Aicanter!
Nonsense, you're a vital part of my research team. You'll be there, have no fear! Now, I don't want to hear another word of protest.
Next season, nephew. Next season for sure....
"Next season for sure..." What? Uncle Calcelmo, I don't understand what you mean.
The excavation, Aicantar! Right after I finish my book. We'll start excavating Nchuand-Zel again.
Could I maybe, skip the excavation, Uncle Calcelmo? I, uh, I just think you won't need me.
Of course there's a collapse in trade, Raerek. The Stormcloaks stalk every road and harass every one of our patrols.
Not to mention the rebels completely control Windhelm and all of Eastmarch hold.
Why do you pester me with battles we can't win? I need my steward to plan for our victory, not nag me with every ill account.
Forgive me for worrying about the future of Markarth. The lifeblood of a city is gold, Igmund, and it doesn't stop bleeding because there's a war on.
My Jarl, we need to discuss the state of Markarth's collapsing trade with the other holds.
Very well. I'll send a request for additional Legionnaires to protect trade to the other Imperial holds. Hopefully Solitude can spare more men.
Raerek, how is The Reach faring against this Forsworn menace?
Cowards, the both of you. My father would not sit idly back and wait while evil men take over his lands. We're done discussing this for now.
Things are bad, Igmund. Our forces are barely able to keep the Forsworn in check. Merchants are reporting the loss of more of their shipments.
This is why I say we take the fight to them. Gather the Legion and drive those blasted beasts out of the Reach for good.
And what do Legion soldiers know about the hills the Reach? And the caves that make up those hills? The Forsworn can hide and ambush every assault.
The safety of the city and our settlements must be our only concern, Igmund. The rest of the Reach is on its own.
I second that, Igmund. Who knows what that family will do for power? They could be working with the Forsworn, for all we know.
Igmund, we need to talk about the Silver-Blood family.
Enough! We can't imprison the very people that own the jail we would be throwing them into. The Silver-Blood family are to be left alone, am I clear?
Yes, my Jarl.
What about them? They seem loyal enough.
Loyal? Thongvor supports Ulfric and his Stormcloaks! We should imprison the entire family as a precaution.
It doesn't matter if they're in the city. We fight them where they live, we won't have to fight them here.
It's not that simple, Igmund. There are reports of Forsworn here in the city.
The only thing we need to discuss is how many men it'll take to flush them out of the hills.
My Jarl, we need to discuss the Forsworn.
They live here too, my Jarl. That's what I'm telling you.
Move it. Get to work. Get to work!
Filthy natives. Get to work. We have meals to prepare and no time to prepare them!
Right away, sir!
Always another big meal to cook. Figures.
Now now, brother. Arnoit is just being his usual gloomy self, he didn't mean it, did you Arnoit? You're just being silly again.
Whatever. Just get back to work. Now.
Voada, you spilled laundry water in the soup pot again! Do I need to cut off your fingers to teach you a lesson?
You touch her, and I swear it'll be your fingers that go missing, you stupid Breton!
What was that?
Flattery doesn't suit you, Thongvor.
How's the forge today?
Remember that old rusty sword I had? Damn thing must have had over a hundred chips in it.
Well, if you had learned to swing it correctly. A sword is an extension of the arm, not a meat cleaver.
I was about to say how impressed I was that you always managed to put it back together.
It's fine. Much better than the rickety tools I had in the Legion.
Your family's success burdens you, does it?
Sometimes I miss the Legion, back when the Empire stood up for Skyrim.
Hello, my friend. Come to visit the forge?
I grow tired of counting coin all day. Put steel in my hand, not gold.
No politics, Thongvor. I told you before.
What does that mean Reberrus? Are we winning or aren't we?
I want word on our campaign against the Imperials.
I, uh, I can't tell Thongvor. It's anyone's guess.
I have a few very detailed missives from border patrols, beginning with Fifth Irregulars' reports on the movements of....
Oh, Talos's breath, Reberrus. Skip ahead to the good part.
I see. Well, let's continue this discussion later then.
Oh, right. Oh, well, things are going well enough. At least, as well as we can hope.
The Forsworn aren't our real concern, defeating the Imperials and making sure we keep control of this city is.
Yes, Thongvor.
Very well, Thongvor. With the Stormcloaks here to help, the Silver-Blood family control nearly every route in and out of the city.
Except the ones attacked by Forsworn.
Well yes, of course you had to go and mention that.
How goes the trade in and out of the city?
Thongvor, do you really think that's wise? I mean, King Ulfric is such a busy man, and there are so many areas of Skyrim to protect.
Whose side are you on, Reburrus? I'm not worried about Skyrim, I'm worried about the Reach. Specifically, the part of the Reach we're standing on.
Yes, Thongvor. I'll draft the letter immediately.
Reburrus, I need you to draft a letter to Ulfric requesting more men.
Ha! About time we got some more muscle in this city.
Thongvor, I have the latest reports from Cidhna Mine and the smelter. We should go over them immediately.
Reburrus, there is a war being fought across all of Skyrim, and you bother me with the usual mundane reports about silver?
Look at these figures, Thongvor! Ore yield is down by half, and the amount of silver bars being smelted is slipping even more than that.
Oh, very well. I'll send my brother. He'll straighten this out.
Very good, Thongvor. It relieves me to hear you say that.
Picking on me again, you backbiting Nord? Tired of those prissy nobles turning down your rotten slabs of venison?
How dare you. No one turns down cut meat from Hogni Red-Arm!
Hogni Red-Arm, more like Hogni Fat-Arm.
Look at you, begging on the streets. Learn a trade.
Just try it. Maybe a little time inside Cidhna Mine will get rid of all that fat on you.
Alms. Give me some meat, you fat Nord!
What did you say to me, Reachman?
I said give me some meat. I'm hungry, and the Divines know you don't need more food in that huge gut of yours.
You little twig. I'll snap you in two!
You there, pretty lady. You need some fresh meat for your family? Just look at the blood coming from this cut....
That's disgusting, get that rotting carcass away from me!
What's wrong? You have to look at the blood closely to see the quality of the meat. How else will you know it's fresh?
I don't need to know if it's fresh from this distance.
Ugh. You're the most disgusting merchant I have ever seen. The guards should take you away.
The only people I offend are cheats who don't pay me enough gold coin, or idiots who don't know good meat when I throw it at their faces.
If you ever think of throwing meat at me, I will have you dragged off to Cidhna Mine so fast the guards will yank those filthy arms of yours off.
What do I do to deserve such hatred? You give people good food and good prices, and all they do is insult you.
Yes, I have. Adara made the rings herself. She is learning to bend the metal well.
Hello, dear husband. Have you brought more silver jewelry for me to sell?
They are perfect. Thank you both.
I'm afraid the necklaces aren't selling well. Customers are not interested in medallions engraved with the symbols of other provinces.
We don't have travelers from Elsweyr or Hammerfell anymore, Endon. Only the natives and the Nords stay in Markarth now.
I need to get back to the customers. We'll talk more of this when I come home tonight.
How are the necklaces selling, my wife? We could make more.
Humph. Used to be everyone in Markarth wore a necklace showing his home province, from Elsweyr to High Rock to Hammerfell and Cyrodiil...
As they always have, along with those crazed Forsworn. They've driven off the color that used to make this city great.
Oh, that sounds lovely.
Care to try out a new ring, or perhaps my daughter could make you a necklace...
Kerah, do you have anything... exotic? Something no other woman in Markarth would be wearing.
I do have one set of bracelets in a style that is popular with the nobility in Sentinel.
Sentinel? That's in Hammerfell, correct? And you say these bracelets are only worn by the nobility?
They are popular with the nobility there, yes. This particular bracelet is a copy of one worn by a Crown Princess.
Hmm. Maybe in a few seasons I could afford such a treasure.
Mama, why are you and papa fighting?
What am I supposed to do? Never leave the house? You want that, Endon?
You want to give up now? Out of fear? Is that what we're teaching our daughter?
We're not fighting we're just.... Why don't I get you something to eat? Mama and papa will talk later.
You're closing the stall, and that's final.
I don't want any of you thieving workers even thinking about stealing any silver.
If I see you sneaking off with even one speck of silver, I'll break your leg and throw you into the river.
Yes, Mulush.
I could smelt metal in half the time as you weak-willed pink-skins. Do I have to do everything?
No Mulush. I'll work harder.
Mulush, we need a break. The heat from the smelter is too much.
Are you complaining? Work. If you have strength to whine, you have strength to smelt.
Careful. You spill one drop of silver, I'm taking it out of your hide.
I'm being as careful as I can.
Did you just talk back to me? I'm not paid to listen. I'm paid to keep you working. Now work.
Just keep at it, or Mulush will beat you.
Divines, I'm tired. This is too much work.
Careful of the molten metal. That gets on you, kiss your fingers goodbye.
I know what I'm doing. Stop telling me.
Surprised to see you working. Mulush almost broke your arm yesterday.
Does it look like I can afford losing a day's wage? That damn Orc isn't getting the best of me.
Think we should buy more horses next season?
I'd rather spend the gold on a new litter of pups, but the horses bring in more gold.
Haven't attacked each other yet. Good a sign as any.
How are the new breeds getting along with my dogs?
Ah, Thonar, don't you worry. Nana Ildene isn't going anywhere.
Oh, I know, Thonar. Only a mad woman would ever betray the Silver-Blood family.
Ah, Nana Ildene, whatever would my family do without you?
Um, good. We reward loyalty, you know.
Uh, yes. Quite.
Rhiada, did you clean the tables today? They're filthy!
No, don't bother. You're useless, as always. I'll get Ildene to do it.
Oh, stop apologizing. It makes you look like an idiot. Learn to talk back a bit, girl! Why, when I was in the temple....
I misspoke. Never mind what I said. Now get back to work.
I'm sorry, Betrid. I'll clean them right away.
I'm sorry, Betrid. I thought I had cleaned the tables properly.
The temple, Betrid? You were one of Dibella's faithful?
You have worked here in the Treasury House for a long time, haven't you Ildene?
It's just... aren't you worried about the Forsworn? Maybe it's not safe here.
Thanks Nana. I feel better now.
Don't you worry Rhiada. If any Forsworn coming knocking on our door, Nana will let you know....
Yes, child. Nana Ildene has taken care of the Silver-Bloods for many years....
You're a very pretty young woman, Rhiada.
You're married, yes? To that young metal worker?
He's a lucky man to have such a beautiful young wife.
Why, thank you Thonar. I'm flattered.
Eltrys, yes, just last season we were wed.
Thank you, Thonar. That's generous of you to say.
Did I hear correctly, Thonar? Is your brother really asking you to settle another dispute between Mulush and Nepos?
Someone has to keep the silver production running, Betrid, and that means keeping Mulush and Nepos in line once in a while.
Humph. Who's running the Silver-Bloods? You or your brother? You need to tell Thongvor that he should settle this himself or step down.
The only thing I need to do, dear wife, is make sure profits are up, no matter what. If Thongvor won't do the dirty work, I will.
You'll never be in charge of this family with that attitude, loving husband.
I am busy keeping this family in coin and your pretty little head adorned with jewels, so I'll thank you not to question where I go at night, wife.
Well maybe if you would finally convince Thongvor to put you in charge of the family, I wouldn't need to question you anymore.
Oh dear, whatever is a girl to do with such fearful brutes about her?
Where were you last night, Thonar? Busy with work or have you found some other woman who's willing to tolerate your lack of ambition?
I'll take control of the family on my own time, Betrid. Until then, my brother remains in charge and you'll keep your mouth shut.
That doesn't matter. All it would take is a stray wolf or a bandit crossing your path... I can't bare to lose you after everything we've done.
If it puts your mind at ease, I'll take it with me. I'm sorry.
Husband, you worry far too much. We are within an hour's walk of Riften.
Synda... you left your dagger behind again yesterday. I told you, the road isn't safe.
Dravin! One of the soldiers I spoke to on the way home said you threatened them. What's come over you?
All you'll accomplish by threatening them is ending up in the Riften dungeon. You're lucky they didn't take you seriously.
I don't care! Just stay away from the soldiers and keep to your business. It's the only way we'll make it through this.
I can't stand them, they represent everything I hate about Skyrim. They're tearing the place apart!
Sorry, Marise. I just can't sit back and watch them treat us like a resource. This is our home!
You'll come of age soon. Time to be married to another chief.
I won't be married to some weak-willed Orc chieften. I'd sooner join the Legion.
The way you and your mother forge weapons is impressive.
It's simple Orc smithing practice, my chief. Nothing that hasn't been passed down for years.
I served in the Legion. Perhaps I'll show you some of their technique one of these days.
I am honored.
Malacath is pleased with your strength, Larak.
Your muscles ripple when you work the forge. It's pleasing.
Thank you, my chief.
Oh Hroggar, you know I'm always hungry. Don't worry, I'll eat when I need to.
Oh, look! We have company!
How are you feeling?
I feel wonderful, just like every night.
Do you need anything? Are you hungry?
When I grow up, will I go to the College in Winterhold?
But...
I was there only for a short time. Much of what I have learned has been on my own. And I will teach you. You have no reason to go there.
But I'm learning about magic, and that's what they do there. Shouldn't I go?
That is enough.
No, I don't think that will be necessary.
But you went there, didn't you? Isn't that where you learned?
The College is not the only place to learn about magic.
Yes, sir.
Yes sir, I have.
Good. Concentration is paramount when dealing with magical forces.
Have you been working on your concentration?
Because an unfocused mind will almost certainly be obliterated. Destroyed by the forces you attempt to control and yield.
Have no fear. I believe it is within you to excel in your studies. But you must learn to concentrate!
Why?
Oh.
It's just a dream, child. Nothing more.
Hush now. Think no more of it.
It was scary. It was like it was real!
I had a bad dream again last night.
Oh?
I dreamt that you went away. You made monsters.
It's not true, I assure you.
I don't know. Someone in town said it.
What? Where did you hear such a thing?
Is it true that you kill deer and eat their hearts?
Don't believe everything you hear, child.
Okay.
No, no. Just watch over him.
What sort of harm? Have you had a vision?
Good. He must be kept safe from harm.
Yes, mother.
You are looking after your brother, yes?
Have you... Do you see that future? Will I be a good leader?
That is what the Divines have planned for you, yes.
I will be Jarl someday, mother?
All things are possible, my child. But I believe it is within you to succeed.
Yes, okay. Well thank you.
No, Gorm. I am simply telling you what I see.
No, no. I'm fine. Is there something you need?
You are troubled, Gorm.
So, the same then.
The visions continue to hold me in balance, Gorm.
How are you feeling, Jarl Idgrod?
Do not worry, my friend. All is well.
The people still doubt me, don't they.
I have never doubted that, husband.
It does not surprise me. They do not share in what I see, and I cannot explain it to them.
No, not at all. It's just...
Just guide them well, and all will work out.
Have you made a decision about Falion?
What decision is there to be made? I allowed him to live here. I stand by that.
Yes, but there are concerns. Rumors that he's up to something.
We are all up to something, my dear. All is as it should be.
Joric will be what Joric will be. Give it time.
Still, I fear there is some connection.
It's Joric. I fear his condition is worse.
What troubles you, husband?
What? Oh, nothing. All is well.
He calls out in his sleep sometimes. I've heard Falion's name. What does it mean?
I have told Idgrod of your concerns. She'll look after you all. Please, go back to your business.
What's the Jarl going to do about it?
Morthal has enough problems as it is!
Please, enough already!
We've no need for wizards in our midst!
How are we supposed to feel safe in our own homes?
Bah, it's no use. Let's get back to it, then.
No. They ain't. And they aren't gonna. If you weren't payin' for your room, I'd have thrown you out a long time ago.
Jonna, do you think the townspeople are warming to my serenades?
Yes, but they'll come around eventually. You'll see.
Oh, I shouldn't be surprised if they come 'round. And if you're never seen or heard from agin.
When I'm known throughout Tamriel, you'll regret this decision.
Nah. Just... don't. Leave me outta it.
I'm thinking of composing a song about you, Jonna. Would you prefer that I proclaim your beauty, your strength, your...
No. I mean it.
No interest in being immortalized in song? Remembered and praised for all eternity?
Ho, Gorm.
Still the same. I tell you, something's got to be done.
When the time is right, friend. When we're sure.
Not right now. Anything new?
Buy you a drink?
The longer we wait, the worse it gets.
Let's talk about it some other time.
What can I getcha, Alva?
Eat? No, I don't think I'm... hungry. Not now, at least.
Right. Okay, tell me if you change yer mind.
Umm... Did you want somethin' to eat?
What can't you get me, sweetie?
Why, good evening Jonna!
How's business?
Very funny.
No, I... I was just asking.
It's as bad as ever.
They got used to Idgrod just fine, didn't they? So what's the difference?
Yes, well. Perhaps you're right.
When are you gonna do somethin' to help Falion? Stop people sayin' things about him?
You have to understand, his presence here has caused... Well, it's difficult for the people to get used to.
Would you like to buy a lady a drink?
After all you've put that man through. You should be more loyal to him.
Forget about Hroggar. He's always so tired lately. I need someone with a little fire in their blood.
What would Hroggar say if he heard I was drinking with you?
You tempt me mightily, Alva. But I won't cuckhold another man, even on murderer like Hroggar.
Hroggar doesn't have to know if we sit together. Or drink together. I doubt he would even care.
If you leave that kinslayer Hroggar, I would be happy to keep your company.
I'm bored, Benor. Nobody wants to have any fun with me.
No, I'm sorry. I'll just... I'll know it if I find it. Does that make sense?
Is there something you need, dear?
All right, can you describe it to me?
If it does to you, dear, that's all that matters.
I... I'm not sure. I think perhaps, but I don't know what it is.
Yes, I'm sure that's true.
Oh, of course! I'm sorry, I didn't mean to say that it's not.
I like your shop, Lami.
Morthal will be mine to govern someday. I have a great deal to learn.
Oh, I quite like living in the hall. Mother says it's an honor to live there and serve Morthal.
Thank you, dear. It must be nice to get out of the hall every now and then.
Well dear, you know where to find me if it ever becomes too much for you.
Oh no! I couldn't. Mother says they are a burden we must bear for our gift.
Oh, yes. All the time. They come with the visions, as always.
How are the headaches, dear? You or your mother still having them?
Are you sure you don't want something for them? I may be able to brew you something to help.
No matter. You'll take care of things like you always have.
Please, let's not have it come to that.
I hear Mauhulakh is wandering again. He's after a new woman.
True... we could simply make sure she never reaches Narzulbur.
He's lonely. What do you expect?
That wasn't what I meant.
They squander their father's love. We can't dally this time.
If he does show up with a bride, we'll have to move quickly.
Once she's with child, I will not harm her.
Yes, you've made that quite clear in the past. And now we have Urog and Dushnamub because of your weakness.
They are good, loyal children.
For all of us.
Have you scried anything new in the entrails?
Come back to me when you have something useful.
Very little. It's an uncertain time.
Not for us, it isn't.
Be careful. The spirits can speak to the living if there's a strong connection.
Bah. He never had a connection with any of them beyond what his loins told him.
Maybe, but...
He's been spending a lot of time at the graves again.
We're the ones he loves. Me, and you.
Good. The more time he pines for the dead wives, the less time he spends finding a new one.
Bolar, I must ask you something.
Well, that's a different matter...
Yes, child?
Have the spirits told you where I may find a wife? One who will be safe from this curse?
Oh, all things in time, my boy. All things in time.
What more do you need that Yatul and I cannot provide?
I need more children.
Why else have they cursed me? Killed all my wives?
Perhaps it's actually a sign of their love for you. They don't want to see you with unworthy mates.
Are the gods angry with me?
Then they should send one they consider worthy.
Patience, boy.
Why do you ask me that?
Don't you ever wonder, father?
I've just never heard of a midwife losing all her mothers like that.
All the time.
But your aunts don't even seem to care.
They are good women. They love me. You will speak no more ill of them.
They're miners. Harmless.
Father, I'm worried about Gadba and Mul.
I've just learned not to trust luck around here.
What about them?
You don't worry about two Orc men coming into your stronghold? That they might challenge you?
Oh, if you're worried about me trying to meddle with you...
It's not you I'm worried about.
Someday, you can have your own stronghold.
I think it may have to be far away from here.
I'm proud of you for helping provide for us.
Well someone has to provide around here.
How is your hunting with Yatul?
What is that supposed to mean?
We are strong. We get the job done.
Nothing.
Nothing! I... it's ill fortune. That's all.
I don't know what your aunts told you, but...
Well, your ill fortune means I have no mother.
They're not my aunts. They're your aunts. And they told me enough.
What are you talking about?
I... I'm sorry.
About how the Divines cursed you. What horrible thing did you do to deserve it?
Haven't I always been a good father? A good chief?
Yatul and I do all the hunting. Mul and Gadba do all the mining. It seems like all you do is find more wives to get killed.
That's not fair, now.
Just... try and keep out of our way.
Oh? I hadn't noticed.
Since Galka was taken from us. She's been... sad, I guess.
She's just worried about you. We all are. We just want you to be happy. We want to make you happy.
Bolar has been in a bad mood for weeks, now.
How will I know when I'm ready?
Bolar said you had been looking for a new wife?
Bolar and I will tell you.
Well, I...
I don't think you're quite ready yet.
You wanted to see me?
But I thought there was only one chief.
The other chief!
Well, right. One of us will be a chief.
There's only one chief!
How much longer do we have to work this backwoods mine?
What about the other one?
A bit longer, yet. We need more money if we want to be chiefs of our own.
Which other one?
No, I don't need to mark it. I remember it.
So where is it?
I found a big load of ebony at the bottom pocket in the mine.
You can tell it because it has lots of ebony.
Did you mark it?
Do you ever get a weird feeling about those sisters?
Who has a sister?
Not today, we can't.
Mauhulakh's aunts. You know... the way they're all around him all the time.
That's just how it is with families. When we're chiefs, you'll see how it is.
Can we both be chiefs?
Oh, good point. I wish my head were made of rocks.
Sometimes I think your head is made of rocks.
That would be good! I could use it to smash other rocks. Easier to mine, then.
My eyes are sharp.
Come, child, I will tell you how to track a snow cat.
They are, but your mind has to be sharp, too.
But you said that was impossible.
No, just very difficult. You have to look for shift in various shades of white.
They're fearsome!
They are indeed. Nothing like your mother, though!
What's the most dangerous beast you've ever killed?
That's what everyone keeps saying. But you didn't kill her. That's what I was asking.
Oh, probably a troll.
Oh of course. My mistake.
What about my father? Was he a good hunter?
Oh, you've seen your father just trying to chase a skeever from his house. He's a bit soft.
Sometimes I'm surprised he's still the chief.
We all are, my dear, but sometimes the Divines reward those who don't seem to deserve it. Call it dumb luck.
Yes. I'm sure he's doing well there.
Last time you said he was fighting for the Empire.
Mama, where did papa go?
He's off fighting the war, dear. For the Stormcloaks.
Did you clean the linens, yet?
I did. Those mead stains are always tricky.
Aye. It will be so. Shhh.
Do you feel that?
You're right. We're not alone.
We love you, Grelod. Thank you for your kindness.
Now, what do you all say?
Yes, Grelod.
And one more thing! I will hear no more talk of adoptions! None of you riff-raff is getting adopted. Ever! Nobody needs you, nobody wants you.
Those who shirk their duties will get an extra beating. Do I make myself clear?
That's better. Now scurry off, my little guttersnipes.
That, my darlings, is why you're here. Why you will always be here, until the day you come of age and get thrown into that wide, horrible world.
If only Maven would stop raising the price on it maybe I could afford to stock more cases.
Keerava, we're running low on Black-Briar Mead.
We could always look for another brand.
That isn't an option. Maven sees me serve a competitor's brand here and we may as well dig our own graves.
Don't worry, the time will come when we can walk away from here.
I hope so. I can't stand this city anymore.
Damn it, Talen. We still don't have enough this year to get out of Riften.
I'll tell you one thing, if you don't make peace with them soon you may get a walkout on your hands. Then we're both in trouble.
Why don't they listen to me, Keerava? Why won't they do as I say?
They always try to take advantage of me. Give them an inch and they'll take a mile.
Maybe they're afraid of you. Maybe it's your breath. How should I know?
Talen my friend, up for some fishing this week?
Oh come now, what's a dragon or two compared to a day full of fishing!
That's not funny, Bolli. People are scared.
I don't know Bolli. It's getting dangerous outside the walls.
Talen! Another round!
You stupid lizard! I said give me some more drink, or I'll have your head on a pike!
I think you've had plenty, Vulwulf. Maybe you should head on home.
Suit yourself.
Xhuth! Black-Briar or not, say that again and so help me you're going to need more than your mother to protect you from me.
Sorry Hemming, I've no interest in becoming your valet.
So, Talen. Have you reconsidered my offer?
What's the matter, I thought you people were used to indentured servitude.
I love when you spin that yarn. Gets better every time you add something new.
Was this before or after the Mythic Dawn attacked the Emperor and Valen single-handedly fought them off? Just shut up and drink, Romlyn.
Have I told you about Valen, my dear?
He killed six Imperial Guards before they dragged him into the prisons.
Drink up, my boy! Drink to those who have fallen! May their souls find their way to Sovngarde!
I'll rest easy when we've driven every last Imperial pig back across the Jerall Mountains!
Now, do me the honor I deserve as your father and drink up!
Yes... father.
Take it easy, father. You're making a scene.
You've been in Riften for quite some time now, Lady Mjoll. I fear that you soon may leave us.
I'm relieved to hear you say that. If you were to leave, I'd miss you terribly.
Riften has problems of its own. Now is not the time for exploration and discovery.
Aerin, I owe you my life. It would take a threat to all of Skyrim for me to depart.
Romlyn, I've been meaning to speak to you. I did a count at the meadery and we're four cases short... again.
I'm not accusing you of anything. Yet.
For your sake, I hope you're right. Because if it is you, and Maven finds out, the Dreth family is going to be one member smaller.
What are you saying? You think I had something to do with that?
The Dreth family doesn't steal, Indaryn.
We already have people that do that and they make quite a bit of coin for it.
Anything you say, Mother.
Hemming, I want you to personally supervise the next shipment.
I don't trust them. Come to think of it, I don't trust you either, but at least you're family.
Then put the thumbscrews on him and hit him... hard.
Bersi still refuses to cooperate. What did you want to do?
I've known Bersi a long time. Even before he opened that rubbish heap he calls a shop.
Give him one more week to think about it.
And if he still refuses?
We hold each other close and hope that all of this ends well.
Talen, do you believe what they're saying? Do you really think the dragons have returned?
I don't know what to believe. If it's true, then dark times may be upon us.
What should we do?
Nothing Vulwulf.... cheers.
Maven! So good to see you again. Hoist a flagon and celebrate with me!
Sorry, what was that?
Vulwulf, it's always a pleasure.
When you're standing downwind of me.
I'll pay you back, if it means that much.
The only reason you have the gold for your "business" is because I gave it to you.
It's not about the coin, it's about honoring your legacy by picking up arms and keeping this land free.
The sooner you remember that, the better.
I'm sorry you disapprove, father. But I've made up my mind. I'm not a warrior, I'm a businessman.
Is it really me, or is it your wife? You need to make a choice Bolli. The honey or her.
Haelga! That's just it. I can't keep up with you. Your Dibellan techniques... they're exhausting.
Oh, Bolli you silly man. You weren't saying that when you were licking that honey off my...
Haelga, we need to stop seeing each other.
I... I'm sorry Haelga, I can't. Not yet.
That old place? I could care less about it. Its you I want, Bolli.
I told you, I can't just pick up and leave. I have my wife, my business... not to mention you have the Bunkhouse.
When are you going to take me away from here Bolli?
It's only because I've had an excellent teacher.
Aerin, you never cease to amaze me. You always see the good in everything.
I think some of them do, Lady Mjoll. They're just too frightened to step up and do something about it like you are.
Sometimes I'm not certain that the people of Riften want to be helped.
If you want to go out to Whiterun and burn that meadery down, go right ahead.
And when the guard traces it back here, and Maven is implicated, I'll be sure to tell her it was your idea.
Come on, think about it. She'd reward us!
If you think I'd would make a move like that without asking Maven, you're out of your mind. Doing that would be a fatal mistake.
So, what do you think of my plan. You in or out?
I'm telling you, Vulwulf, it's the investment you've been waiting for.
Don't worry, I'll treat those shipments as if I owned them myself.
Shor's Beard! You're right! I'll do it... provided you supervise the shipments personally.
Exactly. What better way to help the cause than to put weapons into the hands of young Nord warriors dying for their homeland?
So I pay for the weapon shipments and you oversee their distribution to the Stormcloaks?

Go away. Edda, you know well I barely have any coin to call my own. I'm sorry. You must be starving. Here, spend it well. All right, all right. Here. Yes, I hope this helps. Yes, of course. This war is causing your woes, it's hardly your fault. Certainly, good lady. Here. Are you joking? Go earn a living and stop loafing! I would if I could, but I can barely make ends meet. Here, this should help. Of course, here. Be well. Maybe you should look for work instead of begging for coin. Here you are. Oh you poor thing! Come by the temple and my husband and I will keep you fed. Edda, Edda. There's no need for this. Just come by the temple and we'll care for you. Sorry, all out of coin. I've told you before, and I'll tell you again. Leave me alone. Ugh, you reek. Get out of my way. Here you go, dear. Oh, very well. Just try and clean yourself up. Get away from me, you filthy woman.

Please milady, can you spare a gold coin for an old woman? Please my lord, can you spare a gold coin for an old woman? Please help me, I'm starving. Please, I don't have anything to eat. Can you spare any coin? Spare a septim?
Spare a coin? If you could spare a septim, I'd be grateful. Help out an old man here with some coin, would you? Hey, can I get a gold or two? I could sure use some coin.

No. Now shove off. Snilf, it's me. I don't have a roof over my head either, remember? Oh if only I could provide more than this coin. I hope it'll do. Again? Buy some food this time will you? Yes, I hope this helps. Another uncounted causality of this war. Here you are, you poor man. Certainly, my good man. Here. You're disgusting, stay away from me. If I had even a pot to piss in, I'd gladly share. Sorry. Yes, I hope this helps you. Absolutely. Here you are. Be well. Ugh, you smell horrible. Get yourself cleaned up. Very well, here. Oh you poor thing, you must be starving. Come to the temple later and let us feed you. Snilf, I told you begging isn't the answer. I expect to see you at the temple later. Sorry, no time. I'm late. If you want to awaken from your next slumber, I suggest you leave me be. What? No. Get away from me. I suppose. Just get something to eat and stay away from the Bee and Barb for a change. Very well, please use it for food. Never. Now move aside.
I've told you, my interest in the family business is quite low. I wish to be much more than just a merchant.
Yes, mother.
Ingun, how much longer do you intend to waste your life concocting your foolish little potions?
Your interests lay where I wish them to lay otherwise my favorite daughter may end up homeless and without a septim to her name. Is that clear?
Hemming, I need you to bring a note to Sibbi. I need him to do something for me.
I know that!
I can promise you when he's ready, he'll find the cell door unlocked.
I tolerate your son because he'll do anything I ask, without question. I'd expect the same from my own son.
Sibbi? He's in prison... you put him there.
Why do you tolerate him, mother? All he contributes to this family is embarrassment and disgrace.
I understand, mother. Forgive me.
This is the last warning. You do it again, and you'll be sleeping in Beggar's Row with the rest of the riff-raff!
I... I'm sorry. I could have sworn I sealed it.
No.
Tell me something. Do you enjoy spending Lady Maven's gold for her? It certainly seems that way.
Ungrien! I just found another spoiled keg! What's the matter with you?
That s'wit. One day, he'll regret pushing all of us around.
All I'm saying is Indaryn's going to push someone too far one day and they're going to push back... hard.
Do you know what Indaryn told me? He said if I'm late one more time he'll kick me right out the door!
What do you mean?
The Dark Elves and the Wood Elves have never been the best of friends. Be patient, they'll come around soon enough!
Chin up, Ungrien! Remember, you have a roof over your head and food in your belly thanks to the very same Dark Elves. Be thankful.
I don't know if I can stand the abuse here much longer. They treat us like outcasts.
Wretched Dark Elves. It's just my luck I ended up working under one of them.
Sigh. What is it now, dear?
Don't you "dear" me! I had a bowl of Vampire Dust on my worktable not an hour ago and after you swept in there it's gone!
Ah, I see. Well, just be careful around my things!
Hafjorg! Where did you put it woman?!
Oh my. Elgrim, it's on the shelf to the right of the table, as always.
Oh dear, I didn't mean to say she isn't bright.
It's the things she makes here, the things she says and all those poor little animals she tests them on. It's just not right.
Elgrim, honey. I'm concerned about your new pupil. She seems very... odd.
Ingun? She's brilliant; a natural!
Damn it, woman! Ingun is the most promising alchemist I've ever seen and I won't have you scaring her off!
Ingun! If you want to remain in my shop as an apprentice I expect you to act like one. No exceptions!
Very well, I'll keep practicing them.
I don't understand, Elgrim. The formulas you're giving me are for novices but I've advanced well passed that point.
Until you can do those formulas with your eyes shut, you'll never be ready to master the more difficult ones.
This is an utter waste of time.
Ingun, you clumsy fool! You've tainted our entire supply of Painted Troll Fat. You have no idea how hard that was to get.
I'm sure my mother can compensate you for it.
I'll draft a letter to Rythe. If you could have it sent to Cheydinhal for me, that would make up for your blunder.
I'll make sure it's sent right away.
It means I have a business to run, I need to have the books straight and you're barely ever here!
And just what's that supposed to mean?
For goodness sake, Bolli! You barely lift a finger yourself when you're here except to point at things for your workers to do.
Let them do the work, that's what you pay them for!
Decided to show up for work today, eh?
Sigh.
Bolli, I was looking at the finances and I noticed you've been donating gold to the Temple of Mara. Are you out of your mind?
Maramal's been helping me through a rough patch. I just wanted to pay him back. It's not like he's keeping it!
Uh huh. I'm sure he runs outside with the coin and throws it up in the air so Mara herself can catch it. Come off of it, Bolli.
You may be my wife, but this is my business, so just do your job. Don't worry, you'll still have plenty of gold left over to waste on trinkets.
I know, I was late. I'm sorry.
I don't know what I'm going to do with you. I can't just let this go unpunished.
Wujeeta, we need to talk.
Sigh. Very well. You're lucky Maramal has placed me in a very forgiving mood.
Please, don't get rid of me! I need the coin. I... I'll work for free for the rest of this week. Please!
What was that?
There's always the Thieves Guild.
No, no, no. I need this job! This is the last place in town to have work.
Wujeeta, you can't keep showing up here late. Bolli's just going to get someone to replace you.
Nothing, nothing. Just straighten yourself out before you find yourself headed back to Black Marsh.
The gate's unlocked. You can head inside when you're ready.
Lady Mjoll, if you lost a gold ring anywhere in this city I'm afraid it's likely never to be seen again. I'm sorry.
I was hoping you could help me. It seems I've lost a ring that also means quite a bit to me.
It's made of gold with an inscription on the inside that says "sand elske."
I'm afraid not. I don't deal in stolen goods.
Stolen? How can you be certain? I may have just misplaced it somewhere in the city.
I have a single one left, quite expensive, but also quite elegant.
Posh. I'm not paying for it. Put it on Bolli's account if you please.
Ah, Nivenor. What can I sell you on this fine day?
I'm looking for a necklace. Do you have anything with garnets?
Outrageous! Who does she think she is?!
Madesi, what's this bill for 300 septims!
Begging your pardon, milord. Your wife has run up quite an account in the last few months.
Oh, well... I suppose that's a noble cause. I'll settle this bill at the end of the day. Thank you.
I believe she's trying to look as ravishing as possible for you, milord.
Begging your pardon milady... I know these have something to do with Dibella, but whatever are they for?
Maybe I'll show you one day, Madesi. Have them delivered to the Bunkhouse, won't you?
Lady Haelga, so pleased to see you. Your Marks of Dibella are ready.
Oh, splendid! I can't wait to use them.
Oh, I'm so sorry. I'm certain Bolli would be happy to lend you a few septims.
Much appreciated, Lady Drifa, but I'll manage.
We got a few pieces of jewelry at the Prawn, Madesi. Want to come take a look at them later?
I wish I could, milady. Sadly, I haven't sold enough of my own jewelry let alone buy some from you. I'm sorry.
When are you going to stop by the temple, Madesi?
It only takes but a moment to say a silent prayer to Mara. Please come by soon; not for me, but for yourself.
Very well, I'll try milady.
Sorry Lady Dinya, but I've been busy of late.
Please, milady, it was only because he threatened me. He said he'd have me thrown in the prisons if I didn't give him what he wanted!
I can't afford to just give my jewelry away!
Lady Maven, how may I help you?
Next time a Black-Briar asks for something, I suggest you respond quickly and affirmatively.
Is it true that you refused to sell one of your... trinkets to Hemming?
Madesi, my friend. How have things been since last week's incident?
Hello, Lady Mjoll.
It's my pleasure. If you see the Thieves Guild harassing anyone else, you be sure and let me know.
Ever since you scared off that thug from the Thieves Guild, not one of them's bothered me. We're lucky to have you here.
Here's another septim, Madesi. How much more do I need?
Don't worry, Shadr, your secret is safe with me.
It's for Marise, but don't say a word to her!
Only thirty more and it'll be all yours. If I might ask, who is the lucky woman?
Tythis, please. The Snow-Shods are good people, but tend to exaggerate. Try and stay calm for your own sake.
Madesi, have you heard the Imperials might be headed this way? What would we do?
They aren't invading, milord... it's simply a response to Ulfric and his Stormcloaks. I assure you everything will be fine.
But I've heard from the Snow-Shods that they intend to burn this place to the ground!
All right, all right. Just bring it to me tomorrow and I'll fix it for you.
Why should I pay for a repair on something I just bought?
Fine. It'll be five septims to repair it.
Grelka, I wanted to talk about that suit of leather armor you sold me. The fasteners are already coming loose.
I'll contact my man tonight and let you know what he says.
I don't care what it costs. I need four longbows and four score of arrows. Just make it happen.
I don't usually deal in weapons, but I know someone who can get them for me. You mind paying a little extra to get them fast?
Grelka, how fast can you get your hands on some longbows?
Whatever you say.
I'm watching you, Grelka. One slip up and I report you to the guards. You got that?
I don't know what he's talking about. He must be seeing things.
Aerin tells me you might be dealing arms to the Thieves Guild. Is this true?
Did you do everything I said, Shadr?
Thanks, Grelka!
Hey, I told you not to ask any questions. Now, here. For your trouble.
Yes. The man came by at noon just like you said. I gave him the package and he gave me this pouch for you.
The package was heavy... I needed his help getting it on his horse. What was inside?
I'd still keep an eye on my purse if I was you.
If that's true, then we have much more to fear than the Thieves Guild.
You've heard too? They say the town was completely destroyed by a dragon.
So while I was in Ivarstead, I heard news that something terrible happened at Helgen.
There's the stories about Helgen, bandits, skirmishes between the Stormcloaks and the Imperials... it almost seems endless.
That's a shame. What's causing them all the trouble?
Dinya, about that incense you requested? Its not arriving anytime soon. The Khajiit caravans are having tough times getting through.
Chin up, Brand-Shei. Lady Mara will provide us strength and guidance through these difficult times.
Perhaps they moved on to greener pastures. Whatever the reason, lets be glad they're scarce.
No. I'm surprised actually. I thought they had a stranglehold on the city, but in the last few years, it hasn't been that bad.
They haven't been by the Bunkhouse, but I'm certain they will. How about you?
Has the Thieves Guild visited you yet, Haelga?
It's true. Wasn't much of a thief though. Made enough noise to wake the Red Mountain.
Is it true you chased a thief from your home? I overheard Aerin mentioning it.
Well met, Brand-Shei. I've come by to browse your wares today.
Good. Maybe that will teach them to leave honest citizens alone.
Um... okay. Well, the boots aren't here yet. Hopefully on the next Khajiit caravan.
Always be prepared. You never know if you might get a split in one, or lose one, then where would you be? No sir, that's not happening to me.
What's with all the boots and shoes you keep buying? You must have bought twenty pairs in the last two years.
Brand-Shei... have you managed to find those boots for me?
Well, whatever you're doing, keep doing it and you'll have me as a customer for life.
Can't tell you. It's a bit of a trade secret I picked up when I was living in High Rock.
Thanks for that bushel of apples, Marise. They're wonderful. How did you keep them so fresh?
In a manner of speaking.
May I ask what all the honey's for? I mean, you used to buy almost a jar a week. Are you cooking or something?
I thought it was strange that Aringoth stopped coming into town. I suppose he's having some difficulties out there.
I'm afraid it's going to be a while before I can get any more Goldenglow Honey.
Well, if the shoe fits...
You know very well what I'm talking about. You're saying that I only married Bolli for his gold and that I don't really love him.
What rumors?
Hey. What's the matter with you? You have no right to spread rumors around town about me.
Interesting. Keep your ears open for me and tell me if you hear anything more. I'll make it worth your while.
I heard a traveler say that Helgen was destroyed by one of those creatures. Didn't leave a soul alive they said.
You watch the market, you hear the rumors around Riften. What have you heard about these dragons?
Yes?
Relax, Marise... I have no quarrel with you. I just wish to speak a moment.
Oh! Miss Maven. What can I do for you?
My dear, you have no idea who you're trifling with. Now I suggest you turn around and rattle someone else's cage before you get hurt.
You're a cold, unfeeling bitch.
You may have everyone else impressed around here, but you don't impress me. You couldn't touch me if you wanted to.
Maven. How's the criminal underworld treating you this fine day?
I'm watching you, Maven Black-Briar. One day, you'll slip up and your Imperial friends won't be there to catch your fall.
Religion isn't going to save me. So unless Mara is going to start raining coin from the heavens, why don't you mind your own business.
You poor thing. You should come by the temple, speak to Maramal.
What's so good about it? I've got deadbeats who don't pay me, the city guard looking over my shoulder and Maven Black-Briar breathing down my neck.
Good day, Grelka.
Not lately. Why?
Grelka, have you had anyone come by and try to sell you an iron war axe?
Oh I get it. "It's missing so Grelka must have it." I wish this town would stop pointing their fingers at me.
There is a Thieves Guild in town you know.
Well, we had one go missing from the Pawned Prawn, and I was just wondering...
It's a religious thing.
Try it out? What would you need a leather harness for anyway?
Oh, good. I wanted to try that out as soon as possible.
Oh, Haelga... there you are. Your special order from Hammerfell came in off the last Khajiit caravan.
What's that supposed to mean?
If he paid what he owes, I wouldn't have to say anything. Besides, what in Oblivion do you care?
What's this nonsense I've been hearing? How dare you call Bolli a deadbeat!
Oh come off it, Niv. We both know you married that fisherman for his gold. You don't need to put on an act for my benefit.
Why in goodness name would you have... oh never mind, just bring them by my house later and I'll see what I can do.
Horker skin, actually.
Leather? If they're armored, you should talk to Balimund over at The Scorched Hammer.
Grelka, can you repair boots?
Just when you think things couldn't get any worse.
One of them came in and demanded payment. Bolli tried to tell them no; stood up to them, but...
Did something happen at the Pawned Prawn?
I've come to warn you that the Thieves Guild seems to be back to its old tricks again.
Maven, I... please, don't hurt me.
Turning him in to the guards? Have you joined Mjoll as official peacekeepers of Riften? You cost me a lot of coin.
Maven, please. I didn't know it was your man. Had I known, I would have looked the other way, I swear.
I don't like being made a fool of, Brand-Shei. Not one bit.
I'll see what I can do.
That's fine. I have a special occasion coming up, and I'd like to have it.
The Argonian sugar-cane wine? It's pretty hard to get around here. Very expensive.
Brand-Shei, do you think you can find me some theilul?
Brand-Shei, did you hear about Helgen? It's... it's gone! A dragon burned it to the ground!
I don't know. All we can do is hope the Eight will favor us and have these creatures stay far away from Riften.
Do you... do you think that could happen here? I mean, could a dragon come here and burn the city down?
Yes, I heard. I think all of Skyrim knows by know.
Shadr, that's so sweet... I'd love to.
Naw... he's fine. Look, I wanted to ask if you'll... um, if you'd like to... well, like to have a drink with me at the Bee and Barb sometime?
I'm well. How are things over at the stables? Old Hofgrir giving you a hard time?
Hi, Marise. How are you today?
Sounds good. May I owe you for them?
I have two more bushels for you, Marise. That should keep you well-stocked.
You know I can't tell you that. As soon as I do, and you have a few meads in you, everyone will know.
Of course.
Say, how are you going to sell all those fish before they spoil?
No, no... not at all. Mara believes that the spark of a union comes from inside us, not from our appearance.
Tell you what... if you still feel unsure, come by the temple sometime and we'll talk about it.
There's someone I like very much in Riften. I think I'd like to marry him someday, but... well, he's not of my kind. Would Mara be angry?
Feel free to ask me anything you like.
Dinya? I was reading that missive you gave me and I was wondering something about marriage.
Marise, I've come to warn you that the Thieves Guild has been harassing shopkeepers again.
I hope that doesn't mean things are going to get worse around here.
I've heard. Bolli and Keerava were speaking of it just a little while ago.
If I see him, I'll make sure he doesn't do anything brash. Don't worry.
It's Bersi. He's getting so angry about the corruption in Riften, he said he's going to walk right up to Maven and give her a piece of his mind.
What is it, Drifa? What's the matter?
Mjoll! I'm glad I found you.
Good. You could be our first line of defense since you live outside the city walls, so we're depending on you.
Yes, Lady Mjoll. If Riften gets attacked, we'll retreat inside the city gates and bar the door just like you said.
Have you prepared the stables like I suggested, Shadr?
When I got close, the mercenaries Aringoth hired to protect the estate just waved me off. I don't think he wants visitors anymore.
Why didn't you then?
Bountiful. Although I would like to have anchored a bit closer to Goldenglow Estate.
Hello Bolli. How's the fishing?
Sigh. Yes, as usual. I'll be there.
Will we be dining together this evening after my work at the fishery?
Oh! Bolli... yes, hello.
Nivenor, my darling. What a pleasant surprise.
Of course. I rented a bed there. Where else would I sleep?
So, Tythis... you coming by the Bunkhouse later?
Sigh.
Good, that must be very comfortable for you. I think mine's a bit too small. Perhaps we could trade?
I have plenty of room in my bed.
Very well.
Of course he wasn't you stupid whore; he's a man. Now I'm not going to warn you again. Is that clear?
He wasn't protesting, Maven.
Haelga, I like you, so I'm only going to say this one time.
If you ever try and "practice the Dibellan arts" with Hemming again, I'll make sure that pretty little face loses its beauty.
It's only a bit of fun. You're a lovely young thing, you should try it sometime.
You mean Sibbi? You must be joking! All he wants to do is bed you and be done with it. You may as well get it over with and let him.
Aunt Haelga, why you... demean yourself with these people you barely know? They show no real love for you.
No! I'm saving myself for someone special. Someone who loves me dearly.
You're wrong! Sibbi and I are in love and you're just jealous!
Svana! Has that skooma-addled idiot Niluva paid us her rent yet? Or does she have more excuses?
Why do you insist on defending that woman? All she does with her money is spend it on that Dark Elf garbage!
She said she'll have it soon. She still has her job at the meadery for now, so she'll be able to pay us.
Just be patient, aunt. She'll have it, I promise.
Hey, Svana... I hear you like Dark Elves. Perhaps I could should you what a real Dark Elf can do to you.
Ah, so my reputation as a lover precedes me. Care to reconsider?
You're an animal, Tythis... keep away from me.
You're disgusting! Don't you even think of laying a finger on me or I'll cut off something you can't live without.
Well, let's all raise a flagon to Ulfric; future King of Skyrim and bringer of poverty to the working class!
So, Brand-Shei... business as awful for you as it is for all of us?
Grelka! Lower your voice before you get us both in trouble.
Worse. The Khajiit Caravans are the only way to get supplies into the city, and even those are becoming more infrequent.
If you'd stop wasting your coin on that skooma, you'd have enough gold to live on.
Sorry, Tythis. I'll get it to you somehow.
Niluva, you promised me you'd pay me back yesterday. So what's the story?
Just give me a few more days and I promise I'll come up with it.
How do you do it, Valindor? How do you work at Black-Briar Meadery and the Fishery without getting exhausted?
Oh, it's not so terrible. I actually find the work quite relaxing.
Relaxing? They must be working you to the bone! You should rest before you do yourself in.
Not to worry, dear Svana. I promise you I can handle it, but your concern is quite flattering.
It's an evil substance. Whoever's selling it to you should be brought to justice.
Wujeeta, you really need to stop using that skooma. It's very bad for your health and I wouldn't want to see anything happen to you.
If there was any justice in the world, I'd just get this over with and die peacefully.
I can't, Valindor. It won't let me go. It's taking over my life.
Don't worry about it, Svana. It's my problem... no need for you to get involved.
Look, if you're in some sort of trouble, I could talk to Haelga.
No, no... please, I'm just tired is all. Thank you.
Wujeeta, you're worrying me. You look so... well, so sad.
They say... well, they say he murdered someone. Something to do with Svidi.
Svana, I heard that Sibbi was put in jail. What happened?
If he wasn't a Black-Briar, I'd march right over to the jail and teach Sibbi some manners... but then I suppose I'd end up like Wulfur.
No, it was Svidi's brother, Wulfur. She's in hiding now. Somewhere far from here I'd suspect.
Come to think of it, I haven't seen Svidi in a while. Wait... he didn't...
You have a kind heart; much too kind for Riften. Don't worry about me, I'll be just fine.
Are you sure that's the real reason? It wouldn't have anything to do with others making an Argonian unwelcome, because if it is...
The cold stone, the dampness... it suits me, Svana.
Madesi, why don't you just take a bed here? There's no need to sleep in Beggar's Row.
Hey, greenskin... close your mouth. Some of us are trying to eat over here.
You're not going to goad me into a fight so I'll get kicked out, Grelka. Eat your food and leave me in peace.
Or perhaps you should crawl back into whatever swamp you came from, lizard man.
There's no need to be rude, Grelka. If you don't care for Argonians, then perhaps you should take residence somewhere else.
Don't let it get you down. Indaryn will eventually tire of picking on you and move on to someone else.
And do what? Losing a job from the Black-Briar family would make me a marked man. No one would ever take me on anywhere else.
Maybe it's time you quit then.
I can't take it anymore, Tythis. Indaryn keeps pushing me around and I'm not even doing anything wrong.
Constance!
All right. I'll take care of it. I'll handle it. No need to blow things out of proportion. Please, just let me handle it. It's not a problem. Okay, okay. I'll deal with it.
Yes, Grelod?

Samuel is getting to be a problem. Fancies himself something of a "leader" to the other children. Put an end to the nonsense, or I will. Hroar's crying is keeping me up at night. I'll give you one chance to talk the tears out of him, or he's getting the belt. I can't abide Samuel's constant talk of his parents. "They're coming for me." "This is only temporary." The boy must accept his fate. Seven septims are missing from my purse. I know it was Runa. You get those coins back, or by Stendarr, I'll see her rot in the dungeon.  This place is filthy. I've a mind to cancel all town privileges unless those brats start pulling their weight. The stores are running low. We'll need to water down the milk again. Besides, don't want the little darlings getting fat. We haven't had an adoption in months. At this rate, we'll be stuck with these brats forever. We need to get the word out. A sale, if need be.
I believe it to be a falsehood perpetrated by the Empire in order to weaken the citizen's confidence in your ability to rule.
Yes, my lady?
Excellent, then they'll be no need to devote any resources to stopping it. Thank you, Anuriel. That will be all.
It's been brought to my attention that the poison known as skooma may be present in our city. What do you know of this?
Anuriel, a word please.
Yes, milady. Sorry, milday. They will be completed.
I'm sorry, milady. The components for those elixirs are quite volatile and in some cases, very dangerous to handle. I must take care.
Why are the potions I requested not completed?
Excuses are not acceptable in my court. When I ask for something I expect results, and I expect them immediately.
Yes, my lady. I will pass the good news on to her.
But of course! Tell her she'll have it. Maven is one of the few people I can trust and I'd be delighted to give her my blessing.
My lady, Maven Black-Briar has sent word that she requires your seal in order to expand her shipments into Morrowind.
The execution will proceed as planned.
No, mother. The execution will proceed as planned.
But, mother... this is quite a sizable contribution and the crime doesn't befit such a harsh punishment.
There's still the matter of the prisoner to discuss. Now, his family is willing to contribute handsomely if we release him.
Are you going soft on me, Hemming? Perhaps I made the wrong choice installing you as steward.
What would you have me do, send him to the gallows for treason? He's your brother, Harrald.
My only concern is your safety, mother. One can only imagine the sordid types he may be conspiring with to bring about your downfall.
Mother, how long must we put up with Saerlund spouting his nonsense about the Empire?
I will hear no more of this, Harrald. Do you understand me? No more!
Yes, and I sent it with our fastest courier and under the cover of night, exactly as you specified.
Good. If I need to light a few fires in order to get what we need to defend this place from the Stormcloaks, so be it.
Hemming, have you dispatched that letter I gave you yesterday?
I'm almost certain he'll reach the Imperial City tomorrow, so we should have an answer by the end of the week.
Yes mother? What is it?
Well, make sure we keep the patrols out night and day, just to be certain.
Harrald, I have need of you.
Yes, I've heard such things. Anuriel assures me they're just fabrications and there's nothing down there save a few stray skeever.
This situation with the sewers beneath the city. I hear people have entered this place and have gone missing. Do you know of this?
Next time you speak to him, tell him to clean up his own messes. I'm not about to jeopardize this position for a bunch of low-life thugs.
Any word about our little problem in the Ratway?
I'll let him know.
I've spoken to Brynjolf and he assures me it'll be taken care of.
Come now brother, don't act all high and mighty. I know you could care less about the war one way or another.
The things you say are just an act to please mother.
Perhaps. Perhaps not.
I'm disappointed in you brother. You had it all. You had it all and your mouth cost you everything.
I see you still have the run of the place, traitor.
At least I've chosen a side instead of acting like a spectator.
One day, you'll be forced to make a choice. And I hope it's the right one, brother.
Yes, she's been grooming herself for this for quite a long time.
It's surprising the Council is allowing a Nord rule Riften under the Imperial flag. That can't be their first choice.
Your mother seems to have taken to her seat quite well.
Let's just say my mother knows which pockets to line and keep it at that.
So, is this what it's come to? You'd have your own flesh and blood hanged just to solidify your grip as the next Jarl?
What's become of us? We used to be inseparable... always fighting back to back and letting nothing stand in our way.
You've changed, brother. And not for the better I'm afraid.
I've done what I needed to do keep mother happy. It doesn't matter what I really believe.
If that's what it will take then so be it.
You've done what you've had to for yourself, not for mother.
Wise up, Harrald. There's a storm on the horizon and it will blow through here with all its fury. It's time to choose a side.
So, have you thought about what I said?
I find the concept of sleeping with you not only repulsive, but morally unsettling. Does that answer your question?
You listen to me. I'd be careful wagging that pretty little tongue at me like that otherwise I may just have it cut off.
Just stay away from me and maybe I won't weave a spell to shrink something that matters to you.
Of course. Your training isn't complete yet.
I look forward to it then.
Unmid, my sweet. Are we still meeting later for... combat training?
Maul, can I ask a personal favor of you?
Well that depends on what the favor is, now doesn't it.
It's Hemming. He's making advances and I can't bear the man's presence. Is there anything you can do?
I'll talk to him, but he's stubborn. He's like his mother; he sees what he wants and he won't quit until he has it.
Anything you can do to keep his filthy hands off of me would be a welcome change.
I would never knowingly place Laila in danger, you know that too. Why do you always question my judgment? You don't trust me.
I trust you, I'm just concerned about her safety. That's all. Don't be angry with me.
Anuriel, would you please stop declaring that the city is safe for the Jarl to roam? You and I both know that isn't true.
