I'm not angry with you. Tell you what, lover. Meet me in my chambers later and we can discuss the situation in private.
The coin isn't just for the men, there's a lot of people that need to be compensated in order to make this happen.
My agents are telling me that we've appropriated the caravan from Hammerfell... with minimal losses.
And a hefty cut for yourself too I'm sure. Just see to it the items are secured and the rest disposed of properly this time.
For what it's costing me, I should be handed the merchandise on a silver platter.
Anuriel seems to think that seeing me on the streets might bolster the city's morale.
Begging your pardon my lady, but I strongly recommend against it.
No. Of course you're right, Unmid. I'll stay here for now.
Unmid, I wish to travel about the city. Prepare an escort please.
My lady, there could be agents of the Empire looking for an opportunity like that to have you killed. Are you willing to take that risk?
I'm sorry my lady. The stresses of all this research... it's becoming more than I can bear.
How dare you take that kind of tone. You're in service to me, remember?
Very well. Keep at it. You may go.
Sorry, my lady. I've been looking but I'm convinced Saerlund says truly believes what he is saying.
You're forgiven. Now, I want to know if you've made any progress with my son. Is he cursed? Has he been possessed?
Do you realize how delicate the experiment is you've interrupted by sending for me? I may need to throw out the components and start again.
No, that won't be necessary. You'll have compensation for your loss.
Maven! Always a pleasure to receive you. What can I help you with today?
Thank you, Laila.
Yes, indeed. An entire caravan shipment of your mead taken by Imperial soldiers. What of it?
Thank you, Laila. I wanted to discuss the protection of my shipments.
I'm certain you're aware of the loss I sustained a fortnight ago.
Laila, Riften is my home, but if my meadery can't be safe here, I'll just move it elsewhere.
Quite. To be brief, I need compensation for the lost shipment. Since Riften was responsible for it, Riften should pay for it.
I have payments to make you realize. If I can't make them, I can't make Black-Briar Mead.
Well, I'm also certain you're aware that our own city guard failed to provide the protection required to ensure safe passage of the shipment.
Indeed. We lost three soldiers in that attack. A sad day for Riften.
We... don't have enough to...
Hey, you. Get over here, I want to talk to you.
I'll look around the house and if I find it, I'll bring it to you right away.
Aerin, have you seen my ring? The one with the inscription?
No, I haven't. Don't tell me you've lost it.
I hope not. That ring is irreplaceable.
I suspected as much. The real question now is do we do something about it ourselves or do we speak to the Jarl?
Well, you were right. These so called 'Gutter Saints' live in the sewers beneath.
I say we go down there and clear the place out, just like old times.
No, my friend. That would be reckless. We have to help, but help in a way that doesn't directly place anyone in harm's way.
For now, give this "Ratway" a wide berth.
What would you have me do, woman? Cross the Guild? Take them all on one by one?
Laila is as clueless as she is stupid. No. If anything's to be done about this, we have to deal with it ourselves.
You keep giving and giving Bersi, and they'll keep taking and taking. When is it going to end?
You know I don't mean that. We need to find a way out of this. Perhaps talk to Laila...
Spices? I'm certain I have no idea what you're talking about.
Oh, yes... spices. That was a special order for someone in Whiterun. Should be along any day now. Don't let it worry you, my dear.
Drifa? I was looking through our books and there's an entry for "spices." Says we spent 300 septims. What is that?
You sure? It was in your handwriting. If you can't keep the books straight then let me do them.
If I cared for your opinion on our affairs, I'd ask. Now, if you'll excuse me.
So how are things with you and Bolli?
How do you think? He's a pig. All I am to him is a warm body to lay with.
Nivenor! How can you say that? He gives you everything you ask for.
Dirge! Did you take out the trash like I asked?
Tell me you looked through the trash before you did that.
Take it easy, Vekel. How long we known each other? Yeah. I checked it. All the stuff is in the safe.
Yeah. Threw it in the lake like you said.
Yep. She said that the Jarl was planning a surprise raid on us, but she talked her out of it. Said she saved us a lot of trouble.
That she did. Very good. I'll tell Brynjolf.
Job's done, boss. Gave the package to her just you said.
Good. Did she say anything we need to know?
All right, Delvin. What gives with that case of Shadowbanish you sold me?
Sure, it tastes great. Only one problem. You said it can make the darkness as clear as day when you drink it. Guess what? It doesn't.
Am I responsible if the vintage was off on that case? Sorry, you know the rules Vekel. No refunds.
What do you mean? That wine tastes finer than anythin' Surilie Brothers ever made.
Maybe. That stuff's gettin' tough to bring across the border with all the Argonian patrols.
Puttin' together another shipment from Morrowind, Vekel. Lookin' for anythin' special?
Well if it turns up, I'll be willing to buy.
Well, if some Moon Sugar should fall into your lap...
You need to tell your boys to place nice, Delvin. Almost threw two of them into the well last night.
I'll pass it along.
They aren't my boys. Do I look like the leadin' type?
You know what I mean. Tell your boss that rough is rough, but when someone pulls a dagger fun time is over.
You did? Thanks. I get you the rest of your coin by tomorrow.
Vekel, you have no shame. I'll get you the rest like I said. I want that hammer.
Yeah, funny thing about that. The price was a hundred higher than I expected.
Good news. I found that dwarven hammer you were looking for.
If you like I'd be happy to take it over the operation for you. Take the source off your hands.
And lose out just when the going is getting good? No thanks.
I don't know where you find your sources, but that last shipment of skooma was some of the best quality I've seen in years.
I just got lucky is all. Bumped into someone who knew someone else. The rest just writes itself.
I don't want to settle. I like things the way they are.
Come on, Ton. Marry me. Let me take care of you.
I can take care of myself.
Why can't you just settle down and run the Flagon with me?
How dare you! After all we've been through together? How can you do this to me!
Look, I need to know. What's going on between you and Brynjolf?
That's all they are... rumors. So quit worrying.
Hey, hey. Sorry. I just get jealous when I hear rumors about you.
There's a new guard nosing around the meadery. Can you do something about it?
I need you to do me a favor, Dirge.
Gladly. He won't bother you anymore, I promise.
Sure, Ton. You know I'm good for it.
Come on, everyone knows about you and Brynjolf.
Well, everyone's wrong. Now why don't you just shut up about it.
Hey Ton, you shouldn't cheat on Vekel. He's a good guy.
What are you talking about?
Why don't you just formally join up? Quit sittin' here wheelin' and dealin' when you could be out there makin' a heck of a lot more coin.
We could use someone with your skills.
Tonilia, can I offer some friendly advice?
Thanks for the compliment, Delvin. I may just take you up on that one day.
You can offer, but I may not buy.
I'm going to check the entrance to the Ratway. Be right back.
Okay, okay.
You worry about bashing people's heads in, I'll worry about the Guild. Okay?
This far? We're livin' in a sewer. You said we'd have a house as big as the Black-Briars' by now.
Why are you always acting like such a big baby? I've gotten us this far.
I dunno, Drahff. They'd skin us alive if they knew we were doin' this.
Be careful, Mjoll. The Thieves Guild has Maven Black-Briar at her back.
One snap of her fingers, and you could end up in Riften Jail... or worse.
I know. I just don't want you to leave; you're the only good thing that's happened to this city in a long time.
I had another run-in with the Thieves Guild.
They represent the reason I'm here. I can't just ignore them, Aerin.
I'm really getting tired of your excuses. When you borrowed the money, you said you'd pay it back on time and for double the usual fee.
Look, Shadr. Last warning. Pay up or else. All I care about is the gold. Everything else is your problem.
What? Are you telling me you robbed it? Why? Why are you doing this to me?
Next time, keep your plans quieter and nothing would have happened to it.
I know I did. But how was I to know the shipment would get robbed?
Yes, milady. I've also taken the liberty in preparing a private carriage... just in case.
Yes, milady. That unpleasantness at Helgen supposedly involved a dragon. It killed several soldiers before it departed.
Good. If Riften should fall, it's only right that its leader be spared.
I want you to speak to the city guard. Make sure there's a contingency plan in effect in case Riften falls under attack.
Have our scouts come up with any information on these reports of dragons?
Enough, Maramal. We've all heard of the dragons and their return. There's no need to use them as an excuse to harass our customers.
Put down your flagons filled with your vile liquids and embrace the teachings of the handmaiden of Kyne.
Very well, Talen. I'll remove myself from this den of iniquity.
No, no... Maramal... we talked about this. Talen...
People of Riften, heed my words. The return of the dragons is not mere coincidence.
We're not kicking you out, just keep the sermons at the temple and let us all sin in peace.
Keerava, certainly we can come to some sort of an understanding. These people must be made aware of the chaos they've sown.
This is one of the signs. The signs that Lady Mara is displeased with your constant inebriation.
Not this again...
Hush, Vulwulf... let the boy speak.
Of course it is. That's what happens when you're partners with a corrupt Imperial whore like Maven.
Father, I promise you, this has nothing to do with Empires or politics. It's just business.
How are things at the Meadery, my dear?
It's going very well, actually. The war hasn't even slowed down our production or shipping at all.
Vulwulf! The Empire may be our enemy, but Asgeir is still our son and we're a long way from Cyrodiil.
It has everything to do with politics. Asgeir my son, you have so much to learn.
I understand. It just isn't me. I'm not a warrior and I don't think I ever will be.
Mother, what can I do to make father happier? It seems no matter how successful I become he doesn't care.
Then by Talos, you do what you feel you're meant to do. I'll take care of your father for you.
Of course he cares. You just have to understand that your father was a soldier and he'll always be a soldier.
He just wants you to follow in his footsteps.
You need to be easier on Asgeir. All he wants to do is please you.
That's right. He is your son. He has his own hopes and dreams and we have no right to tell him otherwise.
It would please me if he'd take up arms and fight for to save his homeland. Is that too much to ask my own son?
You can't deny the fact that he needs to give back to his people; to fight to keep us free.
You healed the wounded, Nura. You saw their life's blood spilling into the mud, giving back to the land.
No. I'm sorry, I've worked too damn hard to let his life go to waste.
They laughed at me again, Dinya. They simply don't understand.
Yes, yes, I know. I just wish to show them there's more to life than drowning your sorrows in a goblet of mead.
I'm so sorry my husband. You must remember, they're at the Bee and Barb to drink, not to listen to a sermon.
You're a good man, Maramal. We're lucky to have you watching over us.
It fills me with joy to hear you're with child, Dinya. They said it wouldn't... that it couldn't happen, but Mara has shown them they're mistake.
You were guided here; you were always meant to be here. That's the way of things.
Then I thank Lady Mara with all my heart; for you, for our child and for our love.
And to think I was wandering the ash wastes only two years ago. I never knew my path would lead to you.
Don't worry, I am. All right. But I am getting a bit tired of waiting. Yes, sir.

Later, little one. I need to finish what I'm working on. But keep watching. Watch, and learn. He he. Not just yet, Dorthe. I need to keep forging, and you need to keep watching. Patience, Dorthe. You'll get some time at the forge, I promise you. But not right now. You need to keep watching me. That's how you'll learn.
Can I make something now, papa? Is it time yet? Time for me to make my sword? Or maybe... an axe? I'm bored standing around, papa. I could take over for you...
Ho, now... Keep me out of this...

It's just that papa promised I could make something at the forge. So maybe we could do something together, hmmm... next week? Is... that okay? Just stop trying to change me, mother! I'm not a baby anymore! I'm almost a woman! I... I can't be who I want to be! I'm sorry, mother. I can't help it. All that stuff you like to do, it's just so... boring.
Oh. Um. Well... You see... Wow. Yeah. That sounds great, mother. Only, um... it's just that... Oooh. Ahhh... Well... See, the thing is...

Dorthe, dear, I've been growin' some really lovely vegetables. Maybe tomorrow you could help me plant a new patch? What do you say? Dorthe... I was thinkin' I'd knit a couple of blankets, sell them to Lucan. Would you like to make one? Might be fun, workin' together. You know, Dorthe, with all those vegetables I've been growing lately, I was thinkin' we could make a right lovely stew. Together. How about it?

Shor's crown! There are things ladies like us are supposed to do. We've talked about this... Let me guess. You'd rather play "Daedra and Battlemages" with Ordnar. Or go fishing, or catch frogs... Dorthe, listen to me. Your father and your friend may treat you like a boy, but you're not. Do you understand? So please. Be a girl. For me.

Fine. You play in the mud, or play with your father's forge, or get into sword fights with your little friend. But this is not over. Oh, Dorthe. You're breaking your mother's heart, you know that? Well. I can see your father and I are going to have to talk about this. And when we do, things are going to change.

Ha ha ha ha ha ha ha! That's my boy! Ha! I knew it! Had your name written all over it, that one did! See, now that's what I'm talking about. Working hard, making your mark on this world. Good job, son.
He he he he he. You just wait. My new pranks are going to the best ever! You'll see! He he he he. Ha! That ain't nothing. Wait till you see what I got planned for next week.
Sure I did. And I'd do it again. Yeah. So? Ha ha ha ha! Yeah, I sure did. It was one of my best pranks yet, father.

Hey boy, I heard you nailed a Septim into Lucan's doorstep. Damn near drove him crazy. That true? Tell me, son. Any truth to these stories I been hearing. About you gluing a cow's udders shut? You really do something like that? Heard me a rumor, boy. Something about you putting bugs in the stew over at the Sleeping Giant. You do this?
You really think I can be a blacksmith someday, papa? As good as Eorlund Gray-Mane? Or maybe... even as good as you?
He he. Thanks, papa.
Oh, I know it! You keep working hard, like you been doing, and you could be the greatest blacksmith Skyrim has ever seen.
What? What is it now, mother?
It was as big as the mountain, and black as night. It flew right over the barrow.
A dragon! I saw a dragon!
Dragons, now, is it? Please, mother. If you keep on like this everyone in town will think you're crazy.
And I've got better things to do than listen to more of your fantasies.
You'll see! It was a dragon! It'll kill us all and then you'll believe me!
Sure I am. We get some furs and tree branches, paint them white, and then tie them to Stump. Instant Frostbite Spider!
Frodnar... nobody is going to believe that your dog is a... Frostbite Spider. And if they do... they'll kill him. That's not much of a prank.
Wait, so... a costume? You're not serious...
How about... we play tag! You're it!
Hey, no fair! Get her, Stump!
Oh yeah, and what would you rather do?

Hmm. All right. Do you think... maybe we should? Well, I was thinking... we should. We could stock all kinds of specialty items. You know, to cater to some of our more.... "eclectic" customers. Hmmm... Well, maybe we could go on a sort of trip. Take the wares on the road. Get some new customers.

That's really not at the top of my list, no. Please, Camilla, I need you to focus. Dear sister, we talked about this sort of thing before. We sell dry goods, nothing more, nothing less. Camilla, really? You don't have better things to do? Because I could certainly find quite a few tasks...

Of course, Lucan. Of course. I was just, well... Never mind. Okay, okay. Just trying make this place a little less... boring. I know, I know. My head's in the clouds again. Just... forget I said anything.

Lucan, we don't sell silver buckles, do we? One of the customers was asking. We don't sell any imports from Summerset Isle, do we, Lucan? Lucan, I was thinking we should have a grand sale. Lower the prices by half, maybe get some jugglers. We could attract lots of new customers.
No, dear sister. We do not. I'm afraid not. A sale? To attract new customers? Camilla, everyone in Riverwood already shops here. There are no more customers.
Good morning, wife.
Well, I'd better get to work. I have to fix another saw blade for Gerdur's mill.
Hello, husband. You're rising late. You spent too long at the Sleeping Giant last night, didn't you? Hello, husband. You slept well?
Ah. Uh. Of course I'm not just rising. You must have been out when I woke up. Like a stone.
Take care, husband.
Are those parts ready yet?
They don't have to be perfect. Just send them over when they're ready.
I can only hammer so fast, Gerdur.
But I'm thirsty now.
Not now. If I don't pull night duty, I'll drink a round with you at the Sleeping Giant.
You're always thirsty. Just like you're always drunk. Now let me get back to my rounds.
My favorite drinking buddy! Let's get some mead.
I'll talk to Alvor about getting us a new one.
Gettin' dull. We'll need a new one soon.
And the blade?
Ay, it can. Wouldn't want them any bigger though.
Can the sawmill handle those logs? They look a might big.
Don't you sweet talk me, Alvor. Not after last night. I'll bring you water when I'm done with my other chores.
Woman, you'll be the death of me yet. Fine, take your time. I'll just die of thirst in the heat of this forge.
Sigrid! Love of my life! When you get a spare moment, I could use some water.
Dorthe won't eat that. Are you trying to starve the child?
I've got some fresh cabbage. I'm thinking of making some apple cabbage stew.
Just never you mind about that.
And speaking of spoiling Dorthe, who made her a new doll last week?
Ay, it is.  I suppose it won't hurt the girl to eat it this once.
She needs to learn to eat what I serve her. I swear, you spoil that child rotten. Besides, it's one of your favorites.
Care to have a drink with me, sweet Sigrid?
So that's a no I take it?
Drunk again, Embry? Don't let Alvor hear you talking to me that way. He'll stick your head in his forge.
She'll make a fine wife someday.
Aye. She's helping me in the house, and even helps her father at the forge.
Thank Shor I have a lot of years before I have to worry about that!
It seems like Dorthe grows a head taller every season.
Not this again.
If he does, tell him how bad the food is. And how dangerous it is.
Look old woman. If your boy wants to learn how to fight, we'll teach him. Now off with you.
Has my son Sven asked to join the war?
Gimme a mug of ale. A pint of your finest mead. Some wine, please? I'll have some mead. Pour me an ale.
Coming right up. Certainly.
And... you'll take care of it? Wait, let me guess. You'll get to it later.
Don't I always?

The corn stores are getting low again, Orgnar. You promised me you'd sweep the entranceway. I still need you to make a batch of those fried potatoes. We can serve them with the ale. You are going to brew a new batch of ale, right? Like we talked about? What we have's been sitting in that barrel for over a month.
I don't suppose I could convince you to take care of it now, could I?
Well. There's something to be said for honesty, I suppose. I should have guessed.
Yep.
No.
Here we go...
You do realize these simpletons wouldn't know real music if it bit them in the britches, hmm? Very well. Your wish is my command.
It's about your singing. Well, not your singing, your songs. But you know what I'm talking about.
Sven, we need to talk...
Wonderful. And let's not have this chat again next week. Agreed?
Stay away from Camilla.
Just stay away from her, or...or else.
Ah, Camilla. Fair as the morning sun. But I ask you, how could she prefer your brooding to my romantic tunes?
You play so well.
Oh, Sven. You do know how to turn a girl's head.
With you as my muse, how could I not?
You need to choose between those two boys. It ain't fair to Sven or Faendal to keep tuggin' on their heart strings like that.
It's bad enough my brother is harping on me to pick one. Don't you start too.
I'm just sayin' you should pick one to settle down with.
A hard truth, that is. Let's drink to the fallen ones.
Ay, we can get that for ya. We just finished the timber for those catapults.
I got a new order in for shields. I'm gonna need some hardwood planks. None of that soft pine this time.
War may be good for business, but it's hard on families.
You come do an honest day's work at my mill, and I'll pay you an honest day's wages. Then we'll drink.
It's only right seein' as your the important lumber man.
You'll be wantin' me to pay for them?
How's about a drink, Hod.
Until then, I've no ale for you.
I'll find some coin for you. I always do.
You've had more than enough. Besides, you still haven't paid for the last one.
I need some more ale, Orgnar.
I guess you don't have potatoes in your ears after all. Just make sure we get a fresh batch in soon.
Yep. Ale's going bad.
Did you hear me?
The ale is going bad. We need to get a new batch.
Hard not to.
Orgnar.
Orgnar!
Are you listening?
I told you to weed the garden by sunset, and you didn't do it. Now you're in big trouble!
You're going to get it, Sissel!
Why? What did I do?
Papa told you to do that, not me! Now leave me alone!
Come on now, we discussed that. I wouldn't be traveling all of Skyrim. It'd just to Whiterun and back, that's it.
Have you given my idea any more thought? You said you'd let me know yesterday, and that obviously didn't happen.
Oh, I don't know. Yes, we'd make more money, but I don't like the idea of you traveling alone out there with the war and talk of dragons.
Tomorrow. I'll let you know tomorrow.
Jouane?
Yes, child?
By the Eight, keep your voice down! Do you want the entire village to learn our secrets?
Shh shh. It's fine, child. It's fine. But we must be cautious, hmm? What we do, the things I teach you. The others wouldn't understand.
Hmph. Most certainly not. But perhaps I can teach you how to put some candles out. We'll start there.
I was just wondering. The next time we meet, do you think maybe you could teach me some fire magic? Nothing dangerous! Maybe a candle lighting spell?
I understand. I'm sorry. I just get so excited thinking about it. So... can we. Do some fire magic?
Oooh, wonderful! I can't wait!
Oh! I'm... I'm sorry. I didn't mean to upset you.
Can you believe we're here? Saarthal, of all places.
I'm surprised that the College is allowed to excavate here.
I bet your family would be amazed, right?
Amazed isn't the right word. They might find this... offensive.
Don't get any ideas. We're here on official business, remember?
I'm betting bodies. Lots and lots of bodies. And maybe some valuables...
It's thousands of years old. Who knows what we might find?
What do you think we'll find in there?
Are you excited to see what's in there? This is important to you Nords, isn't it?
I think, given the state of Skyrim, some might disagree.
Not excited, no. Some very bad things happened here.
Oh, right. That whole thing with the elves. Well, it all worked out in the end, didn't it?
That doesn't begin to describe it.
I just don't know that it's right for us to be in here like this, picking through the ruins .
This is a little creepy.
You seem uncomfortable being here.
Like anyone would even notice, in all this mess.
There's no gold, nothing shiny at all.
I'm not sure what I was expecting, but this isn't it.
Don't sound so disappointed. You wouldn't be allowed to take it even if there was.
How do you think the crops are coming, dear?
Terrible. Only a matter of time before soldiers come and burn all my hard work into dust!
Look at the sky. Be a terrible day tomorrow. I know it.
Yes it can. I haven't been wrong in 50 years, and I won't be wrong tomorrow.
Oh, Rogatus! Maybe tomorrow will be pleasant for once, hmm? It can't be terrible every day!
You want me to smile? What's there to smile about? Soldiers and dragons are going to be trampling all over the crops this year. I just know it.
Oh, stop being such a grouch! Not every visitor to the farm wants to burn it down! Maybe they just want to have a nice supper with us, hmm?
Oh, wipe that frown off your face Rogatus. You've been wearing that frown for over 50 years now.
You don't invite monsters into your home to have supper! I won't have them here, and I'm certainly not smiling for them!
No. I have enough trouble without more mouths to feed! They're the Jarl's men, they can eat supper at the keep.
Maybe we could invite some of those nice guards over. You know, for some supper?
Boring? That food is paying for everything. If we lose even a single crop, we could starve or be forced to beg. I won't have it!
All right, I understand. I'll do it tomorrow, okay? Just get off my back.
Aduri, how come the fields haven't been tilled like I asked?
Because it's boring. The fields are going to do fine... you don't have to dote over them so much.
Painting won't put food on the table, but our crops will. Be patient Aduri... it will happen someday, I promise.
I'm sorry, Aduri, not this year. Perhaps next year after the harvest, I don't know. There's so much to do.
It's not going to be next year, nor the year after that! You just care about this farm more than you care about me!
Have you decided if I can head up to Solitude yet? I hear it's the best place to meet someone who may be willing to teach me to paint.
One day, these beautiful plants will make us famous and we can finally move off of this farm... thanks to Sinderion.
They're beautiful. I can see why he wanted to find them.
Remember Uncle Sinderion? These are the plants he was searching for... the Crimson Nirnroot.
Where did all these pretty red plants come from?
You two will just have to learn to get along until we can build you another house.
Quit your bellyaching. We've all got our problems.
You think living with Grogmar is easy? Did you see how he lives?
At this rate that'll never happen.
What makes you so sure? What if I'm right?
I know there's ore still in there, I can smell it. If you think you're right then you can pack up and leave any time you like.
And I'm telling you, you're wrong.
I've been cracking rock ever since I was able to hold a pickaxe and I'm telling you, this mine is drying up.
It's no feast in their neck of the woods either. Last time I was up there, father said they were barely scraping by.
This civil war is taking its toll on all of us. Miners are some of the hardest hit.
How are your parents faring, Grelka? Doing better than we are I would guess.
That's what scares me. I'm afraid I'll travel to Darkwater Crossing and find it burned to the ground.
I'll have you know I can haul up just as much iron as you in a day and still manage to clean up my messes.
All I'm asking is that you clean up once in a while. How you can find anything in your half of the place is beyond me.
You think so, huh? Maybe you'd like to put some septims behind that boast.
I'd rather spend more time in the mine hauling up iron then doing woman's work keeping the house clean.
You have yourself a bet.
I need someone that cares about me more than they care about themselves. That person isn't you.
Grelka, do you fancy a walk tomorrow?
Odfel, I've told you time and time again. I'm not interested in a relationship with you.
And why not? I'm handsome, strong and smart. What else could you possibly need?
I've been watching the way you mine and I have to say, I'm very impressed.
I owe it all to my father who started me swinging the pickaxe when I was a barefoot little girl.
Well, it shows. Your skill rivals some of the greatest miners I've known.
Thank you. It's nice to know someone admires me for more than just my appearance.
Nonsense. Is a child who learns to read "not a scholar" of literature? Is a smith's apprentice "not a scholar" of blacksmithing?
The architecture of this temple is marvelous. Have you ever seen stonework like this, Delphine?
I'm not a scholar, Esbern. How many times do I have to tell you?
Well, I'm "not a scholar" of architecture. And that's that.
The other Blades? No. Best not to think what the Thalmor do to their victims, my dear.
Do you ever think about them, Esbern? The others?
You're right. Sorry to bring it up.
There's a difference?
I've been writing some notes about all the Akaviri designs we've discovered. If only the Imperial Library could see my research.
Now, now my dear. I'm talking about academia, not politics.
Esbern, if the Empire could even acknowledge the Blades existence, we'd all have reason to celebrate.
Come now. You did more than just survive all those years. Your evasion of the Thalmor would be useful for future Blades to study.
"I survived"?
What? Your heroic tale of locking yourself in the Ratway for years isn't enough?
I've been chronicling the recent history of the Blades. What would you like your entry to say?
It will have to do. Besides, if it came to blows, I'm sure the Snow-Shod's would come out here and assist us.
Just worry about keeping the fields tended and let the Jarl worry about the war.
I suppose so. I just fear they won't make it out here in time.
I'm not so sure the few guards they've assigned to the farm are enough.
My sweet Leanora, I will never let anything happen to us. I promise.
It brings me joy to hear that, but what possessed you to say that so suddenly?
My darling, you've made me the happiest woman in all Skyrim.
I've already lost a family, and we're about to start a new one. I don't want that to happen again.
Maybe we'll have better luck tomorrow.
We'll make it, Greta. We always have so far...
It's all we've got for today. Don't be greedy.
Fish? Again? Potatoes? Again?
Eat up, Svari.
Svari, Jala said you stole an apple from her cart yesterday. Is this true?
Yes, papa.
I suppose. But Svari, we don't steal. We're better than that. Understand?
I'll talk with Jala, dear. I'm sure she'll accept a potato as repayment.
Just a little one! I was hungry!

You there. Have you performed your voice exercises today? Your solo performance is about a week away. I expect to hear your early rendition tomorrow, understand? Pardon me, but I trust you've been working on your poem, on the classical heroes of Skyrim, yes?

Yes, well, see that you keep at it. That is all. I'll be the judge of that. Now, back to your practice. Patience, Illdi. We study the heroes of the past so we can have better understanding of the heroes of today... and tomorrow. I'm sure it will be fine. Just don't be late.

Yes, Lady Ateia. My voice is strong as a Dragonborn's! Always! Perfection takes dedication, after all! Yes, madam. I know I have a lot to work on. I've converted the classic tale of Eyldi the Bear to be performed with drums. I think you'll be impressed! At this point, I hardly see how your advice would improve it. It's flawless. Oh, thank you! I've been working on an original piece. I hope it can stand up to the classics! Yes sir, Professor Gemane! It's a war epic about Hoag Merkiller's last stand! Must it be written? Poetry is so dull when it isn't set to music. Why do we always focus on retelling the old stories? There are so many new stories being made, right now...

Passably. Aia is my star pupil. None of the others can hold a candle to her. Especially not that wretched llldi. Some of them have a long way to go, but they're mostly passable. Don't let them hear I said that, though! Bunch of distractions, if you ask me. They just interrupt the rest of my work.
Yes, headmaster.

Try not to play favorites, Lady Ateia. It does a disservice to the whole class. Of course not! Complacency is the bane of art. They're in good hands with you, Inge. I'm sorry to break it to you, Giraud, but students are an unfortunate necessity of a college. Do try to persevere.
How are your students coming along?
What're you going to do after you graduate? I'm thinking of joining the Legion. I hear they're looking for skalds. Just think. Me - a war bard.
Lady Ateia has already arranged for me to perform in the court of the Jarl of Falkreath.
You'd better hope the war's over by then. The Stormcloaks would eat you alive!
Hmph. Music tames the most savage beasts. Even Nords.
I think someone has a crush on Illdi.
I think Illdi's better than Dean Pantea actually knows. She just gets intimidated when she's in class and can't sing.
Have it your way, then.
Aia. You're so mean. I don't think he means anything by it.
You should tell him to mind his own business.
Ataf keeps making eyes at me.
Yes, Dean. Thank you.
Your performance has been excellent lately Aia. You still need training but one day you will make an adequate singer.
Ummm, Morrowind suffered a massive explosion...
Vvardenfell's Red Mountain erupts. Try to be precise, Jorn.
Late One-seventy-one.
Illdi. What year did the Aldmeri Dominion invade the Empire?
Remember, being a bard isn't just about the music.
Good, Illdi. Soak in the lore. Jorn, what happened during the Red Year?
Even while making parts up.
Read carefully. You will see there are ways to stay true to the essence, Illdi.
Can we really just make things up? It doesn't seem right.
Seems like most of these are nine parts fiction.
A good story is nine parts truth and one part fiction.
Be sure to watch your finger positions. Especially during the transitions.
Very good. Let's continue with our practice.
Ataf, please play back that piece for me.
Let's try a lute piece. Follow along...
Very good, Aia. Class, observe her finger movements. Let's try a few more pieces.
Yes, Dean Inge.
Now, you try it Aia
Go ahead, Ataf.
Remember, it's your job to "deliver" these songs. To excite the crowd. Draw them in and they will love you for it.
That was better Ataf. Add a bit of emphasis on "Ragnar" and "Red."
All right, let's try something a bit more... fun.
You see, all you need is a bit of spirit and any song can be made into a classic.
That's all for today. You're dismissed.
This time let's try "The Age of Aggression". I will demonstrate for the class. This time let's try "The Age of Oppression". I will demonstrate for the class.
Not that I mind the break, of course. But, still... I suppose in wartime, people aren't looking to part with their old junk...

It's okay, dear. More work than ever down at the blacksmith. We'll make it through, dear. We always do. Who needs customers and their old junk? Father oughtta punch them in the mouth! That'd get people in here!
Sure has been quiet around the shop lately. We hardly ever get new customers anymore.
If you give me a list, I'll have them delivered to the dock by tomorrow morning.
I need some things for the ship.
Come on, Heimvar. My son could stoke the forge better than you do! You're making progress, Heimvar. But my boy could still work the bellows better than you do!
Yeah, but can he hammer the anvil for 8 hours straight? Sure, but I bet he can't hold his mead as well as me!
Give him time. In a couple years, he'll be the age you were when you started! Right you are! Guess I'll keep training you... for now.
Really? How did we afford that? Besides, I like the gown I already have.
Madame Endarie insisted. She made it free of charge, in honor of your lenience about last month's rent discrepancies.
That was suspiciously nice of her. I thought she hated everyone.
My lady, I'm pleased to inform you that you have a new gown for court, specially tailored by madame Endarie.
She does, my lady. But apparently, she hates you just a little less than the others.
What news have you heard from the war, Irnskar?
I'm not just talking about my subjects. I'm talking about my people: the proud Nords of Skyrim.
You won't like it, my lady.
I told you you wouldn't like the news.
I'm well aware that I won't like it. But it's my duty to keep my people safe. Tell me.
Possession of the holds change on an almost daily basis, but I can report that Haafingar is still secure. Your people are safe.
You're right, of course. But when this war is over, I'll gladly resign and we can stop sneaking around like this.

I'm serious. If Erikur knew about us, he'd force you to resign from your position. And without you, he'd have the Jarl bent around his little finger. I'm serious. If Erikur knew about us, he'd force you to resign from your position. And without you helping the Jarl, Solitude would be weaker.
Falk, you shouldn't have come. You know what'd happen if people found out about us.
One more reason to pray for the fighting to end then, my love.
I know, my lady. I just needed to see you outside of court, away from all of the politics.
Sir, we can't just keep trading blows with the rebels like this - it's only strengthening their resolve.
Don't you think I know that? But these commands come straight from Cyrodiil.
We must maintain order and put the rebellious Jarls in their place, before we have a full scale war on our hands.
Sir, this is costing lives of both imperial loyalists and Skyrim citizens alike. And it's winning the rebels support where they had none before.
Your concerns are duly noted, Legate, but unfounded. I assure you, this war will be over in another six months.
Sir.
Thank you, Legate. In the future, I'll let you know when your opinion is needed.
You don't think this is a war already? Sir, I...
New orders for the soldiers, Legate. Make sure they're distributed as noted.
Understood, sir.
That is correct. Those orders have been delivered by special courier. I can't trust some of our normal distribution channels.
Sir, these are missing commands for about half of the commanders.
Big shipment coming in later tonight. I need you three working late.
Yeah, we'll get the valuables out of there, no problem!
Oh, we'll make sure it's emptied out by morning. You can trust us!
Patience, sister. Patience.
I know of a ship coming in from Hammerfell. Some cargo might get "lost"...
My contact, she says Hammerfell steel is much desired by certain parties.
Why should we settle for half a fin when we could just take the whole whale?
Shoo! Go away! You get nothing from me. You bother me again, maybe you will not walk away. Understand? Sorry, I have everyone I need at the warehouse. Times are tight.
Got any work? I ain't begging. I just need a job. Anything.
I'm afraid "acceptable" just isn't acceptable anymore. I'm sure they can spare a few more coins in monthly rent.
Yes, brother. I'm sure they'll agree it's a fair price to pay in order to avoid interacting with you on a daily basis.
Sister, how is my fortune coming along?
Fair or not, they'll pay it, and that's all I need to care about. Bear that in mind, sister.
Profits continue to rise. The warehouse continues to bring in good revenues, and rent on your stores in the Well is acceptable.
I can commission one from the Radiant Raiment. It won't be cheap, but if you want the best, they're the only choice.
I swear, those scheming elves charge us twice what anyone else would pay.
Of course they do, brother. You keep raising their rent.
That clumsy maid at the palace spilled wine on my best suit. Sister, I believe it's time for a replacement.
Indeed I have, sir. Elven weapons for their armies, sir. Elven material, but poor workmanship, like most of what we get from them.
As always, lord, your loyalty is a shining example to us all.
Scary, thinking of those boots with an army of Elven weapons at their command. Let's be thankful they're half a world away, eh?
Even a fine weapon is only as good as its wielder, sir. But they should fetch a high price from the Imperial army.
Melaran, you lazy milk drinker, have you finished studying the imports from Black Marsh?
Right you are, elf! Or even from the rebels, if they've got enough money to make a competitive offer.
Slow, but looking good, sir.
Slow's the only way to do it! Work too hard and you'll warp the wood.
How's it coming there, Jawanan?
Fihada, where did you learn how to make bows so well?
You'd make a better Imperial ranger than me. I may have charmed the locals, but my fellow soldiers hated my waggling tongue.
Wish I could learn some of that charm. I'm just good with bows, not people.
The same place I learned my charm and quick wits: I used to be an Imperial ranger, my boy!
Rest up, scum. Probably getting executed tomorrow.
Come now. You'll want to show up in Sovngarde refreshed. You got an eternity of merrimakin' ahead of you. Guess the headsman's been busy with all your friends. Ha ha ha ha ha!
Yeah, you said that yesterday.
I mean, the Redguards fought off the Aldmeri and the Empire, and now Hammerfell is an independent state. That's all we Nords want for Skyrim!
They aren't my "people." I'm with the Empire because they pay me. And that means I'm out here, and you're in there. So shut up, scum!
Shut up, scum.
Hey, jailor! What I don't understand is why you're siding with the Imperials.
I said shut up, scum!
So it's okay if your people rebel against the Empire, but not mine?
It's too cold for my bones, but that never seems to stop you, dear.
Another gorgeous gray day, right dear?
I'll see if I can't get some work done inside, where it's warm.
I'm gonna go play soldier with a tree!
That's nice, son. Just don't stomp on the crop like last time!
As long as they're playing instruments they're passable. You don't want to hear them sing.
Speaking of sounding good, I've heard a couple of your classmates on the street recently.
Salmon sounds good today.
Thanks, Aia. That means a lot. Glad to hear it, Aia.
None of what he collected tasted as good as your Spiced Wine, Evette. I'm still finding your Spiced Wine to be the best drink I've ever tasted.
Rum from Hammerfell, mulled wine from Daggerfall and the like.
Really?
You know, my father collected exotic alcohols.
Vegetables are the food of the Divines.
There's nothing quite like a good vegetable.
I've heard stanger things, are eaten over at the Temple of the Divines.
Naw, mostly just froze.
Brave man, with the Blackbloods out there. Did you catch anything?
I went out ice fishing a few days ago.
Well, keep at it. The fish have to get to know you before they're willing to bite.
I'll take a bottle of spiced wine.

Viarmo is trying to get Elisif to allow the Burning of King Olaf. I don't want to look like I don't know how to drink in front of the other bards. No thank you. I'm still feeling sick from the festival.
I haven't known you to drink before, Ataf. A bottle of spiced wine for ya, Ataf?
My mother always used to say that too.
Fine, Ataf. You should eat some more tomatoes, though.
Um, excuse me. Could I buy two leeks.
Greta is taking it hardest. She won't go to the Temple of Divines anymore.
I'm sorry about Roggvir. It's a shame, I liked him.
Do you know I look forward to Burning of King Olaf each year just because of the fire?
A bit of warming wine, Illdi. You know you can't resist.
Not fair. You're well aware I can't seem to get warm here.
You don't need my fruit, I've heard when you sing people throw tomatoes at you anyway.
How about I trade you a song for some fruit?
A war veteran should be respected.
A sale's a sale but I have to know... why are you buying something for Noster?
I am buying a fish for Noster. He likes fish.
Okay. Well. That's all I've got.
I do not like fish.
Jawanan, I don't see you here often.
I think I may wait until the Burning of King Olaf to have and Spiced Wine.
You and everyone else. Word is it may not happen this year though.
It's those damned Blackblood Marauders. They're scaring off shipping. One apple. Since the Blackbloods were dispatched I've had good luck getting shipments.
Your fruit are looking a little less ripe today. Your selection looks very delicious. I'll take an apple.
I appreciate the thought though.
I don't think he would have wanted your absolution, Rorlund. He worshiped Talos.
I wish we could have absolved your brother-in-law of his sins before his execution.
Plenty of ways to worship the Divines as you know.
Of course. And I'm sure it's mostly for ceremonial purposes.
Ah a few bottles of Spiced Wine should hit the spot.
Perhaps if I were a little more blessed I could afford to give away my fruit. As is you'll have to pay, Rorlund.
Perhaps you could spare a tomato for a priest of the Divines?
Thank you, Addvar, I am picky about what I eat these days.
I've been pushing the Salmon but I'll tell you the Slaughterfish is a bit better today.
Fresh fish sounds like just the thing today, Addvar.
Vittoria is practically glowing.
It should be quite the affair. Nice to have something happy in the midst of the war.
Not too bad. A few of the guests from the upcoming wedding have placed orders. They seem to when you're around Silana.
Are your sales going well? I hope the Divines have been keeping you well.
Free of charge for you.
Hello, Silana. Would you like an apple?
That's generous, Jala, but I am happy to pay my way.
I seem to have more chores for the Winking Skeever each day. I still have a delivery to do too.
A little late in the day for your rounds Sorex.
The last one was warm up.
Sure, Sorex. Just like you did the last one.
Actually just a bottle for me today. I'm thinking of giving it to Vivienne.
Spiced Wine for the Winking Skeever?
You never can tell.
The guy in from Dragon Bridge? He didn't seem the type.
I'll need a whole crate of fruit. That Varnius Junius went through quite a few of our supplies.
As you know, Solitude's coffers are much depleted by the war efforts. Thane Erikur, you have a strong head for business. What do you suggest?
Simple. Let the Empire fight its own war, with its own funds, and without hijacking our supplies and soldiers. Let Haafingar rebuild.
This is an unfortunate but unavoidable ebb in revenue. But as long as we continue to support the Empire, our sacrifices will be well rewarded.
My lady... Surely you're not that naive. Such foolishness would only leave us defenseless. The rebels would storm the palace in an afternoon.
Listen to you, speaking of sacrifice. You've never gone hungry a day in your life, Erikur!
The Stormcloaks only rebel because the Empire uses Skyrim as its personal larder. The more they take, the more support the rebels gain!
And what would my impetuous Thane Bryling suggest, instead?
That is quite enough. Perhaps I will raise these issues when I have an audience with General Tullius.
It comforts me to know that, Bolgeir.
No disrespect toward the general, but sometimes I wonder if he's got your best interests at heart.
In any case he won't be turnin' me into no Imperial soldier. I know my place, and it's at your side.
I'm aware of that, Bolgeir, and I appreciate your dedication.
However, if we lose the war, the guardsmen of Solitude will make little difference in the end.
Told you that, did he?
I'm sworn to protect you, my Jarl, but I'm the last line of defense.
The first line is the walls around this city and the men who patrol them.
Men who, I might add, we're precious short on.
Yes, I know. The general acted with my blessing.
It is vital that we bring Ulfric to justice, but that cannot happen until his army of Stormcloaks is defeated utterly.
We lost another five guardsmen, my Jarl.
If General Tullius continues to conscript our men and send them off to battle, we'll have none left to protect the city.
My dear Bryling. Barring any... fancy and folly... the good people of Haafingar are surely capable of dealing with the odd highwayman or stray dog.
Thane Bryling, what do you have to report about the state of Haafingar's defenses?
Trouble on the roads and cities means less commerce. Less commerce means less money and more starving people. And that means more crime.
The news is the same as it's been for the rest of the war, your grace. Our borders are secure, but at the cost of the guards for our towns and roads.
Humph. That's only a problem for people who can't afford to hire their own security.
I don't see any reason why we'd need them. As long as those dogs stay outside of our borders, we're fine.
That may well be our only answer. I will empower my Steward to seek out capable individuals to secure Haafingar. Thank you, my Thanes.
The Stormcloaks are far from the only threat to the hold. The roads are beset by bandits and beasts... and now there's even talk of bloody dragons.
Steward, when is my appointment to meet with General Tullius? There are some issues we must speak about.
He uses all of Haafingar's resources, and doesn't answer to me in the slightest? This hardly seems fair.
I'm afraid he's had to reschedule, my grace. By all accounts, waging war takes his every moment.
"Fair" is a word rarely applied to politics, my grace. I'm afraid you must learn to accept this.
Again? He can't simply cancel an appointment with the Jarl! He serves in my capital city!
I'm afraid he can. His authority comes from the emperor. Who you also serve, technically.
Miss Stentor, watch your tongue in the Jarl's court!
Yes, and I'm also aware of how necessary my divinations and wards have been in the city's defense. My experiments are all I ask for in return.
On threat of what, exactly? This city wouldn't run without me! Now if you'll excuse me, my work awaits.
Very well. But I suspect her grace will not be pleased.
Steward, I will need the following reagents for my studies. Please see to them.
And? I've seen jarls come and go. This one only became Jarl because her husband died. She'll be replaced in a matter of months.
Miss Stentor, these are quite expensive. I trust you know how limited the hold's funds are at this time?
The Jarl would be wise to remember that it is her thanes - and my profits - that are paying for this war.
We know full well about your investment in shipping ventures, Erikur.
I've also heard troubling rumors about dealings between you and the crew of that pirate ship, the Red Wave.
Thankfully, Jarl Elisif cares far less about your lost profits than she does about winning the war!
Then let's increase the taxes on the farms and merchants. We can't afford to lose the loyalty of the ship captains.
General Tullius needs more money for the war effort. We need the funds to arm and provision more troops.
I've heard the Empire plans to levy a tax on our trading ships. Falk, you've got to do something about this.
You know that I support the Empire, as we all do. However, I fear General Tullius is underestimating the Stormcloaks.
Too often the general has lost good soldiers because he did not take Ulfric and his men seriously.
If this continues, and the worst comes to pass, Solitude will pay the price. The Empire is headquartered here, after all.
Speak your mind, Bryling. You're among friends here.
There's something that's been troubling me, Falk. I am hesitant to share it, but I feel that I must.
Have faith, Bryling. When this war is over and Ulfric is dead, you'll see that you were jumping at shadows, and nothing more.
Yes, of course, but Ulfric's message is a powerful one. More of our people flock to his cause every day.
We don't have the luxury of hanging back to see who wins before choosing our friends, Bryling. You know this.
And besides, no Nord with a shred of honor would consider it. We're no cowards.
Oh, I'm sorry, did I imply that you'd be meeting for purposes other than court business? You must forgive me.
I beg your pardon?
Oh, well done. Very subtle.
Is it that time again already?
Very well, let's meet this evening and make the arrangements.
It's nearly time to collect taxes on your properties here in the city, Bryling.
We'll need to visit each home for an assessment.
Stop it, both of you. You're acting like children.
I should very much like to see you try it, my dear steward.
Hold your tongue, Wizard, or you're likely to lose it.
A wise course of action, my Jarl. However, we have little food or water to spare.
Steward Falk, I have a task for you.
I want to begin stockpiling food and water in the event we come under siege, and I would like you to oversee this work personally.
I will make the arrangements, my Jarl.
There's no need for an apology, and you're right about the war.
Perhaps this is a matter best discussed with with the general in person.
My apologies, Jarl Elisif. I was thinking only of the importance of the war effort.
General Tullius does not run this city, Thane Erikur. Or have you forgotten your oaths of fealty?
General Tullius will never allow that. He's ordered all surplus food to be given over for the war effort.
Oh, very well. I can see there's no changing your stubborn Nord minds.
But when this war is won, I will have my parade!
I must protest, my Jarl.
A parade would make you an easy target for a Stormcloak assassin. You're safer here in the palace.
What a... fine idea, my Jarl. However, I would suggest we wait until the war has ended.
After all, the General needs his soldiers out in the field, fighting battles against the Stormcloaks.
Steward, I have an idea that might help to bolster the morale of our people in this difficult time.
I think we shall have a grand parade, and let General Tullius march his troops from the Blue Palace to Castle Dour in all their finery.
Yes, my Jarl.
You should be more careful about the women you spend time with in port. Come back later and it will be ready.
Can you make some new poultices for my...you know?
Back so soon Xander?
I doubt it can be repaired. You'll have to buy a new one.
My tunic is fading. Too much sun and salt spray.
Oh certainly, dear sister. We couldn't afford to have our customers look like the simple pigs they are, now could we?
Sister dear, could you try sewing those sleeves a little tighter? We can't have our customers looking sloppy because of your work.
Good. And while you're at it, perhaps you should sew your mouth shut when our fine customers are within earshot, hrm?
Humph. Some daughter you are.
I barely make enough for us to eat as it is, father. You can't just drink it all away.
Well, did you bring back any mead?
Where've you been all day?
At the market, father.
Sure, whatever.
I'm on my feet all day. Can you please do this one thing for me?
Maybe. I'll see if I feel like it.
Father, could you clean up the house a little while I'm away?
Kharag, take a break and drink with me! Those trees aren't going anywhere! Why so glum, my ugly friend? Did we run out of mead?
Hjorunn, the last time you tried anything, your fist broke on my head! Just as long as you don't breathe on me, Hjorunn. I'll be out for hours.
I have to work twice as hard because you drink up all our profits. Can you pay attention to work for once, instead of your mug?
Guess we can't afford to miss that much work, can we? Oh well... True enough, you cur. Back to work, I suppose...
What did you say? I ought to break off one of those tusks and use it as my drinking horn! Don't make me to defend the honor of my mead! It's been my friend a lot longer than you have!
You don't put up with a man like that. He puts up with you.
I once saw Fihada put an arrow in between the eyes of a Blackblood Marauder at five hundred paces.
How do you put up with that fop Fihada?
I've tasted your food, Odar. It's better than most songs I've heard.
Sometimes I like to think my cooking is like playing the flute or singing a song.
I don't think that was a compliment.
You like everyone Jorn. You'll make a good court bard some day.
I like you Una. You've got presence.
I'm pleased when the palace is clean, I'm pleased when the beds are made on time, I'm pleased when I Erdi isn't around.
Your a hard woman to please Una.
I keep coming out here thinking I'll see what others see in this... frivolity.
Most of those don't happen very often.
Not in our nature.
You Bards don't cut each other any slack do you?
Speaking of harsh.
He's okay. A little breathy and a little harsh on the notes. She's okay. A little breathy and a little harsh on the notes.
I could listen to him play all day. I could listen to her play all day.
Absolutely not. I prefer to be near enough to come visit but free to come and go as I please.
Do you miss your days training at the College?
It is a shame though.

It's too bad the Burning of King Olaf was called off this year. I think some of the younger bards would really have gotten a kick out of it. I think our flutist here has gotten better since the Burning of King Olaf.
Well, you can understand Elisif not wanting it. I'm so glad we got to have it. I thought for sure Elisif would never consent.
Nonsense, dear. I've had more visitors than ever seeking the wisdom of the hearth goddesses.
I fear attendance is down. There are so few worshippers coming to see us. Could it be that the war has weakened their faith?
What troubles you, darling?
A word, my love?
Ah, that must be it. So many of the men are serving in battle. I shall pray to Stendarr that they return victorious.
Your compassion is admirable, but you see, we cannot help them all. The poor must learn from the examples of the gods and raise themselves up.
Oh, yes sir. I feel many of Solitude's families are having trouble getting by, and the wealthy do nothing to help them!
Silana, you don't seem yourself. Is something the matter?
I see you have meditated on this subject quite thoroughly. I shall not stop you, but please, try to attend to your temple duties as well.
I respectfully disagree, sir. Stendarr and Zenithar may demand strength from them, but Mara and Dibella demand compassion from us.
What could be more important than hearing the prayers of the faithful, and answering the questions of the dedicated?
Kynareth has blessed you with tremendous compassion, Silana. You will find a way, I'm sure of it.
Mistress, a word?
Mistress, the people of Solitude are destitute. Many are starving and desperate for work. We need to be more active, to reach out to them.
Certainly, acolyte. What troubles you?
We took you in, didn't we? We would be glad to extend our welcome to any other who showed your dedication. What more could we do?
I know you and father Rorlund have many duties to attend to in the temple, but sometimes I feel that there are more important matters to attend to.
I know, and I appreciate it dearly. But I can't help but feel we could be doing more...
Tag! You're it! I'm bored! Let's play a game!
Can't catch me! Aww, I'm hungry! Can we get some food, instead?
I'm not playing with you, Kayd! You play mean! Father says I shouldn't play with you anymore.
Alms? Alms for a veteran? Spare a bite for a poor old veteran? Please, ma'am, I've got nowhere to go... I lost my eye defending the Empire... Spare some grub for a veteran?
I'm sorry... We barely have enough for ourselves... Here, it's all I can spare...
Which one is that again?
Vivienne, could you check out supplies of mandrake root?
In that case, I'm pretty sure it tried to buy me a drink last night.
It's the root that looks like an ugly little man.
Bring up some more mead, my boy. This cask's nearly tapped!
Yes, father. Which cask should we open?
Just bring any of them, lad! Can't risk thirsty customers without mead to drink, even for a second! Any of them! Just hurry up! No time for a debate when customers are thirsty!
Yes, yes, fine. Just hurry! Mustn't keep the customers thirsty!
Good idea, sis. Maybe you ought to be in charge!

Bring the Blackbriar 195 Berry-Blend. It should be at its peak right now, and if it doesn't get served soon, it'll only go bad. We just got a cask of Old Gold 200 that has a crack in it. Better serve it now before it goes bad. Fat Toad 190 is always a crowd-pleaser. Father could probably charge extra.
It's been a good week, my boy! Loud customers mean good cheer, and good cheer means a full till!
You know, I ought to retire and leave you to run the Skeever, son!
Oh, brother... Hah!
I could run the Skeever! You even said I'm almost as smart as you! Why not let me run the Skeever? I already know lots about it!
What about "Auntie Faida" in Dragon Bridge? She runs a bar, and you said she's one of your favorite girls! But you always say you want more girls in the bar to begin with!
That's it! I'm not retiring, ever! End of discussion! Well, you see, that's a little complicated, and... you know what? Never mind. Guess I'm not retiring anytime soon.
Don't be a silly girl! Running a bar's no job for a young lady. Hah! A girl running a bar? Don't be ridiculous, Minette!
I don't know, father... There's a whole world out there I want to see. You'd just spend your time here, bossing me around and yelling for more drinks. You're practically retired already...
Free mead!
Hooray!
A round for all of my friends! Another round, on me!
You heard the man! Drink and be merry! Let's hear it for our kind benefactor!
Can I buy you a drink, darling? So, um, mind if I buy you a drink? This drink's on me.

Not if you were the last man in the Empire. Oh, if you insist! You can buy me whatever you want! Aw, that's so sweet of you! Thanks! Being friends with the bartender's son has its advantages, huh? Oh, yes please!
You're on! Loser buys the next round! In your dreams! If I win, the next round's on you!
Bet I can reach the bottom of this flagon before you! Bet I can down this ale faster than you!

But I'm sure those Skyrim dogs would stand down if the keepers of the tales showed their patriotism! Maybe if we stopped singing about their silly Nord heroes, the rebels would stop making such a fuss!
Viarmo, the college really must take a stand on the war! Viarmo, don't you think it's time that the Bards College officially declared support for the empire?

Lady Ateia, it is the official position of the college to remain neutral in all political affairs. We cannot risk our history by choosing sides. Now, now, our duty is to record the great tales of history, not to pick sides in them. Best to stay out of the warfare, I feel.
Aia, please be quiet. Viarmo and I are discussing matters of national politics. Aia, this is a delicate matter. Why don't you review your lessons and be silent for a while.
Pantea, perhaps you should attend to your students, and leave the politics to me. That is precisely why we remain neutral. Ours is to tell tales of empires, not to make or break them.
Those draugr are going to come up and kill us all.
They haven't moved out of the caves. I think we're safe.
"We're safe" he says. You'll eat those words when a draugr is tearing into your face.
The guards say no draugr have come out of the mine.
That's comforting. Glad they're keeping watch instead of getting rid of the draugr.
Don't be such a coward. We haven't seen any draugr since the mine was cleared. Be grateful.
Those draugr are going to be back. I can feel it.
Fine, but don't say I didn't warn you.
I don't think it's safe mining a cave on top of that crypt.
There's a war on. We need every scrap of ore we can get, so we're going to keep digging. Understand?
Feels good to be mining again.
How can you say that? This mine was filled with draugr not too long ago.
Steel your nerves. The draugr are gone. Focus on your mining.
I feel like any moment, a draugr is going to come and chop my head off.
Yes sir, of course.
All right. Keep up the good work.
Let's make sure we're just as productive this month as we were last. If Bryling's happy, we're happy.
Yes sir, fine sir.
Good, good. Keep up the hard work. It'll all pay off.
Everything well, Jesper?
Is everything well with you, my scaly friend?
Yes, well... That's all we ask of you. Carry on.
Yes sir.
Teeba-Ei is cold, but Teeba-Ei works hard as always.
Of course not. I never thought otherwise.
I'm fine, father. Work is fine.
Good, good. It's honest work, son. No shame in that.
Right. Well, you let me know if you need anything.
How goes it, son?
Nnnnooowwwwwww....
There once was a hero named Ragnar the Red, who came riding to Whiterun from ole Rorikstead!
And the braggart did swagger and brandish his blade, as he told of bold battles and gold he had made!
Thank you, thank you. No, please, hold your applause.
But then he went quiet, did Ragnar the Red, when he met the shieldmaiden Matilda who said...
"Oh, you talk and you lie and you drink all our mead! Now I think it's high time that you lie down and bleed!"
And so then came the clashing and slashing of steel, as the brave lass Matilda charged in full of zeal!
And the braggart named Ragnar was boastful no moooooree... when his ugly red head rolled around on the floor!
Thank you, good patrons of the Bannered Mare! Thank you!
One more song, what say you? Yeah? All right, then!
You'd better give me five septims right now, or I'm going to bloody your nose...
I... I don't have any money.
Ten septims tomorrow, baby Battle-Born. Or I'm gonna bloody your nose and your lip.
No! Please! I really don't have any money, Braith! I'll give you ten septims tomorrow. Just don't hit me.
Battle-Born! Give me your money!
You sound like my ma. Figured I was lying dead in a field somewhere, is that it?
By Ysmir, it's true. A jester - funny suit and all. Just north, by the Loreius Farm. Fool had a coffin in a cart, with a broken wheel.
Well, sounds like you've had quite the journey, Uthgerd. But you were gone longer than usual. I got to thinking maybe you weren't coming back...
Thought did cross my mind, yeah. War brewing, talk of a riot in Helgen, and now jesters? Skyrim's gone mad, girl. You need to be careful out there.
Ha ha ha ha ha ha ha!
By Ysmir, this is just what we need. There'll be panic in the streets if this proves true.
And you're sure?
Panic we can handle, Balgruuf. It's the dragons I'm not so sure about.
I've dispatched a rider to Helgen. We'll know soon enough.
Hmph.
It took me weeks to find that thieves' den. I can't stop now, and I can't get the sword on my own.
So you're willing to starve your wife and daughter to reclaim some rusty old sword?
I know your family's honor is important to you, but we can't afford it!
I just need to hire one, maybe two good men. You won't starve.
I'll put it plainly. You can claim your sword, or you can keep your wife. If you set foot outside the gate, I won't be here when you return.
Wait... I....
Saffir!
Careful, huh? Thanks, Skulvar. I'll remember that. Ha ha ha ha ha ha!
Like to see him laugh his way out that.
Have it your way. I'll take the job, but don't expect a miracle.
Ha! I'd sooner bend my knee to Ulfric Stormcloak.
Besides, Gray-Mane would never make steel for the Legion.
We'll pay whatever it takes. But we must have more swords for the Imperial soldiers.
I just can't fill an order that size on my own.
Why don't you swallow that stubborn pride of yours and ask Eorlund Gray-Mane for help?
How many Nords died to save the Empire? And what was our reward?
The worship of Talos outlawed, and now the Thalmor come to conduct their witch-hunts while the Empire stands idly by.
What? Speak your meaning plainly, old man.
Bold words, Battle-Born. While you're meting out justice to traitors, are you going to deal with the Emperor, as well?
I've heard you Gray-Manes are collaborating with the Stormcloaks. If I see any such treachery, I'll deal with you myself.
I'll remember that when the Stormcloaks liberate the city. No amount of money will protect you then, Battle-Born.
You won't be laughing when the Thalmor come to root out Stormcloak sympathizers.
I've already put in a claim to the land and property you'll forfeit when you're found to be a collaborator.
I'm surprised you had the wits to notice, Olfrid, what with your nose buried so far up the Emperor's backside.
Someone's been pilfering crops from my farm. If I find out it's one of your kin, I'll see the culprit rot in prison.
Don't lecture me about treachery, whelp. You don't know the meaning of the word.
By Ysmir, I will. Gods know it's been too long since I tasted real meat.
If they do, promise you'll actually purchase something for once.
Just browsin' today. If the gods be kind, someone will take mercy on me and spare a few septims.
I don't suppose you're going to buy something this time?
Three weeks? You're mad! You can't keep the stand closed for that long!
I've been thinking of hunting out beyond the boundaries of Whiterun hold.
Why not? Business has been terrible. Most folk would rather hunt their own meat than buy ours.
Nonsense. That's just an excuse for you to avoid working, and "commune with the greenwood like our fathers of old" and blah blah.
Congratulations, brother. You've been living in Skyrim so long, you've become a Nord.
Again? You just had an "extended hunt" last month. To the Pine Forest, wasn't it.
At least the Nords don't shirk their responsibilities.
That was three days. I'm thinking more like three weeks.
Our stock of arrows is running a bit low.
All right. I'll fletch some more when I get the time.
Good. I'll do the same. We've still got plenty of shafts from that Riverwood shipment.
Don't worry, brother. I'm sure he's fine. We've waited longer before receiving a letter.
Might be worth riding out to Solitude, see if a messenger ship's come in.
If it'll put your mind at ease, then I agree. But not now, all right? We need the business from the stand.
It's been two months, and no word from father.
You don't prepare the meat with any of those strange Elven spices, do you?
Ahhhh... No, no Elven spices. Just some salt, to preserve it. You're not afraid of salt, are you?
Do you have anything even remotely fresh?
I'm not "afraid" of anything. I simply prefer quality merchandise. No, no this meat won't do at all. Too much fat, and it all smells... wrong.
Suit yourself, then. The woods are that way. Outside the walls, walk straight ahead. Can't miss them. Good luck on your hunt.
I can assure you, it's all fresh. I hunt the game myself, every day.
Maybe you'd like to try the horker? Or some beef?
Good day.
Hmm. As you say.
Best you forget whatever you think you saw, elf. Such idle talk can prove hazardous to one's health.
Would your good friend be named Jon, by any chance? I've spied the two of you talking quite intimately. Glad to see you're making new friends. I know Jon's death was hard on you.
Got any sausages? I'm cooking a special breakfast for a friend, and they're his favorite.
Ah, Olfina. How may I help you?
Make it quick, and there might be a bowl of hot stew in it for you.
Certainly. I'll be sure to bring some back for you the next time I go hunting.
I've got a recipe for venison stew that I want to try out. Will you have venison anytime soon?
Your son chose his side, and he chose poorly. And now he's gone. Such is the way of war. The sooner you accept his loss, the better.
Come on, father. There's nothing more to be said here.
Do you believe this old hag?
Face it, cow! Your stupid son is dead! He died a Stormcloak traitor. And you... you best keep your mouth shut before you suffer the same.
Nothing? And what of my son? Hmm? What of Thorald? Is he nothing? So don't talk to me about suffering!
Foolish old woman! You know nothing! Nothing of our struggles, our suffering!
I will never accept his death! My son still lives. I feel it in my heart. So tell me, Battle-Borns, where is he? Where are you holding my Thorald?
"Holding him"? Why I've got him in my cellar. He's my prisoner.
You trying to scare off my customers, son? Lively! Keep it lively! We've been down this road before, Mikael. Save the sap and sadness for your lady friends. My patrons need life! Cheeriness!
Well then, consider it done. Ah! An excellent suggestion. I'll do that one, then.
Well, I was thinking maybe something mournful. A High Elf dirge, perhaps? These are rather trying times, after all. You know, Hulda, there's this lovely Argonian ballad I've been studying...
So Mikael, what'll it be tonight, hmm? Something upbeat? A Breton jig maybe? Mikael, son. How about something with a bit o' kick?
Hmm... Yes, you do raise a good point. What about the "Sweet Maidenfair from Hadleyshire"? Alright, alright... Um... How about "The Guttersnipe"?
I think "Seven Septims for Sigurd" will do nicely. Especially when they're in their cups. Well, that's not bad. But I was thinking "Mogo's Mead" really gets the place moving.
Ha! That's my girl.
Mikael is quite the songbird. Maybe he's the reason you're here all the time. Perhaps it's because there's no better way to face the cold Skyrim nights than with a belly full of ale?
Oh Jon, darling. You know you're the only stone-biting, knuckle-dragging Nord for me.
Sing you a special song tonight, beautiful lass?
Not now, I'm working.
Bah. You're always working. Why else would I spend so much time here?
Aye, the bard's got talent, I'll give him that. You just make sure his music is the only thing you're admiring. Oh, there's a better way.
A buxom barmaid between the sheets will keeps me plenty warm.
Better yet, she won't make my head ring the morning after.
Saadia dear? Oh Saadia...
Yes, mum?

Don't forget to polish those glasses later. You still need to remove that blood stain. From the... incident. Just a reminder, sweetie - the blankets still need to be washed. We're running low on the Black-Briar mead. In a couple days I'll have you make a run, fetch some more. I'll be needing you to mop the place down extra tonight. Lots of spills!
Of course, mum. Oh, yes, Miss Hulda. Certainly, mum. Oh yes, mum. I'll make sure it gets done.

Listen, Braith... Why don't you talk to your mother about this, okay? There's a good girl. I wish your mother were still alive. She could answer you much better. Let me think on it and we'll talk later.
Papa, I want to talk to you...
Hmm? What about?
Well, there's this boy, and...
Nice try, blossom, but I'm not a knight, I'm a mercenary. The answer's still no. Besides, your mother would miss you too much.
Yeah. Right.
Papa, the next time you go away, I want to come with you.
When I go away, I go to war. That's no place for a little girl.
Every knight needs a squire. I could help you with your sword, things like that.
Leave me alone, Braith...
What are you gonna do if I don't? Huh? Gonna cry to your papa?
Just go away!
Oh look, it's little baby Battle-Born.
I... I don't have any money.
You'd better give me five septims, right now, or I'm going to bloody your nose...
No! Please! I really don't have any money, Braith! I'll give you ten septims tomorrow. Just don't hit me.
Ten septims tomorrow, baby Battle-Born. Or I'm gonna bloody your nose and your lip.
Battle-Born! Give me your money!
Braith. I.... I've come to tell you that I'm not afraid of you anymore.
That's what I thought. Now get out of my way, baby. I got things to do.
Don't make me laugh, baby Battle-Born. You'll be afraid of me till the day I kill you.
You... You're wrong! You can't hurt me anymore...
Oh no? So you're gonna fight back if I punch you? Huh? You're gonna hit a girl?
Well, no... I... I mean...
Mother?
Not now, Braith. Go... go ask your father.
What?
I wanted to ask you something. It's about a boy...
Not now, Braith.
Mother? Can I talk to you?
But...
How goes the begging today, Brenuin?
The gods smile on them who show charity. Best you remember that.
Make it quick, then. I don't want your stink driving my customers away.
That's right, mock the town beggar like everyone else. But I've got a right to browse, don't I? I ain't hurtin' anyone.
Look, come back tomorrow, okay? If I have anything left that's not sold or spoiled, you can have it.
No handouts today, Brenuin. Now scat. You'll scare off my paying customers.
You've got the heart of Mara herself, you know that? Thank you, Carlotta. Thank you.
Oh, just one apple, Carlotta? Just one tiny apple. I'll pay you tomorrow, I swear it.
That's what you said last week, and the week before that. Now go, before I call a guard.
And what might you be looking at?
No, no! Don't do that. No need to do that. I'm going. See? I'm leaving. No guards, please.
Oh, the fruit looks so good. So juicy.
Can you close up the stand early today, mama?
Tsk. And to think, I was going to feed you cabbages and apples again. Yes, little fairy, we can go to the tavern for supper.
I'm afraid not, little fairy. The fruit has about another day left before it spoils. We've got to sell as much as we can, as soon as we can.
Yay!
That's what you always say.
Because it's always true.
Can we at least go to the tavern for supper?
These fruits and vegetables are disappointing, Carlotta.
I get them fresh from the farms daily, Nazeem.
If you were getting them from my farm, they'd be twice as fresh.
I had to. The farmers are charging me double for the produce I sell.
Did you raise your prices, Carlotta?
Maybe, but they wouldn't taste as good as a loaf of fresh-baked pumpernickel.
Exactly. Road patrols were cut in half because the Jarl needed soldiers. Now the bandits are bolder than ever.
They've been raiding the farms for food, and supplies are scarcer than ever. Maybe I should sell swords and armor, instead.
Let me guess, they're saying it's because of this trouble with the Stormcloaks?
You're right. I'll have to remember that the next time I get a shipment in.
I'm sure you could charge double for those and still sell them all within a week.
Aren't they? I always set some aside for myself when the traders bring them up from the south.
Those green apples you sold me the other day were delicious.
But I don't want to be patient! I want my dress right now! Father promised!
It takes a while to make a dress, Dagny. You have to be patient.
I'm so angry, I can hardly stand it!
Father promised me a new dress days ago, now where is it?
I'm going to tell father you said that. He'll tan your hide for sure!
All you ever do is complain about what you want. You're a spoiled baby.
Sir, we really must talk. Balgruuf, my Jarl. A word, if I may. I need but a moment of your time, my lord.
Speak. What is it? You've got sixty seconds. Go.

Damn it, Proventus. I've got war lurking just outside my gates, and this is what you offer me? This? Begone. Yes, yes. Take care of it, Proventus. Whatever it is you're talking about... Proventus, you're my steward. Your job is to offer me counsel. This? This is not counsel. Hmm... All right, yes, I see your point. Make the necessary arrangements.
Of course, sir. Yes, my lord. As you say, my Jarl.

Well... It's your son. Nelkir. The boy has been acting increasingly peculiar. Moreso than normal, I mean. Something really should be done... We really must discuss the security here in Dragonsreach. Perhaps we could limit patrols in the city, and retain more guards here? There's been talk again in the streets. A general fear that the giants may move south, and then... Well, you understand. One of the servants had a wonderful idea. Fireproofing Dragonsreach. In case of attack by, um... air. My daughter Adrianne wants to forge a new sword for you. Now, it wouldn't be a Skyforge blade, I know, but she really is quite gifted... I think the time might be right for another public appearance. Maybe address the patrons at the Bannered Mare? Or visit Jorrvaskr?
Hello, Fralia dear.
Perfect, my dear. Absolutely perfect. I'll see you then.
