Lillith - always a pleasure. Just browsing, or were you looking for something particular?
Funny you should ask. I'm in the market for a new locket. Something in polished silver, maybe. Big enough to hold, say, a folded-up letter?
Ahhh, I see. I think I know just what you need. I don't have anything like that here now, but my Eorlund - he can make you one right quick.
When I get home, I'll have him start on it right away. Come back to pick it up in, oh... three days?
Fralia, do you ever deal with the Khajiit at all? I'm sure they would love to trade in your husband's steel.
Plenty of people here that need Eorlund's craftsmanship, my dear. We've never had any reason to deal with those caravans of theirs.
And there it is, friends! The ugly truth! We are the children of man! Talos is the true god of man! Ascended from flesh, to rule the realm of spirit!

And deserve our praise you do, for we are one! Ere you ascended and the Eight became Nine, you walked among us, great Talos, not as god, but as man! We are but maggots, writhing in the filth of our own corruption! While you have ascended from the dung of mortality, and now walk among the stars!
The very idea is inconceivable to our Elven overlords! Sharing the heavens with us? With man? Ha! They can barely tolerate our presence on earth!
"I breathe now, in royalty, and reshape this land which is mine. I do this for you, Red Legions, for I love you."

Terrible and powerful Talos! We, your unworthy servants, give praise! For only through your grace and benevolence may we truly reach enlightenment! Talos the mighty! Talos the unerring! Talos the unassailable! To you we give praise!
Aye, love. Love! Even as man, great Talos cherished us. For he saw in us, in each of us, the future of Skyrim! The future of Tamriel!
But you were once man! Aye! And as man, you said, "Let me show you the power of Talos Stormcrown, born of the North, where my breath is long winter."
Today, they take away your faith. But what of tomorrow? What then? Do the elves take your homes? Your businesses? Your children? Your very lives?
And what does the Empire do? Nothing! Nay, worse than nothing! The Imperial machine enforces the will of the Thalmor! Against its own people!

For we are the children of man! And we shall inherit both heavens and earth! And we, not the Elves or their toadies, will rule Skyrim! Forever! Trust in me, Whiterun! Trust in Heimskr! For I am the chosen of Talos! I alone have been anointed by the Ninth to spread his holy word!
So rise up! Rise up, children of the Empire! Rise up, Stormcloaks! Embrace the word of mighty Talos, he who is both man and Divine!
So, what book should I read to you tonight?
You've got no sense of humor, you know that? Why don't you pick up where you left off with "The Real Barenziah."
Mother!
How about "The Lusty Argonian Maid"?
That's all right, grandmother. I like staying home with you.
It's that Braith girl again, isn't it? Has she been bothering you again? I've a mind to speak with her mother.
No! Please, grandmother, don't do that. I'm fine. Really. Can we just... not talk about this anymore?
All right, dear.
Lars, dear, why don't you go outside and play? It's a beautiful day.
Wonderful, dear. Thank you.
Hrm.
When will you be makin' some more jewelry, love? Some silver lockets and amulets would fetch a nice price at the stand.
Eorlund, dearest, are you hungry? Would you like me to fix you something?
A venison pie, maybe? With a nice cup of mulled mead?
Hrm.
If we send half our guards to aid the legions, just for a few days, it could tip the scales in the Empire's favor.
The Companions can help protect the city, and the Emperor will be in our debt.
I haven't changed my mind, if that's what you're asking. I won't leave Whiterun defenseless, even for a day.
Have you reconsidered my idea?
Have you lost all sense? We are short on guards as it is!
If we lose half our men, the Dark Brotherhood and Thieves' Guild will have the run of the city. The Stormcloaks will be the least of our worries!
The answer is no, I tell you! Now stop pestering me with your war-mongering!
Leave me out of your intrigues, Hrongar. If you have something to say to the Jarl, say it with you own tongue.
I'm not asking you to defy the Jarl, just to open his eyes.
Use subtlety and suggestion to turn his thoughts to the war. You're his steward, he'll listen to you.
What would you have me do, Hrongar? Your brother is the Jarl. You know I can't question his judgement.
Proventus, you must help me. We need to convince my brother to do more for the war effort.
We're at war, old fool, or have you forgotten?
Whiterun is the crown jewel of Skyrim, and you would leave us defenseless?
As you command, my lord. But, the issue could be solved another way.
If we spend less on new arms and armor for the guards, for example...
Raise the taxes, then! Put anyone that refuses to pay in the stocks and make an example of them.
My lord Jarl, if we do not take steps soon, our coffers will be empty.
Forgive me, my lord. It was foolish of me to make such a suggestion.
These secret visits to the tavern will make you an easy target for an enemy assassin. You should have told me first.
Heard about that, did you? Yes, I went out for a pint or two. What of it?
Balgruuf, did you slip out again last night for a drink at the Bannered Mare?
That might be so, but it will never stop me from trying.
Damn it, woman, I'm the Jarl of Whiterun! I won't apologize for talking to my people. You can't protect me every moment of the day.
Nonsense. If Balgruuf falls, someone will take his place, for better or worse. In the meantime, we have a war to win. And win we must.
And if an assassin slips past the night watch, we won't have a Jarl at all. Without Balgruuf's leadership, Whiterun will descend into chaos.
What would you have me do? If we do not send men to fight in the war, you'll find yourself guarding one of Ulfric's men.
I am concerned about the Jarl's safety. Too many of our guards have been redeployed to fight the Stormcloaks.
Owning a farm does have its advantages.
Ah, Ysolda was it? What brings you to the market?
I'm here to buy food, Nazeem. I suppose you don't need to worry about that.
A ballad? Oh, now I know you're joking with me.
So I'm, uh... writing a song for you...
It's all true, I swear it. You can hear it when it's done. I'll just need a year or two smooth the rough edges.
Why Jon Battle-Born. You're writing me a song? Does it somehow involve blood, or beheadings, or the honor of my forebears?
Well, that's where I started. But it turned into something of a ballad.
Ha! I thought as much.
Oh Jon, stop dallying. You know you have to go. It's why Mara put you on this earth.
You think a few miles can truly keep us apart?
You mean you won't forget about me the moment I'm out of sight? Get yourself a nice old rich husband, have sixteen babies?
Tsk. You've uncovered my master plan. Now I suppose you'll never leave.
Harlot.
So have you spoken to that man from the Bards College?
No, not yet. But I will. I just haven't... gotten around to it yet.
I can't. Not tonight. I need to go home. I swear, my father is starting to suspect something. I can't. Not tonight. I need to go home. I swear, my family is starting to suspect something.
That's your imagination running wild. Nobody knows how we feel about each other.
Don't talk about my father like that, Jon. And the answer's still no. Don't say that out loud. Not here. And the answer's still no.
But tomorrow. Definitely.
I want to see you when you're done working.
Are you still working at the Bannered Mare in the evenings, Olfina?
And why shouldn't I? Just because I'm a Gray-Mane doesn't mean I can't earn my own keep.
I didn't mean... I'm sorry I asked.
Yes, my lord.
Our coffers are nearly empty. I can scarcely afford to pay the guards, and we need every one of them in these troubled times.
You'll have to make do with what we have, Proventus.
My lord, since Ulfric Stormcloak's uprising, the cost of goods has doubled. I'll need more coin if I'm to provision us properly.
Purchase more supplies, then. That's your job as Steward, isn't it? Why do you trouble me with these details?
My lord, our provisions are running dangerously low. Our stores of meat, wine and grain are all but depleted.
I warn you, Gray-Mane, you are treading on dangerous ground.
Do your loyalties lie with the Thalmor, then?
I'm no happier about this than you are, but I don't want the see the Thalmor rounding up people in the streets and throwing them in prison.
A law made at the tip of an Aldmeri sword, aye. A sword stained red with Nord blood.
Is this what our people fought and died for? To forsake our most beloved ancestor and divine?
I won't say it again, Vignar - Talos worship is forbidden. It's the Empire's law, and we're still a part of the Empire.
Don't threaten me, boy. You're either a Nord who respects our traditions, or you're not.
If not, it isn't me you'll have to answer to, but the people of this city and this hold.
Don't suppose there is. But you don't have to be so damned prickly.
You know I did.
Yes, father.
You clean out that muck?
You shoe that gelding, boy?
Yes, father, I did. And I watered her, and got fresh feed, and refitted the old saddle, just like you asked. Is there anything else?
Groom her, too?
Shor's beard, boy! You forget where you're standing? What kind o' business we're running? So? So?
I tell you? Saw that wild mare again yesterday, just outside the walls.
Oh. Okay. So we should try to... what? Capture it?
Yeah. So?
We manage to break that mare and bring her back here, we can sell her for a small fortune.
Yes, son. We should try to capture it.
I'm just no good at this. You said it yourself. Gods, I don't even like horses. And if it's true what they're saying about dragons...
Dragons? You want to go out and fight dragons? Are you completely off your nut?
Listen, father. I've been thinking....
Come on, father, how hard can it be? They're just... big lizards. And those scales and teeth, they must be worth a fortune...
Big lizards? By Shor, your mother gave birth to a half-wit. That is the end of this discussion.
Here it comes again. Not happy with a roof and a trade, no. You want to be something entirely... different.
Everyone is this city is so on edge. I could use some good news, Skulvar.
Aye, that it has. Trust me, mum - once you've killed a man from a horse, you'll never want to fight on the ground again. Ain't no goin' back.
Ha! Four more geldings sold. Sound like good news to you?
Why thank you for that most colorful assessment, Skulvar.
So we'll be needing fresh horses, then?
Aye, mum. That we will. Mares, stallions, donkeys - I don't think it matters. Pretty sure I can sell any steeds we get.
Excellent. I'll send the proper letters, then, and have some fresh horses delivered straightaway.
Lookin' forward to it.
Indeed.
I do hate to admit it, but if nothing else, all the fighting lately has been a complete blessing to this business.

The fever's down a bit, an' I can almost see straight. I still can't hold nothin' down, but it's better than yesterday. My joints ache, I can't eat nothin' and my head feels like a furnace. I've seen better days.
The pain's a little less than before, but it still hurts bad enough. It's not as bad as before, but I still can't get a good night's sleep. I ain't going to lie, it's still pretty bad.
I feel better already. Gods bless you, healer. Thank you. The pain is already easing.
I feel better already. Gods bless you, healer. Thank you. The pain is already easing.
I feel better already. Gods bless you, healer. Thank you. The pain is already easing.

The fever's down a bit, an' I can almost see straight. I still can't hold nothin' down, but it's better than yesterday. My joints ache, I can't eat nothin' and my head feels like a furnace. I've seen better days.
The pain's a little less than before, but it still hurts bad enough. It's not as bad as before, but I still can't get a good night's sleep. I ain't going to lie, it's still pretty bad.

If you don't mind me saying so, Ahlam, your husband is a damn fool. Any moment spent thinking about him is a moment wasted. Ahlam, let's be honest. Your husband is an arrogant, domineering buffoon. These are the words you used to describe him to me... remember? Oh dearest, who cares? So your husband is a lout. The work you do here, with me, is invaluable. The people of Whiterun know your true worth.
Something wrong, Ahlam? Are you alright, Ahlam? You haven't seemed yourself today. What's wrong, dear friend? You seem... distracted today.

Now, now, my friend. You must look on the bright side. If soldiers storm the city, there's a good chance your husband may get killed. Let those soldiers come here! You've never seen me throw incense. I could fell a giant.
Ha! Well, when you put it like that, it certainly puts things into perspective. But enough wallowing. And thank you, Danica. Oh, you are terrible. You do know that, right? Ha ha ha ha ha.

Oh, it's Nazeem. He's been spending more and more time fawning over the Jarl. I swear, we're hardly ever home at the same time anymore. It's nothing, I just... It's Nazeem. How did we get to this point, Danica? Is there no love left between us? Hmm? Oh, well... To be honest, I was just thinking of Nazeem. The gap between us seems to be widening. He is just so... self-absorbed.

But it's more than that. Nazeem is obsessed with this civil war, as is all of Skyrim. I swear, it will consume us all. Maybe Nazeem's obsession has merit. This civil war seems so big, so unceasing... I'm afraid, Danica. Afraid for us all.
Probably.
Then you're on.
Fancy a game of Iron Hearts later?
You going to lose horribly, and then say you let me win?
Mutton.
Hmm. So I haven't. All right, I'll buy the ingredients tomorrow and we can have it for dinner.
You ain't made me that stew in a long time.
Which, the mutton or the vegetable?
Well if my layabout manservant fed me more, that wouldn't be a problem.
Oho! Manservant? Is that what I am now?
My mistake. A manservant wouldn't let me starve or freeze. I let you live here, and now I'm two steps closer to the grave.
There's a chill in the air. Ysmir's beard, it gets colder in here every day.
Old man, without me, you would have withered away a long time ago.
That's just you getting skinnier every day, old man. You're losing your padding. You need to eat more.
Hmph. Damn you for being right.
That's what I thought.
Never you mind, then. I'll find a more charitable soul.
So you can spend it on drinks at the Bannered Mare? If it's food you need, ask for that instead.
Spare a coin for a fellow Nord who's down on his luck?
Oh, Grimvar... always with the nonsense. No, no, of course not. Those are just tales...
Fine. Then I'll invite him out to play. He lives right there. I'm going to knock on his door...
Then it's true, what everyone is saying? That Aventus Aretino is doing the Black Sacrament? Trying to summon the Dark Brotherhood?
All right. I won't deny it, child. What you heard is true. But Aventus Aretino walks a dark path. His actions can lead only to ruin.
Ha! Then I'm right. I knew it. He's trying to have somebody killed!
No, child! Wait! That boy, that house - they're cursed.
Now. Enough. We will speak no more of this. I am the only friend you need.
If anything actually happens, call a guard.
My men have their orders. But it's a big city, and there's a war on. Plus these murders.
A few dark elves getting shoved around doesn't really amount to much.
Watch that tongue, Rendar, or your whole lot could be down with the Argonians hauling ballast by tomorrow.
Typical Nord. Beard for brains.
If the guards in the Gray Quarter weren't a bunch of n'wahs, I wouldn't be here talking to you.
But we haven't taken a side because it's not our fight.
Maybe we'll pay you a visit tonight, little spy. We got ways of finding out what you really are.
Imperial spies? You can't be serious!
Hey, maybe the reason these gray-skins don't help in the war is because they're Imperial spies!
You come here where you're not wanted, you eat our food, you pollute our city with your stink and you refuse to help the Stormcloaks.
(Sigh)
None know its origins, but the stories say that men who hear its music are compelled to dance uncontrollably, no matter the peril.
Legend holds that the Dancer's Pipe has won wars, toppled empires and changed the very course of history.
Oh my, I very nearly got us both into a nasty predicament, didn't I?
Don't let this innocent-looking flute fool you, for this is the Dancer's Pipe.
To activate this strange power, one must only speak the magic words, which are...
Now, I know what you're thinking - this is no spoon, it's a fork! Nobody can eat soup with a fork!
Well, my friend, you did not know Ysgramor.
Ah, now here is an item out of legend. This is Ysgramor's Soup Spoon.
Here is the Book of Fate, discovered in a secret room in the Arcane University.
The writing in the book describes the destiny of its reader, so the words change from one person to the next.
Some see only blank pages, and nobody knows why. Perhaps some of us are born with no destiny, or maybe the blank pages signify an imminent death.
These tools were found in a crypt outside Windhelm. They belonged to the ancient Nords who dwelt in Skyrim before the days of the First Empire.
Most scholars believe that the Nords of old used these implements to prepare their dead for burial.
What macabre mysteries would these tools reveal if they could but speak?
And with that, the tour is over. I thank you for your patronage, and I hope to see you again soon!
That's all I ask. With your help, we have a chance to make a better life for ourselves here. For that, I thank you.
You've seen how we live -- cramped alleys, run-down buildings, few guard patrols. Even the name "Gray Quarter" is an insult.
You're a war hero, Brunwulf. Ulfric will listen to you.
I'll speak to Ulfric soon, but I make no promises that I can change his mind.
It's not that simple. Ulfric wants a Skyrim for the Nords. He doesn't trust what he calls outsiders.
Quintus, could you fetch me a copy of The Firmament? I need to compare the old star charts to today's.
Don't waste time apologizing, just find the book!
Did they really record the star positions from Curalmil's tomb? There's no way it's that precise.
I... I apologize, master.
Confound it, boy, I know what I'm doing. It will help me determine the season of his burial, which I can cross-reference.
Yes, master, I know. I just want to keep up my own projects as well.
You can waste your own time, not mine. An apprentice obeys his master. A good one does, at least.
Damn it, child, didn't I tell you to gather my notes on sub-material properties?
Yes, master. I'm sorry, I'll get back to those notes straight away.
Yes, and I'm working on it, but I'm also trying to...
When I ask you for something, I expect it to get done.
Master, I have a question about infusions of arrowroot.
Erm... no. Not yet. I'm sorry, I was reading up on the effects of distillation.
What? You've been lollygagging in idle reading?
No... I was trying to...
Don't be so sure. Now, have you finished grinding the dried snowberries?
I'm sorry to always be so hard on you, boy. I just worry I don't have much time left.
Out of my sight!
I know, master. Don't say such things -- there is always time.
Don't even bother with that one. Leave it to the orcs.
Exactly.
I think I've got a handle on it, but Orichalcum is confusing.
Oh, right. That makes sense. Kind of a messy metal, anyway.
Have you been learning your ores?
Is Ulfric's armor done yet?
This is more delicate work than you're used to.
Can I help with it? Maybe just the cuirass?
I did that engraved piece just last month!
No, I want to take my time with it.
This is the royal armor, lass. Maybe in a few years.
Did you look behind the forge? I think I saw it there.
Hammers don't have legs.
Oh... yes. Now that you mention it, I think... sorry about that.
Did you use my good hammer?
No.
I didn't touch it!
Blast, girl, I told you to leave my tools alone. You have yours and I have mine.
I'm sorry. What would you like to talk about?
Hows about we figure out some way to keep warm tonight?
Oh! You behave, now!
Tell me about the Great War. I hear you were in the battle of...
Elda, honey, let's not talk about the war. It's in the past.
Perhaps. But not today.
Nearly thirty years, now.
Just wondering when you'll be ready to give it up and settle down. Seems like you're always working.
I just feel like if I'm not here, then something could go wrong. Nils is a hard worker, but I wouldn't trust him to run things.
One of these days he'll have to learn.
How long have you run this place, again?
There's a clear spot just west of Riften. You know the area?
I've been there before, but I don't know it well.
I've been thinking about building that cabin we talked about.
Well that's where I want to build. In the fall forest. Give it an easterly view. The sunrise is almost as pretty as you are.
That sounds lovely. You're very sweet.
Oh? Where?
Coming right up.
How would you like a drink?
So what's the news on the street, Captain?
Very much so.
The dark elves are uneasy. There's a killer on the streets. And Viola Giordano won't leave me alone.
Oh dear. What should I do?
Bring it to me straight away when you find it. Don't dally. I can keep it safe.
Calixto, someone left an interesting ring in here a few weeks ago. Would you like a look?
Of course, my dear. It may prove to be quite the curiosity! One must always be alert.
Well, I seem to have misplaced it at the moment. But it was white, like alabaster, with three bright rubies set in it.
Think nothing of it.
Oh, thank the gods you're in Windhelm, Calixto!
Be very careful with that. It sounds as if it may be the Death Ring of Dro'farahn. A ring of the most dangerous sort.
Oh, I'm sorry to hear that. Is everything all right?
Here, let me get you some mead. This one's on me.
Oh, Jora. Good to see you. I was wondering if you might ask Lortheim something for me.
It's been better, I'll be honest with you.
Don't bother. I don't have much chance of seeing my husband these days. He's always up in the palace with Ulfric.
I know, dear. He's a busy man, though, and loyal to the Stormcloaks.
I just don't know what to do anymore. He's hardly ever in the temple. I see him at breakfast, and that's it.
I... I'm sorry, dear, I've got some other customers. I'll be back around in a minute.
What about being loyal to his wife?
Elda, you know better than to believe every idiot traveler that wanders through.
Captain, have you heard these stories of dragons?
But they're saying that one of them freed Ulfric... that he's in league with them.
Think about how ridiculous that sounds. Come now.
Ah, I can't reveal all my secrets to you. But rest assured, I would know.
But how would you know it's real?
Calixto, do you know if there's any truth to these rumors of dragons?
Eh. I try not to trouble myself with stories of the outside world.
Now if someone brings me a dragon scale, that's a different story.
Fine, then. I guess some Dunmer are content to be their pets.
Here's what's going to happen. I'm going to pretend I didn't hear that, and you're going to leave me alone. Deal?
Look, Ambarys, I just came here for a drink. I don't need any trouble.
Don't you ever find it demeaning, working for that Nord family?
What's new with the Cruel-Seas, Suvaris? Have they given you one of those helmets with the horns on them yet?
What do you want from me? I work for them ok? We're not friends. They pay me, and I get the job done. That's it.
Either pour another drink or keep moving, Ambarys.
Touchy. Maybe some Dunmer lives in you yet.
Why do the Nords bother you so much, Ambarys?
I think that's just their way. The Nords don't like anybody who's not a Nord, but they're not bad people, deep down.
Oh, I doubt that very much. Who would load their ships, then?
Look around you. Don't you know what their little war is about? They want all non-Nords out of Skyrim. That means you and me.
Just you wait and see.
Why do you even need to ask? They treat your people as bad as they do mine.
That's really none of your business...
If it's all the same to you, Scouts-Many-Marshes prefers to eat and drink in peace.
How much do they pay you per day?
Eight septims per day, plus lodging.
Sorry, my scaly friend, you've come to the wrong place. Around here we don't ignore what's happening in the world.
How much?
Eight septims for breaking your back, and then you live in squalor. How much is your dignity worth?
You know. Where do you get your goods? I am always amazed at how you manage to sell things so cheaply.
I'll consider it. Many of the people I deal with are... secretive. You know how it is.
Well, I'll want to meet them next time they're around. Maybe you can give an introduction.
My... my what, now?
Oh, just a matter of finding the right suppliers.
Niranye, I just have to know -- what is your secret?
Of course! I undersand completely. You just put us in a room, and I'll do all the talking. No worries at all.
Oh, I see. Well, I'm sorry to have troubled you about it.
Just... know that your efforts are appreciated.
I'm not looking for special treatment, Aval. All I did was talk to Ulfric.
For all I know, he's already forgotten the conversation. I wouldn't get your hopes up.
But I insist. and with good reason.
Malthyr told me that you've been speaking to Ulfric about our situation. He said you're going to help us.
So few Nords have ever offered to help us, a discount is the least I can do.
That's not necessary. I'll pay the same price as anyone else.
Friend Brunwulf, how good to see you!
If you see anything you like, just let me know and I'll glad offer you a discount.
I doubt Ulfric would let Thalmor into Windhelm without a fight. But please, do continue. How would you help us?
Well, I've heard awful stories about these Thalmor, and how they're rounding up everyone who still worships Talos.
The interrogations are quite merciless, from what I've heard.
I fear for you and your husband, should the Thamlor come here. But perhaps there's a way I can help.
Is that so? And what were you thinking, exactly?
Hello, Jora. I'm glad to see you. In fact, I was just thinking about you and your husband.
We accept the risks that come with our faith, but I'll keep your offer in mind. Thank you, Niranye.
Well, let's just say that I know some people who are experts at helping others disappear when they need to.
They are discreet and thorough, though not inexpensive. I hope you'll keep that in mind, should the worst come to pass.
You're such a wet blanket, captain. Can't a girl have a little fun from time to time?
If that business proposition includes smuggling, forget it.
The sailors I know are plenty good at finding trouble without any help from you.
I was wondering if you still had many associates in the shipping profession.
I have a business proposition for any sailors who might be looking to make a few extra septims.
A pleasure to see you as well, Niranye. What can I do for you?
Captain Lonely-Gale, it's always a pleasure to see you.
In fact, I'm glad you're here. There's something I'd like to ask you.
Just promise me when you get some more in, I'll have the first crack at them.
You know, I'm not sure. My husband's been tending to the vines, so I'll have to ask him.
Is that new batch of tomatoes ready for sale yet, Hillevi?
So serious! (Laughter)
What is it Ulfric's always saying... "On my honor as a Nord, I swear it." (Laughter).
You've done more than enough already. You've been a good friend in a time of need, and we won't forget that.
I'm sorry I lost myself for a moment there. I just need some time to get over the loss.
I... I'm so sorry, Torbjorn. You must be suffering terribly. I wish there was some way I could help.
My little Friga loved to cook, but she was terrible at it. Then one day, out of nowhere, she made the most amazing leek soup.
She watched while we ate it, and when she saw how much we loved it, she was... so proud...
It was my pleasure, Torbjorn. I enjoy cooking, and after what you and Tova have been through, it was the least I could do.
I wanted to thank you again for the mince pie you sent over. It was delicious.
I've been meaning to speak to you, Niranye. Rumor is, you've got ties to the Thieves' Guild.
The eyes of the law are everywhere these days.
The guards are looking for a killer, but who knows what else they might turn up? Good day.
Not that I'd know anything about it, of course, but it seems to me that the last thing a thieves' guild would want is to draw attention to itself.
It's a bad time to be a criminal, what with these murders going on.
In fact, thieves have been known to kill, if there's a profit in it. This war's been hard on all of us.
One should never pay too much attention to rumors, Torbjorn.
You have piqued my curiosity, however. Please, do continue.
I'll be sure to stress your urgency. It seems like every farmer in Skyrim is short on supplies these days.
Tell him I'll pay double the normal price. We've been getting by with one broken pitchfork, but it's falling apart.
Revyn put the word out to his suppliers but with the war on, tools are scarce. Both sides have been snapping them up.
Did you have any luck tracking own some more pitchforks?
I'll be sure to tell her.
We've got another dozen ripening on the vine. They should be ready in a few days.
Well enough, I suppose. Nilsine bought up most of the tomatoes, and was asking if we could get more.
How's business today?
Oh, I see. Yes, yes of course I'll take a look. Just bring them by whenever it's convenient for you.
I have some things that belonged to my daughter, Friga. She... she won't be needing them any more.
Yes, that's right. Whether or not I'm interested depends on what you've got, of course.
I understand you purchase used goods, as well as sell them?
We need to move faster. Keep them off balance.
Calm yourself, Galmar. Save it for the battlefield.
We can't march on Solitude. Not yet. One thing at a time.
It's working, Galmar. Our patience has won us friends and allies. And our armies are systematically taking care of the rest.
Our men are getting massacred out there. Damn Imperials.
Is there any news from High Rock?
I suppose we shouldn't be surprised. They've never had many problems with the Empire.
Not a peep. Those prissy Bretons can't be made to lift a finger to help their neighbors.
Those milk drinkers? Might as well be elves. Think they're better than us.
Regardless. It appears Skyrim must stand alone. Again.
A navy, my lord. We could stop the influx of Imperial troops to Solitude, and choke their northern lines.
But imagine -- fleets of ships sailing from Windhelm, all bearing the Stormcloak flag! It would be glorious!
I'm still not sure I understand what you're asking.
I'll think on this, but I make no promises.
I can ask no more. Thank you, my lord!
You need but ask.
And I suppose the Cruel-Seas would be just the clan to provide ships and men?
But most of their supply routes come south, from Cyrodiil.
Yes, sir. I'll try to contain her.
I don't care if she can find a living dwarf -- I can't have her stirring up trouble. We have enough problems as it is.
See that you do. I will not let Windhelm descend into chaos over a few overactive imaginations.
Captain, I've been receiving complaints about this Giordano woman.
Yes, sir. I've been trying to quiet her, but she's insistent. She thinks she can find out who's been killing the women...
Well that much is good. Let's finish this first war before starting the next one, eh?
What's the current spirit among the dark elves?
Um... yes, of course, sir.
Carry on, Lonely-Gale. And loosen yourself a bit.
As restless as ever, sir, but I don't see them taking any kind of incendiary action. Not soon, anyway.
Well, sir, the hold of Falkreath is fairly vulnerable, and blocks the only road from Cyrodiil.
A reasonable strategy.
A good point, old friend.
And you, Jorleif?
Galmar thinks we should double our men in the Reach.
To be sure, my lord, I am not skilled in the arts of war or military tactics.
But you're able to see the whole in the parts, and for that I'm grateful.
As you wish, sir.
Sir, there continues to be unrest in the Gray Quarter.
Let me know if you hear anything more substantial?
Blasted dark elves. I don't suppose you could tell them that I presently have larger concerns? Such as all of Skyrim?
Of course, my lord.
They don't seem to be very sympathetic to our cause, sir.
Of course. Something that seems to be in short supply these days.
And the message, sir?
I'm diverting Gar and Haddring's men to join him.
Is that wise, sir?
It will work if we can pull Hran's men from the south. And find a bit of luck.
Jorleif, I want you to send a messenger to our western camps.
I'm not seeking advice right now, friend. Just send the message.
I'm fairly sure that the dragons don't care about our matters one way or the other.
But just think of the advantage.
Do you think we could persuade one of the dragons to join our side?
I'm not saying it wouldn't be useful. But there are better uses of our resources right now.
I don't suppose we would ever really trust the thing anyway.
Did you notice that the snow settles in a different direction near the murder sites?
What is it now, Viola?
Captain, captain!
Don't you think all your tramping around there investigating might have something to do with it?
I... well. Perhaps. But still! It's curious.
I'm sorry to be such a bother. We'll talk another time.
Have you thought about my invitation?
Captain Lonely-Gale! I've been looking for you everywhere!
I've thought about it, but I'm not sure it's such a good idea.
Yes, I think that must be it. My wife hasn't been gone that long, after all. Ask me again on another day.
And now you've found me. Can I help you?
Oh, I see. Is it still too soon?
Viola, dark elves sleep just like the rest of us.
You wouldn't think it from the racket that Cornerclub makes.
Do you think those dark elves had anything to do with the murders? The attacks all happened at night, after all.
I'm sure the guards have the matter well in hand. Now, if you'll excuse me.
No, I really don't. It'll be a while before I'm ready for that. I'll be on my way now.
It was an old Nord proverb. It said, the best way to get over the loss of a lover is to find a new one.
Hello, captain! Can you spare a moment? I heard something the other day that I wanted to share with you.
What did you hear?
I didn't lose a lover, Viola, I lost my wife. It's not the same thing.
Well, if it works in the one case, why not the other? Don't you want to at least give it a try?
Fine.
Why do I always have to be the Elf? I don't want to!
We're playing Hunt the Elf. You're the Elf.
Good morning, Assur. What do you want to do today?
Too bad. That's what we're playing, and you're the Elf. Now go hide so I can hunt you!
That's because you always lose... Elf.
I hate this game.
I'm gonna find you, Elf!
Ha! Found you!
Always looking on the bright side, aren't you.
Don't sass me, little girl.
How are you today, Thaena?
Same as ever. Trying to keep from freezing to death, trying to keep food on the table.
I certainly hope so, otherwise I'm wasting my time.
Yeah, well I don't see anything.
You got anything in here worth buying?
You looking for anything in particular this time?
Perhaps, perhaps. I'm not quite sure what I need.
Well, you know the drill. You don't see it here, it's gonna cost you extra for me to get it.
I'm fully aware of the terms of our... arrangement.
Not yet. You know you're asking for some pretty strange stuff, don't you? It's not easy to find.
You assured me that you could find it, however.
I did, and I will. It's just tougher than I thought.
Have you gotten the items I requested from you?
Good!
All right, let's give this a try. Ready your ward...
What's that? Oh yes, yes. Thank you, I will.
Are you looking for any specific volumes, Drevis?
Hmm? Oh, no. No, not really. I... Actually, I've forgotten what I was looking for.
Ah. Well, then. Let me know if you need anything.
Did she, perhaps, mention any dangerous research she might be working on? Anything that could get her in trouble?
Can I help you with anything, Nirya?
I'm here to help you with books, Nirya. That's all.
Ah, yes. Of course. No, I don't need anything.
I was wondering. Has Faralda been in recently? Borrowed any books that you can recall?
Nirya...
This is why I avoid being social.
Oh! Well... I... I'm sorry. Yes, we have been working on something together.
You've been spending a fair bit of time with Sergius lately, I see.
Calm down! Why are you over-reacting? I was going to ask if the two of you are collaborating on research!
What? Why, the audacity! How dare you imply such a thing!
I... see.
I only wish to escape the constant glaring of my "colleagues" and discover an opportunity for repose. Your Arcanaeum is so lovely and quiet...
Don't fret, my fanged acquaintance. I shan't trouble you a bit.
Did you need something, Colette?
Ah, my dearest Urag! How are you today, my green-skinned friend?
So, you don't need anything then.
Oh, my dear Urag. You're trying so hard to help. I do hope you're not disappointed.
Was there something specific you needed?
"Disappointed" is not the word I would choose, Colette. Excuse me.
I'm positive whatever I require will be revealed to me on its own, in due time.
As always. The Nords don't ever stop wanting things enchanted.
Perhaps, but it just means more work for me.
Keeping busy, Sergius?
At least it's more money for the College.
Err, excuse me Enthir. Might I have a moment?
Yes, err, apologies for the intrusion. I was wondering, err, if you could possibly, ah, procure a few select items for me.
See that you do.
Really, Arniel? Because I seem to recall doing just that for you recently, at which point you assured me that you'd cover my expenses.
What is it?
And that, my nervous little friend, has not happened. Would you care to comment on that, perhaps?
Ahh, hmm. Yes. I, err, I was unaware that I had forgotten that. I will, err, I mean I'll take care of that as soon as possible.
Oh, no. Err, wouldn't do to say at all. Not, err, not now. Not at all. I have far too many things to do still.
So, Arniel. How's that little project of yours coming along? Any progress worth mentioning?
If you say so.
Oh, that. Err, yes. It's... It's quite promising, I believe. Definitely on the right track. Results, err, results should be soon.
Right. And what did you say the point of this little venture was?
No, and I'm not expecting any.
My family didn't really approve of me coming here at all.
Still no word from your family?
Oh. Well, that's... awkward. Sorry to have brought it up.
Really? That must be so nice. I came all the way to Skyrim just to get away from my family's expectations.
No, not really. Couriers don't seem to like delivering letters here.
Ah, that's too bad.
Have you heard from your family recently?
Not at all. It means I'm not being hounded about my progress at the College.
J'zargo continues to struggle with wards. You have time to practice?
J'zargo understands. You hesitate because you know J'zargo will be better than you. Very well.
Maybe later. I'm sort of busy now.
Why, because I'm a Dunmer? We didn't all grow up in dwarven ruins, you know.
Do you think you might, err, have a moment to look at something for me?
Yes, I just thought perhaps you'd have, err, come across something like this before.
If this is another dwarven trinket, I keep telling you I'm not familiar with them.
Well, err, yes. Sorry to have troubled you.
Don't even talk to me, Gane.
Hello, Nirya.
Ah, err, yes. Sorry.
Ugh. What do you want?
I'm busy right now, Colette.
Well, then. Fine. Have a nice day.
Why should I want anything? Why can't I simply be sociable with my colleagues?
How are you, Drevis?
Some days I marvel that you haven't managed to blow yourself up.
What are you up to, Gane? Hmm?
What? Err, nothing!
There's talk of it, but I find it hard to believe.
I do hope it's true. So many opportunities...
Opportunities for what?
What? Oh, nothing. It's just... It's an interesting development.
Is it true? Are there really dragons in Skyrim?
You haven't heard any more about dragon sightings, have you?
No, which is fine with me.
A pity. You have any idea how much fangs would be worth? Or even better -- bottle their flame. The right buyer would pay an immense amount.
Bottle... their flame? I can't... No, I don't think I've any interest in that sort of thing.
Your schedule is always clear, Arch-Mage. I see to that.
Ah, yes. True. Well, thank you.
Mirabelle, would you please make sure my schedule is clear for the next few days? I'm working on something important.
Forgive me, but at what point does it become our concern?
Never. The College cannot become mired in local politics. What happens inside these walls is our worry. What happens outside is theirs.
Sir, the Imperial Legion has again requested assistance. What shall I tell them?
The same thing we've told them before, and the same thing we've told these Stormcloaks. It's not our concern.
I'm dealing with a few new research proposals, evaluating the results of three long-term projects, and keeping an eye on our new Apprentices.
There were also two items requiring disciplinary action recently.
Everything's under control, then? Right. Keep up the good work.
Is there anything new I should be aware of, Mirabelle?
Yes, thank you Arch-Mage.
Arch-Mage, the Synod have contacted us again, asking if we've any word on their researchers. What shall I tell them?
That hasn't changed, has it? Then just tell them again.
No, I don't think so. Respond to their request, and we'll leave it at that.
What did you tell them last time?
That they had arrived, asked for information which was provided to them, and went on their way with no suggestion of further interaction.
Should we consider investigating the matter?
Yes, Arch-Mage. Thank you.
I've had yet another complaint. Please stop barging in on experiments in progress.
My dear, I am merely observing the proceedings.
Well then "observe" from a greater distance. You're making people uncomfortable.
I continue to hear things about dragon sightings in Skyrim.
Would you like me to send someone? Faralda or Phinis, perhaps?
I'll think about it.
Dragons? Well, that's fascinating. We should have someone look into that.
Hooray for the Arch-Mage!
Glory to the Arch-Mage!
Well done, well done indeed!
Congratulations!
Long live the Arch-Mage!
Members of the College -- your new Arch-Mage!
Don't just walk away from me! Where do you think you're going?

And what, you think that'll solve all your problems?

I suppose that's a benefit to having so few customers.
Are we running low on mead?
Let's just keep an eye on the supply. It's such a chore to restock.
How long are we going to let Ranmir drink himself into a stupor? When will enough be enough?
As long as he keeps paying, I suppose. He keeps to himself, and isn't hurting anyone.
It's not my place to get involved in their family's business, remember? You're the one that told me to stay out of it.
Are you so sure of that? I think Birna might disagree with you.
It's just children playing, Haran. I wouldn't fret over it.
I'm not "fretting." I don't want Eirid playing those sorts of games!
All right, all right. I'll speak to her.
I understand Eirid's been playing "Hunt the Elf" again.
I understand Korir's been complaining about our customers again.
I believe he was suggesting their presence causes him harm.
What of it? It's our Inn, and they cause him no harm.
Well, then he's welcome to eat and drink at home, isn't he?
Well, isn't this a surprise!
If I wanted to get yelled at, I'd be home. Can't you leave me be?
How much of our money have you spent today, Ranmir? Anything left, or is it all gone?
Oh, I'm sorry. Am I bothering you? Am I making your life more difficult?
Please, come home. Just... Just come home.
Why don't you go... sell something.
Ha! Drink ain't gonna kill me. Not today, anyway.
Can't. Got at least two rounds to go.
Why? Because I'd rather be here trying to keep my only brother from drinking himself to death.
Is everything well, Nelacar?
And there haven't been any... problems?
Oh yes, quite fine. My accommodations here continue to be just what I need.
Are you referring to your other customers? No, everything is quite all right. I expect a bit of animosity now and then.
I see. Well, let me know if things get out of hand.
No, certainly not. A small experiment may have gone awry, but clearly with no discernable consequences.
I say, you didn't hear any loud noises last night, did you? No, ahh... explosion sounds?
I... see. And is this something I'll need to worry about in the future?
No, I certainly didn't!
Oh, certainly I hope not! That would be quite unfortunate for my research.
Is there a reason you're asking me?
I'm sorry, could you describe the smell?
It was a minor miscalculation. I've already corrected it for future experiments.
This, this is why people have a problem with your college, Nelacar.
Like some horrible monster was turned inside out, and then exploded. What did you do?
Yes, that will be fine. Thank you.
I shall inform you the moment something noteworthy happens.
There is no news, I'm afraid.
So, what's the latest exciting news about goings-on in Winterhold?
None? Nothing at all? Nothing from the College, even?
As you wish.
Well, he's been very busy. Perhaps today he'll have some free time.
Again? Are you sure? He still hasn't answered your last several requests.
Will you be needing anything special today?
Why don't you see if Arch-Mage Aren is interested in joining me for a meal?
No, I don't think so. Not today.
Malur, I need you to take care of something.
I haven't even said what it is.
Doesn't really matter. Thanks, but no.
Aren't they all?
I'm sure you're right.
Looks to be another cold day.
Not like this. Feels colder than usual. Bet it's those damned Mages.
It's clear that memories are far too short.
And it's clear money matters more to Dagur than honor.
This is what it's come to. No one seems to care what they've done to our home.
That... wizard is still at the Inn. I can't believe Dagur allows him to stay there.
Eirid's a little girl who doesn't understand that they're responsible for destroying our home.
Because they don't care about you or I, cub. They think they're better than all of us, and that we can just be thrown away.
That's my boy.
Eirid says the mages at the College are nice people, but you said they're bad.
Why did they do that? Why would they be so evil?
I hate them.
Let's see if this works...
No, but that won't account for the size issue. Blast, if only so many of these creatures hadn't escaped.
Perhaps some more Glow Dust in the next batch of potions. That should increase their resistance.

Get ready. Trouble ahead. Yuck. Something smells. Trouble is in the air here. I've got a bad feeling about this. Keep your blade ready. I don't like where this is going. I want you sellswords out of my mine.

The Silver-Bloods have made you a very generous offer for this pile of dirt. I suggest you take it.
I... Yes, I understand.
Falion, I am disappointed. I'm told that you're up to something out in the marsh, Falion.
What is the meaning of this?
You've been exploring places you shouldn't, and you know it. I don't even want to know what it is you've been doing.
It stops at once, or else there will be consequences of an unpleasant nature. Do you understand? It doesn't happen again, or else I'll have you thrown in jail. Clear?
(screams)

This... This is really from her, isn't it?
Did she really run off and do this? For me?
I... I have some thinking to do. Thank you for this.
The prominent feature here is the Hall of the Elements. It's our primary location for lectures, practice sessions, and general meetings.
The College of Winterhold has been a fixture in Skyrim for thousands of years.
Unfortunately, we've had to implement more stringent entry procedures, due to some problems with the local Nords.
We don't anticipate any real violence, but it never hurts to be prepared.
Now I'll show you to your quarters. You're going to be sharing space with your fellow Apprentices, who you'll meet shortly.
This is where you'll be staying. This bed and desk are yours. Please try and be considerate of others.
Now, let's go back to the Hall of the Elements, where most of the members gather for lectures and study sessions.
Initially you'll be learning from Tolfdir, one of our most esteemed Wizards.
Our newest members are housed here in the Hall of Attainment.
I'll ask that you please keep your voice down while inside, as others may be working on research or... delicate experiments.
Tolfdir is likely already addressing the new Apprentices. Go on in, and if you have any problems, let one of our senior members know.
Please, please! This is exactly what I'm talking about. Eagerness must be tempered with caution, or else disaster is inevitable.
Sir, I think we all understand that fairly well. We wouldn't be here if we couldn't control magic!
Unless you can control it, it can and will destroy you.
So, as I was saying, the first thing to understand is that magic is, by its very nature, volatile and dangerous.
Then what are we waiting for? Let's get started!
What I'm talking about is true control, mastery of magic. It takes years, if not decades, of practice and study.
Of course, my dear. Of course. You all certainly possess some inherent natural ability. That much is not being questioned.
But we've only just arrived here -- you've no idea what any of us are capable of. Why not give us a chance to show you what we can do?
Welcome, welcome! We were just beginning. Please, stay and listen.
See? He agrees with us too! Why don't you actually show us something? See? She agrees with us too! Why don't you actually show us something?
Oh, don't listen to him. We can do it, just give us a chance! Oh, don't listen to her. We can do it, just give us a chance!
We're all pretty new at this, right? Let's just give it a chance. What's the worst that could happen?
I'll teach you all a ward, and we'll see if you can successfully use it to block spells, all right?
In continuing with our theme of safety, we'll start with Wards. Wards are protective spells that block magic.
All right, let's settle down. I suppose we can try something practical...
You must first prove your worth, and then I shall lead you across.
You risk death by doing so, and you shall not gain entry.
Do not cross the bridge unaided!
Now, cast the ward spell, and keep it up.
Excellent work!
Hold still...
You have to keep your ward up, or else this won't work. I don't want to hurt you.
The College has undertaken a fascinating excavation in the ruins of Saarthal nearby. It's an excellent learning opportunity.
Well, I think this is an excellent start. I'd like you all to continue practicing with wards, please.
I suggest we meet there in a few hours, and see what awaits us inside. That's all for now, thank you.
I think perhaps we're ready to begin exploring some of the various applications of magic throughout history.
You may be used to the Empire bowing to your every whim, but I'm afraid you'll find the Thalmor receive no such treatment here.
Yes of course. I'm simply trying to understand the reasoning behind the decision.
Very good. Then we're done here.
Yes, of course. The Arch-Mage has my thanks.
I believe I've made myself rather clear.
You are a guest of the College, here at the pleasure of the Arch-Mage. I hope you appreciate the opportunity.
I really do need you to stay in place, please. I don't want to risk hurting any of the other Apprentices.
Over there, please. Just opposite me. Wouldn't want anyone else in the way.
While technically in charge of the College, the Arch-Mage's responsibilities often keep him occupied. Thus, I run the day-to-day operations.
Now, if you'll please follow me, I'll show you the living quarters.
The Arcanaeum is located above the hall, and the Arch-Mage's quarters above that.
I have responsibilities to attend to. We'll continue this discussion some other time.
Onmund, please search that area over there. See if you notice any... residual energies. Alive or undead.
Now, let's see. What shall we have the rest of you do?
J'zargo... what shall we have you do... Ah! Why don't you verify that we're the first ones here? Look for any amount of tampering with the tombs.
Brelyna, my dear, why don't you search for warding magics. Anything designed to keep people out. Don't interact with them, just identify them.
All right, everyone. Let's be careful, but have fun!
This warning is passed to you because the Psijic Order believes in you.
Hold, mage, and listen well...
Judgment will be passed on your actions to come, and how you deal with the dangers ahead of you.
You, mage, and you alone, have the potential to prevent disaster.
Judgment has not been passed, as you had no way of knowing.
Know that you have set in motion a chain of events that cannot be stopped.
Take great care, and know that the Order is watching.
I think perhaps it might be best if you lead the way. My eyes aren't what they used to be.
Don't worry, I'll stay right with you.
This is all very strange. I've never seen anything like this.
Well, this is highly unusual. And very interesting.
As some of you may know, Saarthal was one of the earliest Nord settlements in Skyrim. It was also the largest.
Sacked by the elves in the infamous "Night of Tears," not much is known about what happened to Saarthal.
Why in the world would this be sealed off? What is this place?
This is an exciting opportunity for us. To be able to study such an early civilization, and the magics they used...
I thought it high time I caught up with you.
Hold on, my boy. Hold on! Hold on, my dear. Hold on!
I'm not the only one seeing this, am I?
Why, this is utterly unique.
I never imagined we'd find something like this.
Why is this buried so far within Saarthal?
Well now... would you look at that.
Do you see that?
I wonder... what effect might your spells have?
Some kind of resonance... you and the wall. It must be connected to the amulet!
There! Now attack it!
Keep it busy. I'll try to drain some of its power!
Nothing seems to work!
There's a lever, right there in the center. Hurry, before more of them show up!
You have to let me out. They're going to do something awful to me!
Please, please let me out of here!
I, uhh... wait, what?
He gets the books, I get you. It's very simple. She gets the books, I get you. It's very simple.
You wouldn't do that, would you? You wouldn't leave me here with her!
I'm waiting.
We need to go upstairs, that's where she is! That's where the books are!
No, no! This is the wrong way!

Really, I think there's been a mistake. May I just speak with her, please, to clear all this up? Just let me out of here. I only wanted to help you! Okay, now can you let me out? Please? I won't tell anyone it was you. Just open the cage, and I'll leave quietly. Won't make a sound, won't bother you at all.
Quiet down. Stop your whining. She said you stay in there, and that's final. I'll give you something to cry about if you don't quiet down.
The undercroft is ahead... ugh, Necromancers. Be careful.
The library is just through here. We're getting close now.
This little adventure of yours has cost me a number of test subjects. I need more, and you'll do nicely.

We don't know that. We don't even know what it is. Where is Aren, anyway?
I still don't see why we had to bring it back here.
The Arch-Mage believed it important. It must be powerful.
In his quarters, with that Thalmor, Ancano. Something urgent, it sounded like.
All right, that's enough. Let's return to our business please. All right, that's enough. Back to bed, please.
Look out! The prisoners are loose!
Hmm? What is it?
Go, boys! Attack!
And begin.

Again!
Ah, a test subject! Go, my pets! Attack!
Well? What is the meaning of this?

Don't play coy. You asked to see a specific member of the College. Here he is. Now what is it that you want? Don't play coy. You asked to see a specific member of the College. Here she is. Now what is it that you want?
There's been a misunderstanding. Clearly I should not be here. I shall simply take my leave.
I'm sorry, I'm afraid I don't understand.
I am not "up to" anything. I apologize if I have offended in any way.
Now, I'm not sure that you're quite as attuned as I am, given my extensive years of experience, but can you feel that?
Now, I...

Yes, I've no doubt of its gravity. This, however, is a matter that cannot wait.

This marvelous object. It practically radiates magicka, and yet it's unlike anything I've felt before.
We will see about this...

Ayleid, Dwemer, Daedric... Not even Falmer. None of them are a match. Quite curious indeed.
"Night of Tears", by Dranor Seleth. Old book, one I'd forgotten about. This thing here... it might be what the book was about.
Here's something to consider, Mirabelle.
He proposed that the real reason Saarthal was fought over by the Elves and the Nords was because something was unearthed there.

Something arcane. Very old, very powerful. Do you think...?

Please remain calm!
Everyone please, stand back!

What's happened? He's not...
Do we have to? They'd never lift a finger to help us.
We'll stay here. Get back to the College and let them know what's going on.
Come on, Arniel. Let's go.
That looks like it's the last of them.
You only face failure once more...
Nivahriin muz fent siiv nid aaz het.
You... You are not Aren, are you? Has he sent you in his place?
Have you returned, Aren? My old friend?
You do not answer... Must I use this guttural language of yours?
Did he warn you that your own power would be your undoing? That it would only serve to strengthen me?
Come. Face your end.
Do you seek to finish that which you could not?
Wo meyz wah dii vul junaar?
It was Atmah's idea to come here, at first. She talked me into it, and I convinced the others.
Savos is right. We can make it if we just stay alert.
We all knew this was the end. Without even opening the door, we knew what was behind it would kill us.
You keep talking like you're sure we'll find something useful in here.
Elvali died here. I don't even remember what killed her. One of the countless faceless horrors. I think she was glad, in that final moment.
Now you've put it all to rest, but it can't undo my mistakes. They can never be undone...
There were six of us. Full of ambition, eager to conquer the world.
We can't go back. Might as well go forward. We can still do this.
What happened after was my fault. All mine.
Can you imagine the looks on their faces when we come back?
We could have turned back. It could have ended there. But we kept going.
That's how I consoled myself for years, after I'd sealed this place shut and vowed never to let anyone open it.
But now it all comes out again...
Gods, what have we done?
I was in charge now. I pushed them on, insisting it would be worse to try and go back.
I can't believe we're doing this.
When it was over, Atmah, Hafnar and I stared, pale-faced, at one another, unwilling to admit we'd made a terrible mistake.
If we'd all died there, if we'd loosed the thing on the world, who knows what might have happened?
I never meant for any of what happened here. Tried to seal it up, lock it away forever.
It's too late. There isn't enough of him left to go back in after.
Atmah cried to herself. Hafnar wouldn't look at either of us. And I kept telling them it would be all right.
Let's just get inside, see what's in there.
And then we were all fighting just to survive. None of us were prepared. It was amazing the rest of us survived.
It would seem I'm bound to this place. The bitter irony of it all -- my greatest failure, and even in death I can't escape it.
We barely made it out alive, and you want to go back in?
I've no idea what killed her, but I'm sure something did.
Don't forget, this whole idea was Atmah's to begin with.
I had to leave them behind, had to sacrifice them so I could make it out alive.
I knew you'd come eventually.
We... we have to go back. We can't leave Girduin...
There were only three of us left. Takes-In-Light just sat down and gave up, and we left her there to die.
You would care about that, since you're the Arch-Mage's favorite!
One moment we joked about what we'd find below, the next he'd been ripped in half.
I had no choice, don't you see?
Against six College-trained mages? I think we'll be fine.
"If we can just make it through, it'll all be worth it", I told them. And the fools believed the words I myself didn't trust.
We'll be back at the College before anyone even knows we're gone.
Girduin died first. It happened so fast, none of us had a chance to react.
"No matter what, we stay together", Hafnar said. I looked him in the eyes and lied to him.
And what if... What if there are things guarding this place?
Are we truly sure this is a good idea?
We thought it would be so simple.
Enchanted weapons, tomes of ancient knowledge, Shalidor's secrets themselves -- who knows what we could find!
I... I don't know why I pressed the others on, convinced them to keep going.
Come on, we're finally here! Let's not waste any more time!
We were sure we'd find it all here, hidden away from time. Power, knowledge... All the things we didn't want to wait for.
What was that thing, anyway?
None of our spells were potent enough, none of our wills were strong enough.
Given the history of this place, it's more than likely there's still some amount of power here.
Hafnar was covered in blood, but his stupid Nord pride wouldn't let him admit defeat.
...I'm sorry, friends. I'm so sorry!
I don't think going back is a good idea.
Agreed. We all stay together.
You're right. This is all my fault. Should we turn around, head back?
I'll be right with you.
This is insanity. We never should've come here.
We stay together, no matter what. Agreed?
Dead. Something grabbed her from behind. Gone before I could do anything.
We're not going to make it, are we?
Where's Elvali? She was right behind me.
This is it, you know. Through this door. Can you feel it?
Come on, we can't stop now. We have to keep moving!
What else could we do? Stay there and die with her? She refused to go on, we didn't have a choice!
Just another minute, please.
I promise you, I'll never let this happen again! I'll seal this whole place away...
We shouldn't have left her there to die!
Come on, you can make it. Let's go.
I had no choice! It was the only way to make sure that monster never escaped!
Going back would be the end of all of us. We keep pushing forward, and we'll make it. We will!
How much worse is this going to get? We need to get in there and stop this!
I'm as ready as I'm going to be.
Not until we're all ready. We have to go together.
What are we waiting for?
No, no. You just stay here and rest.
You want to stay here, fine. But the rest of us aren't giving up now.
We'll come back for you as soon as we've reached our goal. You have my word.
I don't care... We're going all the way in. I want to know what Shalidor hid in here.
Be on your guard. I've no idea what to expect inside the College.
The power to unmake the world at my fingertips, and you think you can do anything about it?
Head for the Great Hall, quickly! Don't stop for anything!
You've come for me, have you?
Come then. See what I can do now.
You think I don't know what you're up to? You think I can't destroy you?
Still you persist? Very well.
Enough!
The staff! Use it on the Eye!
I am beyond your pathetic attempts at magic. You cannot touch me.
Spells have no effect!
No! You will not deny me this!
You cannot take this away from me!
No! The Eye is mine!
He's no longer abusing the power of the Eye. I would've expected all this to stop.
And yet...
You've done it! You've beaten him!
Please, follow me. I'll escort you inside the College.
You do indeed have the power. I'm impressed.
Oh dear. That wasn't supposed to happen.
This really isn't turning out the way I'd hoped.
There! Now, I...
Let me try again...
Please hold still, and don't move.
Oh no, that's not it at all.
There! All better.
Just wait. Just... I can fix this.
Oh my. That isn't right!
Okay, now don't move at all.
You have to hold still or this isn't going to work.
Do you... do you feel all right? You look very, umm, green.
I'll get it right this time, I swear.
Right, then...
But please, don't leave. You've been instrumental in this process. I'd like you to see the results first-hand.
Well, I suppose it's time, isn't it? Let's see what happens. You, uhh... You may want to stand back a step or two.
I certainly don't expect it to have quite the same results. I'm no tonal architect, of course!
I also lack Sunder, the counterpart to the dagger Keening. I am reasonably, confident, however, that this will still work.
Lacking the heart of a dead god, I am substituting the crystal you helped craft in its place.
Work, damn you!
This little experiment is a first step in recreating the events of their disappearance in an effort to unravel that mystery.
I don't understand. This should produce some notable effect.
Everyone knows the dwarves disappeared. No one knows why.
Perhaps a little harder?
I apologize if I have not been clear about my work. I didn't want to discuss it for fear this moment might never come.
Hmm. That... That didn't really do anything, did it?
And so it is done.
Ahh, yes. I see it now.
I need only look for a few moments...
It's magnificent, isn't it?
You are worthy. The knowledge is yours.
Then, finally, realization and horror arrive together. The orange is flame, heat. The sound a roar, a challenge in their ancient tongue.
But now it's too late for escape. The dragon is upon me - fire and darkness descending like a thunderbolt.
And not just any dragon, but the Dragon - Alduin, the World-Eater, the dragon who devours both the living and the dead.
Then it came again, this time more distinct. Closer. Definitely not lightning now. It was orange - brilliant orange, the color of hearth and dawn.
And a sound, too. Distinct and indistinct. Not thunder... something else. Something I should recognize, but in the dream I cannot place it.
Then came the flash of light - just on the horizon, within the clouds that mark the border between worlds.
It could have been lightning, but there was no thunder. In the dream, the sense of foreboding grew, but I could never wake up.
I used to dream of it. In the dream, I was standing... someplace high up... a tower, or mountain.
It was always just before dawn. The whole world was in darkness.
And then I would wake up. And hope that it was just a dream... but know that it was not.
I want to leave my high place, to seek shelter. From what, I don't yet know.
In the manner of dreams, I cannot escape. I'm forced to wait and watch.
Yes, papa.
Inside the house. Now.
Why? I want to watch the soldiers.
This looks like the way out! I was starting to wonder if we'd ever make it.
This way. Come on, hurry up. Better to stick together down here.
There you go. Take a look around, there should be plenty of gear to choose from. I'm going to see if I can find something for these burns.
Let me see if I can get that door open.
We should keep moving. Come here. Let me see if I can get those bindings off.
Looks like we're the only ones who made it. Was that really a dragon? The bringers of the End Times?
Let's keep moving. That thing is still out there.
Come on, this way.
Didn't you hear me? I said the keep is under attack!
Don't you even know what's going on? A dragon is attacking Helgen!
Come with us. We need to get out of here.
There's no way out that way, you know...
Come on!
Forget the old man. I'll come with you.
An old storeroom. See if you can find some potions. Might come in handy. An old storeroom. Grab anything you can, but let's keep moving.
Look out!
A dragon? Please. Don't make up nonsense.
Hold on, now, we only want to...
Damn, that dragon doesn't give up easy.
You have no authority over me, boy.
You fellows happened along just in time. These boys seemed a bit upset at how I've been entertaining their comrades.
Grab what you can, and let's go.
Although, come to think of it, I did hear some odd noises coming from over there.
Hear that?
I guess we'd better try this way.
Go ahead. I'll follow your lead and watch your back.
Hmm. That doesn't go anywhere.
No, I haven't seen him since the dragon showed up.
I hate those damn things. Too many eyes, you know?
What next, giant snakes?
You've got to tell them! We weren't with you! This is a mistake!
Whoa!
Why are we stopping?
Let's go. Shouldn't keep the gods waiting for us.
No! Wait! We're not rebels!
Why do you think? End of the line.
We better get moving. Come here. Let me see if I can get those bindings off.
We'll meet again in Sovngarde, brother.
Here we are, found a key. Let's see if it opens that door.
This one's locked. Let's see about that gate.
There you go. You may as well take Gunjar's gear. He won't be needing it any more.
That's it! Come on, let's get out of here before the dragon brings the whole tower down on our heads.
Maybe one of these Imperials had the key.
Looks like we're the only ones who made it.
I'm going to see if I can find some way out of here.
Damn. No way to open this from our side.
Wait a second. Looks like there's something in this cage.
A storeroom. See if you can find any potions. We'll need them. A storeroom. Grab anything you can, but let's keep moving.
Was Jarl Ulfric with you? Shor's bones. We were too late. Damn the Empire.
We'd better push on. The rest of them will have to find another way out.
Not the sneaking type, huh?
Let's see where this goes.
Hold up. There's a bear just ahead. See her?
Whew. That was close. Sneaking is overrated, eh?
No going back that way, now.
That thing was a dragon. No doubt. Just like the children's stories and the legends. The harbingers of the End Times.
Almost there.
I'd rather not tangle with her right now. Let's try to sneak by. Just take it nice and slow, and watch where you step.
That looks like the way out! I knew we'd make it!
It's the Imperials! Take cover!
It's the escaped prisoners! Get this gate open.
This looks like the way.
You'd better get out of that Stormcloak gear. Today's not the day to go around dressed like a rebel.
This is Helgen. I used to be sweet on a girl from here. Wonder if Vilod is still making that mead with juniper berries mixed in.
See if you can unlock that door. Did you find a key? See if it unlocks that door. Unlock that door and let's get out of here.
And what's wrong with him, huh?
I don't know where we're going, but Sovngarde awaits.
But if they've captured you.... Oh gods, where are they taking us?

I guess we're lucky that didn't come down on top of us.
I'd rather not tangle with her right now. We might be able to sneak by. Just take it nice and slow, and watch where you step.
We'd better push on. I'm sure the others will find another way out.
Damn it. No going back that way.
Easy does it now.
Let's go on ahead. See if the way is clear.
I better stay back and see to the old man. Good luck you two.
All right, let's see if we can find a way out.
I'll keep watch in case Ulfric comes through here. Talos guide the both of you.
To the block, prisoner. Nice and easy.

Next, the Nord in the rags! Next, the lizard! Next, the Breton! Next, the dark elf! Next, the high elf! Next, the renegade from Cyrodiil! Next, the cat! Next, the Orc! Next, the Redguard! Next, the wood elf!
Forget the list. He goes to the block. Forget the list. She goes to the block.
Follow the Captain, prisoner.
As we commend your souls to Aetherius, blessings of the Eight Divines upon you, for you are the salt and earth of Nirn, our beloved....

Captain. What should we do? He's not on the list. Captain. What should we do? She's not on the list.
Who are you?

Guards, get the townspeople to safety!
Someone get the battlemages out here. Now!
Don't just stand there! Kill that thing!

What in Oblivion is that?
Ulfric Stormcloak. Jarl of Windhelm.
Lokir of Rorikstead.

Troll's blood! It's a torture room.
The torture room. Gods, I wish we didn't need these....
Who are they, daddy? Where are they going?

Done? Let's get moving.
Done, then? This way!
Hear that? Stormcloaks. Maybe we can reason with them.
Just give me a minute... I'm out of breath...
We need to get moving! That dragon is tearing up the whole keep!

Not many wood elves would choose to come alone to Skyrim. What're you doing here, Redguard? You a sellsword? A sailor from Stros M'kai?  You from one of the strongholds, Orc? How did you end up here? You're a long way from the Imperial City. What're you doing in Skyrim? You're not with the Thalmor Embassy, are you high elf? No, that can't be right.... Another refugee? Gods really have abandoned your people, dark elf. You from Daggerfall, Breton? Fleeing from some court intrigue? You with one of the trade caravans, Khajiit? Your kind always seems to find trouble. Are you a relative of one of the Riften dock workers, Argonian? You picked a bad time to come home to Skyrim, kinsman.
Anyone else feel like running?
No, I'm not a rebel. You can't do this!
Face your death with some courage, thief.
Ralof of Riverwood.
Step towards the block when we call your name. One at a time.
My ancestors are smiling at me, Imperials. Can you say the same?
Come on, I haven't got all morning.
For the love of Talos, shut up and let's get this over with.
Wait. You there. Step forward.
Empire loves their damn lists.
